name: Presidente. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on 17 January 2019.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Knobloch. Excellencies, distinguished guests, Mr President of the European Commission, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, Prime Minister, gentlemen of the Romanian Government, ladies and gentlemen, today we are celebrating Remembrance Day and commemorating the victims of the Holocaust: Jewish communities, ethnic minorities, such as the Roma and Sinti, homosexuals, the disabled and all those people deemed undesirable by the Nazi regime.  For the first time on Remembrance Day in the Hemicycle of the European Parliament during the plenary session. With this gesture, we are sending out a strong signal today more than ever: we must not forget; we don't want to forget. We renew our commitment to keep the memory alive and to fight non-stop all forms of hatred, discrimination and anti-Semitism.  Perpetuating the memory of the unprecedented crimes of the Holocaust is not just an act of commemoration: it is an essential stage in the process of personal and collective healing. The Holocaust must remain a perennial warning. We must no longer tolerate acts of violence and racial hatred. According to data from the latest Eurobarometer, 50% of European citizens believe that anti-Semitism is a problem in their own country. This is proof that, unfortunately, the anti-Semitism virus has not yet been eradicated. We must react firmly to any re-surface of the shoots of hatred. Our values and history are stronger than intolerance and violence. Europe has demonstrated this more than once. The European Parliament has been and will always be at the side of those who suffer acts of hatred and discrimination.  In 2016 we organised a high-level conference on the future of Jewish communities in Europe. In 2017 we adopted our first resolution against anti-Semitism. Together we must do more to defend the principles of the United Nations resolution that established Remembrance Day: to promote educational programmes, to reject any denial of the Holocaust and to unreservedly condemn any manifestation of intolerance on an ethnic or religious basis. Our message today is very clear: there is no place in the European Union for hatred and anti-Semitism. We will not allow the tragic mistakes of the past to be repeated: 'never again'. We will hear the testimony of Dr Charlotte Knobloch, President of the Jewish Community of Munich and Upper Bavaria. Charlotte Knobloch was only three years old when she was banned from playing with other children in her neighborhood. She was Jewish and that was her only fault.  She miraculously survived the Holocaust authorities thanks to a Christian woman who worked with her family. Charlotte Knobloch dedicated her life to a courageous fight against hatred and anti-Semitism. All our gratitude goes to you. I invite you, Madam President, to reach the lectern and to speak before the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: Charlotte Knobloch
text: former president of the Central Council of Jews in Germany. Mr Tajani, thank you for your introductory, reassuring and excellent words; President Juncker, Excellency, Prime Minister Michel, students present, members of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you very much, Mr President, for the invitation that I was happy to accept. Because a visit to the European Parliament is always something very special for me. Let those you regularly go in and out of this building say to me as a guest: it is an uplifting feeling to be here. This House is not a Parliament like any other. Certainly, each of you has been elected to this Chamber as a representative of your country and your party. They are all here to make policy in the democratic competition and to create a good future for the citizens of Europe. But that's not all. Behind this lectern and above the Bureau, you see not only a national flag, as in the national parliaments, but 28. In the middle, they frame the blue-yellow flag, which stands for the idea of European unity – an idea to which you, as Members of this Parliament, are committed. This semi-circle does not only create laws – it creates common ground. And it symbolises the values on which Europe still builds and on which European unification rests: freedom, democracy, human rights, openness, tolerance and the will to peaceful coexistence. For many of us – myself included – it was hard to imagine how these ideals today determine everyday life in Europe. Too oppressive and too comprehensive in my youth I experienced the rule of barbarism, which wanted to know nothing human and destroyed and murdered without inhibition. I lost almost everything at that time: many of my loved ones, my home, my primal trust in the world and in the people. More than once it was luck or chance that saved my life. For years I lived in a hiding place – under a false name and with a false identity. If I had been myself, it would have meant my safe death sentence. I can stand here today because, among all the many murderers, followers and indifferent, there were also people who risked their lives to preserve their humanity. I can stand here today because the light of humanity has never completely extinguished even in the darkest time in human history. But even against this background, one thing was quite clear to me: at the first opportunity, my godly husband and I would leave Germany and Europe. This continent seemed to spoil us at that time. Everywhere we wanted to build a new life – but not here. The birth of our children meant that we had to put our emigration plans on hold again and again. These children grew up in a country where insecurity and discomfort were the defining feelings for them and for the entire Jewish community.  In the early post-war decades, uncertainty without limited contact with the non-Jewish environment dominated. It was never known for sure who might have Jewish blood on his hands. The discomfort of continuing to live in this situation in the "land of the murderers" – that was our country at the time – was always palpable. Staying permanently in Germany seemed unimaginable to us in this situation. The fact that I am standing before you today is proof that – fortunately! – over the decades, much that would have been unimaginable before became possible. Who would have expected the democracies of the post-war period to prove so robust? Who would ever have thought it possible that centuries-old enmities could be overcome in Europe within just a few years? And who would have believed that after the unimaginable atrocities of the Holocaust, Jewish life would return to life in Europe, even in Germany? All this seems self-evident today. But, ladies and gentlemen, it is not. And the achievements are not always as stable as it seems at first glance. Unfortunately, this is becoming clear again these days. The post-war liberal and democratic order in Europe is now more than ever in jeopardy. I am not talking about the external threats to our cohesion. There is no doubt that the European idea would be up to them. What worries me far more is the attacks from within. Europe can continue to be "united in diversity" only if it is aware of its values and defends them, of course. (Applause) But this future is compellingly linked to the knowledge of the past. On 27 January, on the International Day to commemorate the Victims of the Holocaust remember the six million Jewish people murdered by Nazi Germany between 1933 and 1945. The liberation of the Auschwitz concentration camp, on whose anniversary the commemoration was scheduled, marked the 74th anniversary of this year. Fewer and fewer survivors can tell from their own view about the horrors they had to experience there. All the more important is the signal of the leading candidates of the Christian and Social Democrats for the upcoming European elections, Manfred Weber and Frans Timmermans, who travelled together to the memorial in Auschwitz after their nomination. Nevertheless, it remains a sad fact: more and more voices of memory are falling silent. The "time without witnesses" is imminent. For some, this circumstance leads to the misconception that the memory of the Holocaust and the memory of its victims are unnecessary today. Nothing could be more wrong. Nevertheless, we are seeing political movements gaining strength throughout Europe, which are firmly opposed to remembrance and to remembrance. What they propagate is a present without a past as a springboard into a future without memory. Unfortunately, it is no surprise that anti-Semitism is revived with such forgetting of history. We members of the Jewish community are already experiencing the consequences of this development. In Germany and many other EU states, Jewish life in public is only possible under police protection, and the sense of security of the Jewish population has been declining for years. It is true that the centres of Jewish life have returned to the cities everywhere; Synagogues and town halls were newly built as a sign of the new self-evidentness of coexistence. These buildings rest on a foundation of trust. I can tell myself from my own experience how long it took me to feel at home again in my hometown and birthplace of Munich after 1945. I only unpacked the proverbial suitcases for the opening of our new synagogue in November 2006. Today, however, I am constantly caught thinking that I might have been too hasty with these words. Trust among Jewish people is dwindling in many places. They had trusted that they would never be let down again in our country. They often suffer from hostility, verbal or pertancy – but they suffer even more from indifference, lack of understanding, lack of empathy. For wherever we look, everywhere the hatred of Jews raises its ugly head again today – in all social strata and in all areas of the political spectrum, from the political right to the radical left to deep into the middle; also in many Muslim milieus. Forces like the AfD, the representatives of the anti-Semitic BDS campaign and radical Muslims may have little in common – only anti-Semitism unite them all. Ladies present, of course, this is only half the truth. Fortunately, there are people all over Europe who are committed to memory and democracy and openness. Their voices are loud and numerous. In many, if not all, countries of the European Union, they make up a large majority of the population. But we must not rest on this numerical superiority. History has shown how difficult it can be for the majority to defend their ideals against a renegade minority. And so we see in contemporary European politics how quickly anti-Semitism spreads if it is not set limits in time. One of the most drastic examples of this development can be found in the United Kingdom today. The Labour Party, which has been a bastion of state-political reason throughout its long history, has become one of Europe's most blatant cases of political anti-Semitism in recent years, chaired by Jeremy Corbyn. Under the new leadership, Labour has far outstrowed the political centre. (Applause) It is clear that in the moral semi-darkness of such non-positioning, the most questionable political plants thrive. This example shows how quickly the departure from a policy of tolerance can take place when the omens are favorable. Labour under Corbyn is an example. Such developments cannot be explained solely by reference to the special political role of the United Kingdom – they are everywhere in Europe, and they show that something has slipped in our countries. Anti-Semitism is once again finding political and social space in many European countries. What has been smouldering for a long time comes to the surface today: Where hatred of Jews is not immediately and vigorously combated, it breaks Train. The latest anti-Semitism surveys have also shown this unequivocally. Mr President, you have already referred to this. Ladies and gentlemen, let me be very clear: a Europe in which 89% of the Jewish population complain of an increase in anti-Semitism in their home country has a problem. A Europe in which more than a third of the Jewish population has already seriously considered emigration has a problem. Hatred of Jews poisons the social climate as a whole. It makes a mockery of the fundamental European promise: freedom and security actually apply to every single citizen of Europe – or they do not apply to anyone. It fills me with sadness and sorrow that today, so many years after the end of the Holocaust, we have to deal with such widespread anti-Semitism once again and still. But it must be our duty to counter this development and to push it back. That is our responsibility. For the greatest tragedy in Jewish history took place here, in Europe. The cities that are now the centre of our lives were often the scene of the worst crime in human history, caused by the German government at the time, less than 80 years ago. Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, Ladies and Gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioners for their excellent work. They are the ones who guide the fortunes of the European Union. I therefore call on you to press hard today and in the future, even after the forthcoming election of this Parliament, against the rampant hatred of Jews. I hope that this Parliament will continue to shoulder its responsibilities in the future. The freedom and democracy we enjoy today are always as strong as the democrats' commitment to them – and the willingness of the majority to defend them against a energetic, hateful minority. We must not let this hatred prevail. Not again. "Never again" must not become a "Now again". (Members of Parliament rose and applauded the speaker)

name: Presidente. –
text: On behalf of the European Parliament, I would like to thank President Charlotte Knobloch for her valuable testimony, which is invaluable to all of us. We will now observe a minute's silence in memory of all the victims of the Holocaust, bearing in mind that in order to devote a minute to each of the victims, we should remain silent for over eleven years. After the minute's silence, we will hear Ravel's Kaddish played by the Queen Elizabeth Musical Chapel of Belgium. During the minute's silence, the drawings of the children held in the Terezin ghetto will be shown in the Chamber: there were about 15 000. Just 150 were saved. In a perennial memory of their tragedy, they left on paper their creations on display today in the Pinkas synagogue in Prague, to which we extend our heartfelt thanks.  More than a thousand words, these drawings illustrate their emotions in the face of atrocities that no child should ever suffer.  "Never again."  (The Members of the House observed a minute's silence) (The sitting was suspended for a few moments)

name: El presidente. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by talking about an issue which makes us very sad: Venezuela. As you know, last week, on the occasion of mass marches against the regime, the president of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, proclaimed himself interim president, relying on the Venezuelan Constitution. Soon, a large part of the international community, especially the States of Latin America, recognized it as such.  More than forty dead and nearly nine hundred arrests occurred during these protests. This afternoon, and next Saturday, the Venezuelan people will be back on the street calling for democracy, freedom and respect for human rights. The European Parliament in this parliamentary term has already ruled eight times on the situation in Venezuela. No other country had this attention. Unfortunately, the situation worsened and reached a point of no return. Maduro's regime has managed to get more than three million people to leave their own country. It is the most important migration phenomenon in the history of Latin America. If things don't change very soon in Venezuela, it will be compounded by disastrous consequences for the entire region. In the face of last week's events, the European Parliament cannot be silent. I spoke by phone with President Guaidó, our only interlocutor, to assure him of the support of the European Parliament. We have awarded Venezuela's democratic opposition the 2017 Sakharov Prize. We were the first institution to denounce human rights violations, to call for sanctions against the regime, to call for a regional strategy to help in the refugee crisis. Some countries are only interested in oil. We care about the people and suffering of the Venezuelan population.  (You can hear applause and a mocking laugh)  (Heading to the place where laughter comes from): "Risus abounds in ore stultorum". Ask for the Latin translation.  In speaking out, we should not only think about a peaceful solution and a democratic transition, but also reflect on the reconstruction of the country, so that people return to a normal life with food and medicine. Venezuela is going to need a lot of help and investment. The European Union must be at the side of Venezuelans. In the face of historical events where democracy is at risk, it is clear that we must be on the side of freedom and human rights and not oppression.

name: Presidente. –
text: The Minutes and texts adopted at the sitting of 17 January have been distributed. Are there any comments? (The Minutes of the previous sitting were approved)

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for twelve days now, the Italian Government has been holding 47 migrants rescued in the Mediterranean hostage, with the complicity of other European governments that deliberately build their shameful election campaign on the skin of migrants. What is happening off the port of Syracuse is a disgrace to europe as a whole: a land of freedom.  The management of migration must be brought back to the centre of the parliamentary debate and dealt with with the instruments at our disposal, in full compliance with Article 80: solidarity and a fair distribution of responsibilities. That is why, Mr President, I call for a debate on the Sea Watch case to be opened at this part-session, so that such incidents never happen again, either in Europe or elsewhere in the world.  Allow me to make a personal comment, Mr President: in these two days that I have spent in Syracuse, the role of MEMBERS of the European Parliament has been strongly called into question and I believe that it is your responsibility to defend the role of Members of the European Parliament, because access for inspection visits has been denied. I believe that this cannot happen, either in Italy or in any other country, because the Member of the European Parliament is free to play his role in all places, even where people have been deprived of their freedom.

name: Presidente. –
text: If the Member States of the Union had approved the Dublin reform as proposed by the European Parliament, this would never have happened. Neither this nor anything like it. I therefore believe that there is a strong message to send to the Member States: hurry up and approve the Dublin reform.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, similarly to Ms Kyenge I would like to suggest and recommend an urgent meeting, an urgent debate, for this plenary to express our solidarity with the victims of Emmanuel Macron’s policies of mass brutality. As you know very well, 15 people have lost their eyes, 80 people had severe head injuries, and I suggest that the debate on Hungary should be deleted from the agenda because these human rights violations that are going on in France are far more serious than the ones that are going on in Hungary.

name: Presidente. –
text: It is the groups or a qualified number of Members who are asking for a debate or a change in the agenda. If your group or a qualified number of Members ask to put the matter on the agenda, I will put it to the vote in the House, which will decide whether or not to proceed. The same applies to Mr Sleyley's proposal. Mr Kyenge.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I thank you for organising the ceremony in which we all expressed our deep feelings about the Holocaust. I must, nevertheless, leave here my regret that an attack was made against the British Labour Party for anti-Semitism.  (Applause) I think this is outrageous. It’s not doing right to all the people in the British Labour Party, all the members who are Jewish, who fought against the Nazis, and who died against the Nazis. I am very sorry that I did not hear a word about the Roma and the LGBT people who also perished in the Holocaust. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: I would remind you that the victims of the Holocaust or the survivors are free to say what they think, but I would also remind you that in my speech I reminded you that the victims of the Holocaust were not only European citizens of the Jewish religion, but there were also Roma, Sinti and homosexuals. This was made very clear in my opening speech.

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I rise in defence of Rule 115, that Parliament shall ensure that its activities are conducted with the utmost transparency. I am very surprised to learn that Mr Weber’s EPP is taking the unprecedented step of imposing secrecy on the vote on lobby transparent tomorrow. In a democracy, politicians do not make laws in secret; citizens have a right to know how their representatives vote. Forcing the whole of Parliament to vote in secrecy on a political issue is not only ridiculous, it also undermines citizens’ confidence in the European Parliament. Why is the EPP afraid to let voters know how their politician vote? So I urge you, Mr Weber: do the right thing and prevent your group from this blatant misuse of the rules in imposing secrecy on this transparency vote. Do the right thing, if not, shame on you!

name: Presidente. –
text: An appeal. There is no reference to the agenda. I would ask you to keep to the agenda when the agenda is on the agenda. We will proceed to the political debate at the time of the political debate.

name: Presidente. –
text: We now come to the order of business. The final draft agenda as set by the Conference of Presidents pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure was distributed at its meeting on 17 January 2019. On Wednesday, I received a request from the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats to include, as a fourth point, a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Policy on the 'Situation in Venezuela'. The declaration will be followed by a round of speeches by the political groups. The debate will end with a resolution to be voted on Thursday.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to inform the House accompanying us in the rostrum Francisco Sucre, who is the chairman of the Committee on Foreign Policy, Sovereignty and Integration of the Venezuelan Assembly and, therefore, number two of the legitimate Government of that country. He is also in the guest gallery Antonio Ledezma, who is the metropolitan mayor of Caracas.  Having listened to your speech on behalf of this Parliament, I believe that this House is not left but to decide to hold a debate on the political situation in Venezuela today and to vote on a resolution.

name: Presidente. –
text: I have received a request from the S&D Group to postpone the Commission's statement on the 'state of trade negotiations between the United States and the Union' until a later day.

name: Bernd Lange
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, as Chair of the Committee on International Trade, I want to request the postponement of the debate on the state of the US-EU trade negotiations. Just a few days ago the Commissioner presented a draft mandate for negotiation and just today the implementation of the trade relations was published. So the Committee on International Trade thinks that we should have more time to have a profound and critical discussion about these documents and present a resolution to the plenary to have a position of the Parliament. The Committee on International Trade is preparing a resolution and, therefore, we would like to postpone the debate with the Commission statement and the winding-up resolution until the March I plenary.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the thing is that the Council has the Commission’s draft for the negotiation mandate with the US right now on the table, so if this Parliament wants to have any say at all about what’s being negotiated then we have to make our position clear now. We cannot wait for later. Later on we will not play any role, we will not have any say, and then we will again be totally out of the procedure.  I am very astonished because the S&D Group has so far always fought very hard for the formal involvement of the European Parliament, so I’m very astonished by this proposal and I would like to ask colleagues to reject the postponement proposal and let’s rather talk about what our position is, what our demands are for the mandate, for the negotiation, and let’s make sure that Parliament’s voice will be heard in this.

name: Presidente. –
text: We now come to Thursday. On Thursday, I received a request from the EFDD Group for the vote on Mr McDerman's report to be taken. I would like to ask the President-in-House whether he is not in a position to give an opinion on the amendments to Parliament's Rules of Procedure and to postpone it until a later part-session. I also received a request from the Group of the Greens/European Greens for this report, which was put directly to the vote, to be postponed until the February part-session with an in-depth debate. Since the plenary decides on the changes to the agenda for this part-session, I put to the vote, having, of course, listened to the speeches for and against, the request to postpone the vote on Mr De Clercq's report. Corbett. The possibility of having an in-depth debate on this report will, however, be discussed at the next meeting of the Conference of Presidents.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Rule 227 provides that amendments to the Rules of Procedure are to be examined by the committee responsible, the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. This is a rule but it is also a basic democratic principle. However, tomorrow we will vote three amendments to the Corbett report on the revision of the Rules of Procedure which, although of utmost significance, were never tabled or discussed during the many meetings of the working group and the committee.  The S&D with Jo Leinen, the PPE with György Schöpflin and ALDE with Mr Goerens require that the decision on the future existence of political groups be put into the hands of the absolute majority of Parliament through a vote on their political affinity. On the basis of which parameter? No parameter is established in this proposal. Is there – and this is a question – a political affinity between you, Mr Schöpflin, and your Group after it split up on the Sargentini report which called for the activation of Article 7 against Hungary, led by your party? Just a little more than a quarter of your PPE colleagues voted in favour of your government. Should you already go with the non-attached? This is not, I think, a rhetorical question.  And you, Mr Leinen, apparently find elements of political affinity on the interpretation of the principles of democracy with the exponents of Fidesz that you were criticising so much in this plenary on other occasions. Do not speak also about ALDE that many times showed us very different votes – Mr Goerens who until very recently was sitting beside Members of those groups which collected signatures for Finland’s exit from the euro despite the pro—federal rhetoric. Democracy means first and foremost granting the opposition’s rights. It can never turn into a tyranny of the majority. On behalf of the EFDD Group, I ask for the postponement of the vote on the Corbett report in line with Rule 149a. (Applause)

name: Richard Corbett (S&D)
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, that was all very interesting, but not entirely relevant to the procedural point that was moved, which was to shift the debate, and presumably the vote, of course, on this report to a subsequent part-session on the grounds that there hasn’t been enough time to consider this report. I would remind the House that this report was drafted by a working group of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO), a working group in which every Group was represented. It then went to the AFCO Committee as a whole. It has now come before Parliament. It is subject to amendments in the usual way, as with previous rules reports, as indeed with most of our reports, there are amendments that come up and new compromises that emerge at the plenary stage. It was already postponed from December to January I. It was postponed from January I to January II.  I wonder whether he’s taking a leaf out of the book of Mrs May about kicking the can down the road further and further and further until there is no time left to deal with it – maybe that is what is intended by the EFDD Group? In any case, I recommend that Parliament do not follow that. (Mixed reactions)

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, just to clarify, our proposal is to have a fully fledged debate on the Corbett report. For us, whether we have it now or in February is not the point; we don’t need to postpone it. What we want to do is debate it, because Parliament should have a proper debate about what rules of procedure we’re going to use for forming the Groups. That is a matter of concern for all the Groups. It is a serious matter. So we should have a proper debate about that and know what we are going to vote about rather than just doing it in a couple of minutes. The whole report has really serious implications: on the formation of a group, the question of what sort of lobbyism would be allowed and whether we have learned from the Me Too movement. This concerns really a lot of things so we should have a proper debate; that’s our point of view. We can have a proper debate now, no problem, we don’t have to do it in February. We can do it in February but now the question is simply, do we have a debate? That’s our request: to have a full debate.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, then I would like to request that we have a full debate on the Corbett report in this plenary session.

name: Presidente. –
text: So let us put the Proposal of the Group of the Greens/European Green Group to the vote. (Parliament agreed to the request for amendment) *** Following consultations with the political groups, I would like to submit to the House the following proposals for amendments to the final draft agenda: On Wednesday, a debate on the Council and Commission statements on the 'Withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union' is added as the first item on the agenda, followed by a round of speeches by the political groups; The joint debate on gender balance has moved to Thursday as the first item of the morning. On Thursday, the joint debate on gender balance will be the first item on the morning. The discussion with Finnish Prime Minister Juha Sipilä on the future of Europe will follow, from 10:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. Voting will begin at 12:00 p.m. In addition, the following points are added to the vote: Report by Mr De Clercq on beazley: Siekierski on "Rules on direct payments and support for rural development for the years 2019 and 2020";  – Objection under Article 106 on 'Genetically modified rape'; – Objection under Article 106 on 'Genetically modified maize 5307'; – Objection under Article 106 on 'GENETICALLY MODIFIED MAize MON 87403'; e – Objection under Article 106 on 'GHB614 genetically modified cotton'. ***

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to speak precisely on the amendment of the agenda, because I have been raising my hand for a long time. I have made a very specific request from my group: that of asking for a debate in this part-session on the case of Sea Watch, precisely because we must bring it back into the Parliamentary Chamber. This is a European issue, but it is also a question of the violation of fundamental rights. I have made this specific request and I would like it to be voted on.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr President, your group, as provided for in the Rules of Procedure, has not received any request to amend the agenda, which must arrive at least one hour earlier. For all the other groups, this request has arrived. Since no request had been received on behalf of your group, I did not put the report to the vote. It's not my responsibility. (The order of business was thus established)

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union (2019/2539(RSP)).

name: Melania Ciot
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, two weeks ago, I recall the steps already taken on the Council side following the European Council endorsement of the agreement on the withdrawal of the UK from the EU and Euratom and approval of the political declaration setting out the framework for the future relationship between the EU and the UK last November. This was just after having learned the outcome of the meaningful vote in Westminster, an outcome we cannot but regret. We were all hoping that at least this would have been a wake-up call, leading the UK government and the British Parliament to come out with a clear sense of direction and timing. From what I understand from yesterday’s vote, this is not the case and we face more rather than less uncertainty.  What are the alternative arrangements? Prime Minister May has now been instructed to negotiate with the EU. How can we reconcile the intention to discuss alternative arrangements with the clear EU position that the withdrawal agreement is the best possible compromise text achieved in the negotiations? I don’t want to speculate on how the various options on the table will unfold, but this is clear that this state of affairs makes a disorderly exit of the UK more likely still and its consequences more serious for all of us, but in particular for the UK. Economic operators are increasingly vocal about the impact of this uncertainty, in terms not only of direction but also of timing on their activities, investment and, therefore, jobs. It is also clear that this uncertainty and the tensions it leads to at sectoral and national level will further test our unity and resolve. It is, therefore, all the more necessary on the one hand to resist the temptation of bilateral deals and, on the other, to reflect our common purpose in the swift adoption of the necessary contingency measures. The responsibility for ensuring the UK ratification of the deal remains with the UK Government. Our determination to proceed should, however, comfort the UK Government in its effort to complete its part of the ratification process. In this respect, within the limits of our principles and positions, notably as regards citizens’ rights and the Irish backstop, one should remain open to talks and clarifications if this can help the ratification process in the UK. While we have been clear that renegotiation of the agreement is not on the cards, we should stand ready to act once the UK Government has clarified the next steps on its side.  In the meantime, we continue the ratification process in the EU, which, I understand, is also moving on in the European Parliament as well. Given the uncertainty I mentioned before, in terms of both timing and content, we have to continue our preparations for all outcomes, including a no-deal scenario. The Council and the Member States at national level are therefore intensifying their work on preparedness and contingency, building on the solid work already underway. This means, of course, new legislative activities at this late stage of the legislature, but we are confident that by working, together we can deliver. I’m encouraged in this respect by the agreement already reached on a few Brexit-related proposals. The Presidency, with your cooperation, is determined to facilitate the adoption of the necessary contingency measures in good time.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, in less than 60 days, the United Kingdom is due to leave the European Union.  I say to Mr Farage and others, this is a bad decision. Listen, listen.  Even as the Commission has defended the interests of the European Union, a spirit of respect and friendship has accompanied us at every step in these negotiations. The Withdrawal Agreement and political declaration agreed by all 27 leaders and the United Kingdom Government is the result of that. The Withdrawal Agreement remains the best and only deal possible. The European Union said so in November. We said so in December. We said so after the first meaningful vote in the Commons in January. The debate and votes in the House of Commons yesterday do not change that. The Withdrawal Agreement will not be renegotiated. Both sides have said loud and clear that there can be no return to a hard border on the island of Ireland, no slipping back into darker times past. I believe the Prime Minister’s personal commitment on this point, but I also believe that we need a safety net that secures us against this risk. We have no incentive nor desire to use the safety net, but at the same time, no safety net can ever truly be safe if it can just be removed at any time. Sometimes, from time to time, I have the impression that some hope exists that the 26 other countries will abandon the backstop and also Ireland at the last minute, but this is not a game and neither is it a simple bilateral issue. It goes to the heart of what being a member of the European Union means. Ireland’s border is Europe’s border and it is our Union’s priority. We know from yesterday’s debate that the House of Commons is against many things. It is against a no-deal Brexit, it is against the backstop, but we still do not know what exactly the House of Commons is actually for. The concept of alternative arrangements is not new. It was discussed in the negotiations. It is referred to in the political declaration and, in our letter to Prime Minister May, Donald Tusk and I committed to explore it further as a matter of priority, but a concept is not a plan. It is not an operational solution. Many in the House of Commons, both amongst those who voted for and those who voted against the amendment are aware of this.  I will continue to be in close contact with Prime Minister May, for whom I have the greatest respect, and I will listen to her ideas, but I will also be extremely clear about the position of the European Union that I have presented today.  Monsieur le Président, Mesdames et Messieurs, laissez-moi vous dire clairement que le vote d’hier a accru le risque d’un retrait désordonné du Royaume-Uni. Nous devons continuer à tout faire pour nous préparer à tous les scénarios, y compris le pire. La Commission a commencé ses travaux préparatoires en décembre 2017 et ces dernières semaines, en étroite coopération avec votre Parlement, Monsieur le Président, nous avons accéléré nos préparations. J’ai envoyé une équipe dans chaque capitale pour aider les États membres à être prêts. Le Conseil européen a apporté son appui à ce travail depuis le début. Nous avons à ce jour publié 88 notifications montrant quelles sont les conséquences du Brexit dans différents domaines, ainsi que 18 propositions ou actes législatifs. Les trois dernières propositions portant sur le programme Erasmus, la sécurité sociale et le budget de l’Union européenne ont été adoptées et présentées aujourd’hui. Je voudrais d’ores et déjà remercier tous les membres du Parlement qui sont concernés, afin de garantir que nous parvenions à des accords rapides sur ces propositions et sur tous les dossiers urgents en attente. Il est plus que jamais important que l’Union européenne reste calme, unie et déterminée, comme elle l’a été tout au long de ce processus. Dans ce travail, nous devons suivre une règle d’or: nous ne devons pas reproduire les bénéfices de l’accord de retrait ou de la déclaration politique. I am still an optimist by nature, and a believer in democratic institutions by conviction. This leads me to believe that there can and will be agreement with the United Kingdom, so that we can move on and move forward together with our new partnership. We will work day and night to make it happen and to ensure that we are ready in case it does not. Whichever way, I will always ensure that this House is the first to know, and the last to decide. (Applause)

name: Le Président. –
text: Before I give the floor to our negotiator, Mr Michel Barnier, I want to point out, both to the President of the European Commission and to our negotiator, that, for the European Parliament, whatever the solution to the Brexit problem, the defence of the rights of the 3.5 million European citizens living in the United Kingdom is a priority. We also defend the rights of British citizens who live here in the European Union. In other words, first of all the rights of citizens: Europeans , today - British, and who come from other countries.

name: Michel Barnier
text: European Union's chief Brexit negotiator. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam Secretary of State, first of all, thank you, Mr President, for allowing me once again to speak here in front of you, in plenary, and thus, day after day, to consolidate with President Juncker the climate of trust, transparency and dialogue that we have built together with you, ladies and gentlemen, , and in particular with the Brexit steering group, Guy Verhofstadt and all the members of this group for the past year and a half, at the rate of one meeting almost every week. Ladies and gentlemen, yesterday, for the first time, British Prime Minister Theresa May openly pleaded to reopen the withdrawal agreement. Even before the late-night vote, it distanced itself from the agreement that it had negotiated and which we had agreed to. The British Government subsequently gave explicit support to the amendment tabled by Sir Graham Brady, which calls for the replacement of the backstop that we have provided for in the Irish protocol with alternative devices, which have at no time been defined. At the same time, the House of Commons rejected the scenario of a no deal, without specifying how to avoid such a scenario. That is the situation we are in this afternoon. In the course of this very long and extraordinary negotiation, we are at a time, Mr President, whom I want to describe - as I was at the very first line alongside and under the authority of President Juncker, President Tusk and yourself - as serious and very serious. President Tusk last night, President Juncker at the moment reiterated that we share this desire of the British Parliament to avoid a no deal, and I agree with Theresa May: voting against a no deal as was the case last night does not eliminate the risk of no deal. For us, ladies and gentlemen, the withdrawal agreement is and remains the best and only way to ensure an orderly withdrawal from the United Kingdom and to implement in an orderly manner the sovereign decision taken by a majority of British citizens, which we respect, to leave the European Union. And I believe, despite today's difficulties, that we can achieve this goal, provided we are both realistic and lucid, respectful and responsible. Each other, with each other. Ladies and gentlemen, the backstop, which President Juncker has spoken of, is part of the withdrawal agreement and this agreement will not be renegotiated. The conclusions of the December European Council, which are in full line with the european Parliament's declarations and resolutions, leave no room for doubt on this point. I would like to say a word about the backstop, so that everyone can see what it is. This backstop is not dogmatism, it is a realistic solution. Throughout this negotiation, under your control, we have sought solutions to the problems created, in particular but not only in Ireland, by Brexit itself. The backstop as it appears in the withdrawal agreement is the result of the extremely intense negotiations we have been conducting over the last two years with the United Kingdom, never against the United Kingdom. The backstop is a pragmatic response to the unique situation on the island of Ireland after the United Kingdom decided sovereignly not only to leave the European Union, but also to leave the single market and finally leave the customs union. It took two years to find this solution, which reconciles several requirements. The first requirement for all of us is to avoid at all costs the return of a hard border in Ireland, that is to say to preserve the conditions that have been there for 20 years of peace, stability and dialogue on the island of Ireland, especially since the signing of the Good Friday Agreement. I would remind you that the United Kingdom itself, through the voice of its Prime Minister, has repeatedly confirmed its commitment as co-guarantor of the terms of this Good Friday agreement. And we ourselves have supported for 20 years, through the Peace programme, by European law, by European policies, by the European budget, by the good success of this cooperation between the different communities. The second requirement is the willingness and demand of the British Government to keep Northern Ireland and Great Britain in a single customs territory. The third requirement, of course ours, the one for which we are collectively responsible, is the preservation of the integrity of the internal market. Ladies and gentlemen, this last point is fundamental to us. The Irish border will become, by the British will, the European Union and the internal market. This will be our new external border. What is at stake, of course, is the protection of all consumers and businesses in the Union. I will say this more concretely: the British decision to leave the Eu,100 the Single Market and the Internal Market has a practical consequence, which is that every commodity, every living animal, every animal or plant product that enters Northern Ireland from Great Britain enters not only Northern Ireland and Ireland, but also the single market of your countries. The nature, the quality, the safety, the regularity of this product, the safety linked to animal protection - I say as a former Minister of Agriculture of my country - require checks, which we do at every external border, everywhere in the European Union: tax controls, health checks, veterinary checks, regulatory ones. We owe this protection to all consumers, 500 million today with the UK, and 22 million businesses. We owe this protection to all those who make the internal market work and live. Among those who today are calling for the removal of this backstop, there are British parliamentarians - I was listening to one more this morning - who have negotiated with us and who know perfectly well that this backstop is the solution we have found for what is - as Jean-Claude Juncker said - the heart, for us Europeans, of our obligations and our principles. , that is, the protection of the internal market in all its dimensions and the rights attached to it: social rights, economic rights, consumer rights, environmental rights and the protection of businesses and consumers. Ladies and gentlemen, when I listen to some of the people who participated in the negotiation, express themselves as they do, I find it difficult to accept frankly the game of reproaches to which they would like to play against us. (Applause) I would like to say, after President Juncker, that we will not do anything - it is as simple as that and I say it calmly - that would weaken the internal market. We will not do anything that will jeopardize the future of the European Union for the present of this negotiation. And as President Juncker has said, however, we are obviously open to the alternative arrangements that were mentioned yesterday by the House of Commons. The Irish protocol and the political declaration mention them, the letter from Presidents Tusk and Juncker has even made it a priority in future negotiations. We are ready to work on it immediately after the signing of this withdrawal agreement. But today, frankly, no one, on one side or the other, is able to say precisely, in a clear way, what the nature of these alternative devices would be so that they would be operational and that they actually fulfil the objectives of the backstop. That is why, I say it again calmly and clearly, at the moment, and with regard to this withdrawal agreement as proposed to you to be ratified, we need this backstop as it is. Ladies and gentlemen, rejecting this backstop as it is today is a sort of rejection of the solution that was found with the British, but the problem remains, as I have described it. On this point, and beyond the question of the alternative devices I have referred to, the European Council, like the European Parliament, have already repeatedly and clearly rejected the idea of a time limit or a unilateral exit from the backstop since such ideas would immediately distort the very idea of backstop, which is an assurance that we do not want to use - like you, your own insurance in your apartment or your house - but which is there if we ever in need. Finally, I would like to point out that the withdrawal agreement that we are talking about and which you know goes far beyond the question of Ireland. This agreement secures the rights of more than 4.5 million citizens. Mr Tajani, you have mentioned Parliament's priority, we have made it ours and, whatever happens, the security of citizens' rights, our 3.5 million compatriots, nationals of our various countries, who live in the United Kingdom and of course, reciprocally, the security of the rights of 1.5 million British citizens who reside in one of our countries, will remain our priority. This agreement protects all beneficiaries of the EU budget in the 28 countries. Commitments made at 28 will be met at 28. The agreement establishes a 21-month transition period during which businesses and governments on both sides can prepare for this future relationship and during which we will have time, a very short, demanding time, to negotiate this future relationship in a new stage of negotiation. This agreement is the prerequisite for building the trust we need between the United Kingdom, which will remain a friendly, allied, partner, and European Union country. A true partnership, solid and ambitious. I would just like to add that with regard to this future relationship, the Europeans are ready and will remain ready in the coming days to be more ambitious and to rework the nature and intensity of our future relationship, economic in particular. You know, ladies and gentlemen, that there are several models of economic cooperation with third countries. Each of these models obviously has its own balance of rights and obligations, but there are many models. I am simply saying that if the British demand were to evolve beyond a simple free trade agreement, on which we agreed in the political declaration, with a view to achieving any of these models, we are and will be immediately ready to discuss it and respond to a new British ambition with our own ambition. This has already been said both by yourself in your resolutions and by the European Council. Ladies and gentlemen, I was talking earlier about realism and lucidity, as you did, Madam Secretary of State, less than 60 days before the date of the UK's exit. In the absence of a positive majority in the House of Commons today for a solution identified and acceptable by the European Union, it is, as President Juncker has said, urgent and necessary to prepare ourselves for all scenarios and to put in place all the necessary emergency measures than ever before. This is the work that President Juncker has entrusted to the Secretary-General and all the teams that work with you, with your committees and with all the Member States. Thank you for your attention and for your trust. (Applause)

name: Elmar Brok
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, Mr Barnier, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work he has First of all, I would like to thank Jean-Claude Juncker and Michel Barnier for the good cooperation, the real transparency, the information we receive and also the listening in this process. A good example of cooperation! And this also leads to our great awareness that we continue to support this negotiating strategy.  Yesterday we saw votes in the House of Commons in which all constructive proposals such as a new referendum, a customs union, were rejected. It has only been agreed that Mrs May will now come for the third or fourth time to talk to Brussels about the backstop again – nothing new.  I think it is important now, before Mrs May comes here, that you finally talk to each other. It is a scandal that the leader of the opposition and the head of the government have not been talking to each other for three years. When you leave, you should know what you want before harassing others. Please come with your own position! Talk to each other! Please talk to each other. Come to a constructive idea and come back to Brussels. That might be an important question. Talk to each other. We are united. You are not united within the government, within the Tory Party, within the Labour Party. That's the main problem. We see here that we have a negative majority, which is made up of different groups, ranging from the hard Brexiteers to the Remainers. And here we can negotiate and propose what we want: those who want a hard Brexit will not agree, and those who still hope – with which is my heart, but no longer the mind – we will have to see that they will reject anything that is not a referendum. And as long as that is the situation, nothing will happen. Negotiations can be held with Mrs May on a new type of backstop, which will also be rejected for these reasons. And you have to see one thing: Ireland is a member of the European Union. It is largely thanks to the European Union that the Good Friday Agreement has been concluded. I remember our old friend and colleague John Hume, who did this out of this House with many others.  (Interruption: Rubbish! Rubbish!) We will defend this. We will defend the peace programme. We don't want a hard border. And the British government has also said it does not want a hard border, having repeatedly signed that it wants a backstop – the first time in December 2017. That has to be clear.  We will defend Ireland and try to get a soft border. But you have to have the willingness of the other side. And the backstop we have today with this customs union is a British invention, that was the British proposal. The European Union has made other proposals on this. In other words, you now want to negotiate something that you yourself have proposed. I think that's a great number that's gone. And that's why: talk to each other! They need to talk to each other in London and make this clear among themselves.  With the Withdrawal Agreement, we are getting a transitional arrangement in which we can regulate the many things, such as a free trade area or further ones – Norway, Switzerland, we are all open to it. But we don't need the backstop. It is clear to everyone that 99% of the time when we reach the transitional period, the backstop will not be applied at all. So it is not a question of regulating the matter, but of not wanting an agreement, for the various reasons I have presented. And I would ask you to put that right, to make that clear.  That is why it is certain that we are now implementing preparedness legislation. It is important that, when a proposal comes along, we are prepared to talk openly and to reach a solution. I welcome the fact that the House of Commons has said we don't want hard Brexit - we don't want that either. I don't even want Brexit at all to make that clear...  (Applause) But that is the British decision to do this, we have to accept that, and we must minimise the damage to both sides.  There is only one thing that is clear to me, and the British people must know this: the damage to Britain is always the greater. The European market is fourteen times the size of the UK. Companies will deduct. All those who produce for the European market will leave the UK. It will be a bitter hour for Britain. It will be a damaging hour for us, but a bitter hour for Britain. Let us come together and talk sensibly, and that means: that the British side must first have its own constructive position. (Interruption: Goodbye!)

name: President. –
text: Excellent German from the British bench there. Thank you.

name: Roberto Gualtieri
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, it is difficult to deny that we are facing a difficult and grave situation and that the risk of no deal has increased. The House of Commons has voted, it rejects a no-deal Brexit, which is good, but at the same time it has asked to replace the Northern Ireland backstop with alternative arrangements, which is clearly not a workable option. We have seen with surprise the same Prime Minister who just a few days ago said that the best backstop was an essential part of the best deal possible, now calling for its replacement. This might have temporarily united a political party but it has not provided any positive solution to the Brexit deadlock. We have therefore to explain again why this Parliament and the European Council in their mandate to the EU negotiator have made clear that an operational and legally binding backstop is an essential pillar of a withdrawal agreement, and that we will not give consent to any deal without it. Preventing a hard border in Ireland and protecting the peace process is not a partisan position, and the single market integrity is a non-negotiable free principle for the European Union. The backstop is a guarantee, an option of last resort. It is necessary to ensure that if an agreement on the future EU-UK relationship is not concluded by the end of the transition period, the minimum essential safeguards will be in place to keep the border open while safeguarding the integrity of a single market. It is worth recalling that the backstop was modified at the request of the UK Government and it was not an easy concession from the EU’s side. We did it to allow Northern Ireland to remain part of the same customs territory as the rest of the UK, avoiding tariffs, quotas or checks on rules of origin within it, and we did this notwithstanding the fact that our original proposal of backstop was simple, fair and did not impose any material border in the Irish Sea. The only positive message from yesterday’s vote is that the UK parliament rejects a no-deal Brexit. This is welcome: a no-deal would be bad for everybody but a disaster for the UK. It is right that MPs made clear that this is not acceptable. So what’s next? We have always said, and we repeat today, that we want to see as close a relationship as possible between the United Kingdom and the European Union. It is the UK’s red lines that have made this impossible so far. This means that for us the only alternative to the backstop is a closer EU-UK relationship. If you want to ensure that the backstop is never used, build a positive majority for a more ambitious relationship: a customs union and at least a closer alignment with the single market. We are now less than two months away from the UK leaving the EU. We urgently need to see a positive proposal from the UK on how to break this deadlock. If their parliament is unable to do this, then it should be put back to the British people. If the UK needs more time, we are open to it, but we need a clear plan or proposal on how it will help resolve the issue. We cannot allow more time for bluster or false promises. We are united – strongly united – calm and firm behind our negotiator who will continue to follow the clear mandate given both by the European Council and the European Parliament. So it is right that on the basis that is unity, we have to be worried but we can also be optimistic. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: Please show respect to the speakers. Mr Coburn, that was directed towards you.

name: Ashley Fox
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I’ve heard five speeches this afternoon describe the efforts made to negotiate the Withdrawal Agreement and how good it is. But I’m sure you will all have noticed that this very Withdrawal Agreement was rejected two weeks ago in the House of Commons by an overwhelming majority, so now is not a moment for rhetoric but for reflection. It was never going to be easy to disentangle the United Kingdom from the European Union but there is now a clearer road ahead, if we choose to take it. I know there are some here – Elmar Brok – still hoping that the UK will stay in the Union and are taking positions based on that hope. But this is not going to happen. It would be wrong in principle to ignore the referendum result and, in practice, it is clear there is no majority in the House of Commons in favour of such a course. The amendment designed to secure a second referendum was withdrawn as it had so little support. The British Government and the House of Commons wants to leave the EU in an orderly manner and with a deal, and to achieve that we need to change how the protocol on Northern Ireland operates. We must do all we can to support the Good Friday Agreement, but it is a paradox that the backstop, whose purpose is to avoid a hard border, may in just 58 days’ time be the cause of creating such a hard border in the island of Ireland. Let me repeat, the backstop in its current form will not prevent a hard border, it will create it. Let us all pause to consider this: it may be very easy to sit down to great applause today for a rigid defence of an existing position. History may not be so kind. Because as things stand, we don’t have a deal. There is no deal until both sides have approved it according to their law. And it is simply not good enough to repeat ad nauseam that the deal cannot be amended. That leads to no deal, and that leads, as the Commission confirmed last week, to a hard border between the United Kingdom and Ireland. So it is my hope that even at this late hour changes or additions can be made to bring a deal safely home. As Mr Barnier said: ‘in the event of a no deal the EU would find an alternative operational way to carry out checks and controls without putting back in place a border’. That’s a quote. Let us look at that now. Let us consider whether time limits and exit mechanisms offer a solution. Let us proceed with good will, remembering that flexibility and generosity are not signs of weakness but of strength. For what is at stake is not just the draft agreement. At stake is the future partnership between the European Union and the United Kingdom. Let us ensure that we can construct a long—term relationship to promote our common values and our shared interests in an uncertain world. Let us find a way to move forward together.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, after the vote yesterday, Ms May announced that she will come to Brussels and for my part, I have to tell you very honestly that she’s always welcome – certainly here in this European Parliament. It would be good if she were to come once to the European Parliament as we requested already more than a year ago.  But the question today is naturally, for what? For what? To do what? Is it to change the red lines that the British Government has used from day one? That could be a breakthrough, I think. That could change effectively the outcome of this whole process.  Or my second point: what will her mandate be? Because, for the moment, as I must say to Mr Fox, I have not seen, and this includes yesterday, a parliament that gives a clear mandate to Theresa May. We have seen a vote against a number of things: against the deal; against no deal; against the backstop. But until today, for more than two years the House of Commons has not voted one proposal in favour of something, in favour of a relationship between the EU and UK – never!  The last two months, I have to tell you, have been very exhausting, and not only on the other side of the Channel but also here. Endless debates, long lists of amendments, amendments going in all directions, selected by the Speaker, and then won and lost with a teeny-tiny majority.  I give here the list: the Grieve amendment, that was on 4 December. That was a Remain amendment – won by 22 votes. The Cooper amendment, also a Remain amendment. That was on 8 January – won by 7 votes. Then another Cooper amendment, that was yesterday – lost by 23 votes. Then the Brady amendment, which was more a Leave amendment – won by 16 votes yesterday. And then again a Remain amendment, the Spellman amendment to take the no deal from the table – won by 8 votes! Is that the way to solve a problem of this magnitude? Is that the way to do that? Is that the way you do that? That is, every day changing your opinion? And in any way creating uncertainty, instability, instead of concluding a real, new relationship between the EU and the UK. I have to tell you that I look at that and I cannot understand how what started as a catfight inside the Conservative Party is today an existential problem for the whole of Britain. Take yesterday’s voting for example: the Spellman amendment with a majority of eight votes saying the no deal is off the table and then the Prime Minister comes back five minutes later saying ‘No, no, we just did that as a joke, a no deal is still possible’. I have to tell you that we cannot go any further like that. There is a lack of clarity and a lack of stability and I hope one thing, that at this moment, as we speak, a meeting is happening between the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Corbyn, and the Prime Minister, Ms May. I hope that they will decide or that they will discuss content, and that it is not just eating biscuits and drinking tea this afternoon, because it could be the solution to this problem if they start working together on a cross-party approach so that we know what the position of the UK is in the future.  (Applause) Because we don’t know it. Putting in fact, country before party. Telling us how they see that future relationship between the EU and the UK and not using or abusing Brexit, as happens now, to get rid of each other. Because that is what’s happening today.  If that is the spirit that emerges in Downing Street this afternoon, then Prime Minister May can come – has to come – to Brussels to tell us what this broad, stable majority cross-party wants as a future relationship and I think there too is the solution for the backstop. Because if there is a close relationship – deeper, as Michel Barnier has indicated – then the backstop will still exist but it will not be necessary to use it. It will be a theoretical insurance that it is, in fact, not necessary to apply.  Again, we are ready to go in that direction. Michel Barnier has indicated this. Jean-Claude Juncker has indicated this. It is time the political class in Britain is also ready to go in this direction, as fast as possible, because you will be the first to pay the price for this lack of clarity.

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Westminster is in meltdown. The internal contradictions of Brexit were laid bare last night. Brexit was never anything more than a bunch of slogans. It could never be turned into a coherent negotiating position. As we play out the end-game and the Brexit fraud is revealed, its supporters dream up fantasy deals so that failure can be blamed on Brussels. But we must hold our nerve through this Westminster chaos. A majority of UK citizens know that the best future for our country is inside the European Union. Here we can continue to be part of the world’s most successful peace project, and together we can tackle the huge cross—border issues we face, most notably climate change. We are now the majority and, as young people reaching voting age want to join us in improving our continent in mutual friendship, so our numbers grow. Now that MPs have rejected no-deal, the clear choice is still between the deal negotiated between the UK and the EU, and remaining in the EU. This choice must be given back to the people. The hostility of the supporters of Brexit – as we see here – to such a democratic check proves that they are running scared because they know, as I do, that the will of the British people has changed and has turned against them and their Brexit chaos. (“Rubbish” from the right of the Chamber)

name: President. –
text: Colleagues, if it were in my power – but it’s not – the word ‘rubbish’ would be banned from this Chamber. I wouldn’t share it with you, sir.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We have, of course, also discussed today in our group how we intend to deal with the current situation in the light of yesterday's vote. It is quite clear to us as a group that we stand by the negotiated withdrawal agreement as the achievable solution. It is not the best one could wish for future relations – as a basis for developing future relations between the EU and the UK – but it is obviously what has been worked out with a great deal of effort, with a lot of resources and with a lot of loss of nerve over the last two years, a year and a half. At some point, you have to decide whether you can achieve what you can achieve together, then stand by, or whether everyone from your side tries again – I want to pick that out, I want to do something again – and then ultimately massively endanger the common foundations. I would like to take this opportunity to remind you – and I would also like to say this with regard to my colleagues in the House of Commons – what we have achieved as the European Parliament, Less than two years ago, when we formulated the mandate for the negotiations, it is that we were able to influence Mr Barnier's mandate and that, in this discussion, we were also able to make clear, among other things, how important it is to regard the rights of EU citizens in the United Kingdom, but also of British citizens in the European Union, and, on the other hand, the whole issue of stabilising the peace process in Northern Ireland as red lines in these negotiations. It was not about our own interests, it was about the issues of peace and stability throughout the Union. I took a very close look at the debate in the House of Commons at the beginning of January and also yesterday, and I had the impression, in part, that our British colleagues are not taking us seriously. They also do not understand certain processes, and they debate as if they could vote on the changes on their own. No, ladies and gentlemen in London, you must also talk to us about this, you must also take note of our position, you cannot pretend that the British Empire also applies in the European Union. We have our own democracy here. You have been part of this democracy so far. I have always respected and appreciated what I knew about British diplomacy and democracy. I am horrified by the spectacle shown to us. I think it is important to go back to the basics of what we actually want to achieve in the end, and not just wall ingenuate. Let me be quite clear: the only hope I still have is that in the conversation between Corbyn and Theresa May there will actually be a bit of movement in the negotiations with the EU, and then there can be a lot of talk about it. We are open to developing more relationships, for developing clear relationships. But what we are not going to do – at least not from my group, and I am very glad that the other groups, most of them at least, see it in a similar way: we will not allow anything to be reversed in terms of employment rights, environmental standards and consumer protection standards. We will not allow the Good Friday Agreement to not be respected in all its parts. We will not allow a hard border to be crossed. We will not allow EU citizens to ultimately be considered third-country nationals in the UK on 30 March and will ultimately have to face a process that is discriminatory to them, that takes away all their rights. I would like to say this to my fellow Members in the House of Commons in particular: I was pleased when the British Members won the right to have a voice in this process. But then they should also use this voice and sometimes express out loud what they really want.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, public opinion and, indeed, public anger had a big impact on those votes in the House of Commons yesterday and with it, we’ve seen a diminution of the risk of a second referendum for now, the prospect of Article 50 being extended taken off the table and when I hear speakers – despite the Spelman amendment – saying today they’re worried that the risk of a no deal has increased, you’re right, it has, but not because of what happened last night in Westminster, but because of the response, gentlemen, we got from you this afternoon. Even when the Prime Minister actually gets a majority behind her and, alright, I accept she made a dreadful mistake by signing up to the backstop. You summoned her. At 4.15 in the morning, she left Downing Street, she went to meet the ultimatum that you’ve set her, she signed up to something that has proved to be a disaster. She signed up to something that no country – unless it had been defeated in war – would have signed up to. We now realise that mistake and actually, the House of Commons, the country, is overall looking for a deal, but do you know something? Before the referendum, no one knew who the European Commission were. That Maoist Barroso was a complete unknown. You guys are now household names and what we’ve seen is an appreciation in Britain that unelected bureaucrats in Brussels have been talking down to and humiliating the Prime Minister of our nation, and we don’t like it and even when she comes back, trying to be reasonable, saying let’s renegotiate, you’re not prepared to give an inch. The reason that a no-deal Brexit has got a little bit closer is because of the sheer language and attitude, not just from the Commission, but from many in Parliament towards the United Kingdom. I think public opinion will be very, very angry that there is no give today from anybody in Brussels whatsoever. I think many will say, ‘we’re simply dealing with fanatics who are not prepared to be reasonable or make any sense of compromise’. Of course, Theresa May has made compromise after compromise, way too many compromises in my view, so I think we are beginning to think that the public will come to a view that no deal is better than the backstop, and that’s a big problem. It’s a big problem for all of you, who want to get re-elected in a few weeks’ time, because no deal means no GBP 39 billion and your voters will be coughing up the money. No deal means the hundred million bottles of Prosecco we buy every year from Italy will become more expensive, as will three quarters of a million German cars.  So why don’t we all prepare sensibly for a no-deal scenario? Why don’t we prepare to go to the World Trade Organisation, use Article 24 so that we can, after we leave on March 29, have a two-year period of no tariffs, no quotas, no restrictions of any kind, no problems or difficulties with Ireland whatsoever? Brexit will have been delivered, you will have protected for at least two years your voters. That, ladies and gentlemen, right now, is the only possible constructive way forward. (Applause)

name: Gerard Batten
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Madam President, the last two-and-a-half years have been a long and tedious series of spurious impediments put up in order to prevent us leaving the European Union, as exemplified by the classic backstop bull. The House of Commons rejected the so—called deal and sent Mrs May back to renegotiate with a Commission that has already told us that it won’t renegotiate. The Commons may have rejected the amendment to extend Article 50 but it knows very well that the Withdrawal Act itself allows that date to be put back, and the Council of the European Union can extend Article 50 if it so agrees. Will we actually leave on 29 March? Or will the British political establishment manage to overthrow the result of the referendum altogether? The best thing that can now happen is if we have no-deal on 29 March and that we leave under the Withdrawal Act and on WTO terms. Article 50 will have expired and the treaties will cease to apply. If the British Parliament prevents this happening, then they will have put themselves in open rebellion against the British people and that will have profound consequences for any belief in democracy that is left in the United Kingdom.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Madam President, today is a good day for Brexit. Today is a good day for British democracy because over the past two years our government has lost its way. Instead of negotiating effectively, it compromised weakly. The EU wanted to trap Britain in a backstop deal that makes us pay money, yet stops us competing against them on the world stage. The EU worked and encouraged Remain collaborators in this House and Westminster. It invited devotees from Blair to ‘Chuckling’ Umunna, flowing like champagne at an Islington Remainer’s wake. The constant negativity stalked us, weakness cowed us, division delayed us, but weakness no more. Despite this, the British people were not for turning. They value their vote over Project Fear. They do not fear a WTO deal but relish an independent future. And the British Government has finally caught the mood and got on the freedom train. They finally understand our desire for independence, our fight for self-determination, our belief in our nation state. By uniting last night, the Conservatives are succeeding in releasing our spirit of belief once more. We will leave the European Union. We will have Brexit. And we will be an independent nation once more.

name: Melania Ciot
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, should the parliamentary process in the UK lead to a ratification of the Withdrawal Agreement, hopefully along the foreseen timeline, we will have to move to the next steps, starting with the implementation. This implementation will have to be kept under close watch so that it delivers in the interest of citizens and businesses, and contributes to the trust needed for the negotiations of the future relationship, which are unlikely to be easy. We will therefore count on your cooperation at all stages of these processes in the years to come.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. – The agreement to leave the United Kingdom from the European Union has been negotiated for more than a year and a half.
