The British Government and the European Union have agreed on a balanced, reasonable and fair text. The red lines were respected from party to party and the Union secured the approval of 27 different Member States, establishing the text as a final and non-negotiable result. The british parliament's clear rejection of the agreement has called into question an orderly Brexit. However, the lead of almost all the proposed amendments shows that Parliament does not want this agreement, but does not present an alternative. Less than two months ago, this position is irresponsible, unreasonable and unjustified.  The safeguard clause for the border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland must be a red line to protect peace between Ireland, preserve good friday agreements and ensure the integrity of the internal market. I call on the European institutions and the Member States to remain steadfast in defending this exit agreement and to respect the European Parliament, which has the right and duty to assess, debate and vote on the outcome of these negotiations on behalf of the European citizens it represents.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. The British must decide what Brexit they want. There is still disagreement in the House of Commons on how brexit should be shaped. The symptomatic of this is that Theresa May is coming to Brussels for the third or fourth time to renegotiate the backstop. I can only underline once again what my group colleague Elmar Brok said: when you leave, you should know what you want before harassing others! We know what we want: do not curtail the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union and do not jeopardise peace between Ireland and Northern Ireland.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. – I would describe all what has happened in the UK in the last week as follows. Another spin on the wheel of British politics, with no movement ahead. In practice, Theresa May has been given the right by the British Parliament to negotiate in Brussels to abolish the mechanism relating to the Irish border.  Today I can say, especially after listening to Juncker, Barnier and the leaders of the main political groups, that no one intends to open the agreement and renegotiate it. What we are all currently seeing as the only possible outcome is a request by the British government to postpone the 29 March 2019 deadline.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement on combating the atmosphere of hatred and violence against democratically elected authorised persons (2019/2534(RSP)).

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this is obviously a very important debate that we’re about to have. In our democracies political debate can sometimes be fierce – even very fierce – but resorting to violence or inciting hatred is never acceptable. Politically motivated murders, physical or other acts of hatred are shocking and directly contrary to our very core European values. Earlier on today, this House already paid tribute – and let me join that tribute – to a fighter for freedom and democracy, the mayor of Gdańsk, Mr Paweł Adamowicz. For 20 years, he stood for those values. He dedicated his life to the service of his city and wider society. While I’m speaking about this subject, I cannot but also recall the death of a Member of the UK Parliament, Jo Cox, who was a passionate defender of the rights of everyone in society, including new arrivals from abroad, and indeed of the European Union. We need to recognise that that sometimes individuals can be drawn to acts of violence – radicalised, if you like – by conspiracy theories, polarised debates and more radical ideology. There can be no free and fair elections across Europe if there is a climate of hatred and threats of violence against candidates and those holding democratically elected mandates. Unfortunately, we’ve seen that even Members of this Parliament are not immune from violence and abuse because of the views that they express, and we must deplore that. Earlier this year, Commissioner Jourová spoke at the inaugural meeting of the European cooperation network on elections. This network is a concrete step forward in implementing the Commission’s election package from last autumn. The package recommended deeper cooperation within and between Member States to jointly identify and counter threats to our democratic processes and protect the integrity of our elections. We’ve had several exchanges over the last year on threats to electoral processes, including at an event in April, ‘Democratic Participation on Electoral Matters’, a Conference in October on ‘Election Interference in the Digital Age’ and in November, the Colloquium on Fundamental Rights. At all of these exchanges one message comes through: one way a climate of hatred and threats of violence can be created is through disinformation and smear campaigns, often spread through the social media or accelerated through the social media. There have been coordinated disinformation campaigns which aimed to discredit and delegitimise elections around Europe, sometimes conducted by third countries and sometimes by private interests from within our countries that do not have citizens and our democratic processes at heart. Responding to this effectively is a challenge. These threats don’t respect borders or jurisdictions. They do not fit neatly into how we’ve dealt with regulating elections and political speech in the past. A group can misuse personal data to target online disinformation or to attempt to intimidate voters through threats. Other aspects, such as the often widely diverging rules on donations and contributions, and the opportunity that the online environment creates to get round existing electoral rules make it even more of a challenge to deal with this. That’s why we need to collaborate together to ensure that we can bring together the resources and expertise needed to strengthen our readiness to respond to and to resist and mitigate this kind of challenge. Within the framework of the European election cooperation network, we are discussing what works, such as good ways to reach out to citizens to build their awareness and to retain their trust. And media literacy, an effort that has been pursued in Sweden, before their last election was a good example. We consider new ways to involve citizens in securing the democratic process itself, as Latvia recently demonstrated, by inviting citizens to give examples of political ads which were thought to break national rules directly to the regulators. And we discuss how best to make use of existing tools, from data protection to financial supervision, and how best to close gaps which may have opened up as new technologies and their use and abuse have come into this electoral space. We will look to see where we can deploy European institutions’ – our institutions – influence and competences to support and help the Member States’ efforts. In particular, this means working to ensure that the internet platforms, the big social media platforms, live up to the commitments that they have signed up to as part of our various codes of conduct and good practice, the Code of Conduct on Hate Speech and the Code of Practice against Disinformation. As you may have seen, we presented the first of what will be a series of monthly reports on the progress the social media platforms are making in tackling disinformation yesterday. On the subject of hate speech, we need to keep in mind that hate speech is not free speech. It should be an unwritten duty of all democratically elected representatives to condemn hatred and to refrain from incitement to it. In accordance with the jurisprudence of the European Court of Human Rights, states may sanction, or even prevent, all forms of expression which spread, incite, promote or justify hatred based on intolerance. In today’s society, online hate speech poses a societal threat, which not only affects the safety of immediate victims, but has a more general chilling effect on the freedom of expression and debate, not just online but in our societies. Our core objective should be to ensure that authors of illegal hate speech are effectively prosecuted. We must ensure that all Member States implement the Framework Decision on Racism and Xenophobia. The challenges that European electoral processes face are too complex to be solved by any one authority, Member State or even private-sector service provider acting alone. Indeed, no one should be left to act alone in this space or indeed to hold all the cards and make all the judgments. Rather, a comprehensive approach is essential to ensure electoral security and legitimacy, while preserving an open democratic debate, a level playing field and the security of all those involved in our democratic processes. We must never lose sight that all our efforts need to be fully rooted in protecting and promoting the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights, in particular the freedoms of expression and association, which after all is what we are fighting to defend in our democratic processes and elections. Thank you for putting this on the agenda. We look forward very much to hearing today’s debate and following up with you subsequently between now and the European parliamentary and other forthcoming elections.

name: Janusz Lewandowski
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today, at the heart of European democracy, we are talking about how to protect our democracy from hate speech that is ruining the community, giving rise to violence and, finally, criminal regimes. We have just honoured the memory of the victims of the Holocaust. This debate is, above all, not only, but above all, a reaction to the assassination of The President of Gdańsk Pawel Adamowicz, my friend. The knife was inserted into a person who can not feed feelings of hatred even towards his enemies, in Gdansk – a city marked by multiculturalism, bad and good history, in the finale of a great charity event, so unique that it mobilizes the good energy of millions of people.  But it is not about diuding what it was today, but, according to the will of the family in Parliament today, it is about drawing conclusions for the future, because the problem is European, not just Polish. Before Adamowicz was mentioned Jo Cox – England, 2016, Theo van Gogh – Netherlands, 2004, Anna Lindh – Sweden, 2003 Previously Olof Palme, but also Daphne Caruana Galizia in Malta and Jan Kuciak in Slovakia. Too much of this politically motivated death in the 21st century, in which we should know everything about how to protect ourselves from the misfortunes of the 20th century, namely the misfortune of wars and totalitarianism, because they fed on hate speech. They fed on this language, which was the language of Nazism, Bolshevism, all totalitarianism. It is a language of contempt, which insiling people with human dignity, excluding them from the community either as enemies of the people or as enemies of the homeland.  Unfortunately, this comes back in alliance with the anonymity of the internet. Old demons wake up. In a particular case Polish hejt was nationalized, inflicted on the public media, which once a century lynched President Adamowicz. It was tolerated when the perpetrators of the "hanging" of MEPs on the market in Katowice were tolerated, since the proceedings against the perpetrators of symbolic death certificates issued to the mayors of those cities who agreed to accept refugees were discontinued. These are the hallmarks of the disease of our democracy.  But hate speech knows no bounds, it washes the European Union from different sides, because the European Union supports itself on the basis of completely different values: respect for the human person, diversity, openness and dialogue. May the death of Pawel Adamowicz be a wake-up call and a sobering one. If we doubt the self-limitation of the political class, in the various codes of good practice, voluntary and permanent, it means that we need to improve the rules, also enforce these laws, consistently prosecute hate speech, especially in the abyss of the internet, because it is the most dangerous there, it is anonymous.  The law proposed by german minister Heiko Maas may be a model. We have recommendations from the Polish Ombudsman, twenty recommendations on how to combat hate speech, also on the internet. Then and only then can the evil that has happened be turned into good. Then and only then – according to the wishes of Pawel Adamowicz's family – his death will not be in vain. (Applause)

name: Tanja Fajon
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. They compare her to a slave, they want her raped, and they send her to her country.  In Hungary, public television security guards physically tackled opposition MPs, and Laszlo Varju ended up in hospital for his injuries. The Fidesz party is behind the attack. Nova 24tv and Democracy, a Slovenian media funded by the SDS party with money from Hungary, regularly refer to me as a notoriously far-left, fascist, Sorose's mercenary, a blood-his-head killer, a traitor to the homeland and the like. When I alerted them to the untruth of statements and criminal liability, they said I was offended. Dear colleagues, I'm not offended, but we have a serious problem. Such statements and actions in a democratic Europe should not be without consequence. Coming out of your mouth, under the feathers and hands of politicians and the media. And not ordinary citizens.  Three months ago, I organised a conference on hate speech in Ljubljana. It drew attention to a few phenomena that we should be discussing very seriously if we want to address and cover this problem: What is the role of the media, which is facing human rights defenders and racists in ensuring objectivity? Is it or is it not the media's job not to let the voices of hatred and intolerance into public debate? On the left pole, in the spirit of advocating values, we were just tolerant of the impatient in the sense that we were trying to explain to them, through rational arguments, why homophobic outbursts were inappropriate. Now, when it comes to it, the right is defending the freedom of expression, which she has tailored in the spirit that anyone can say anything, but he is not punished for it. On the other hand, opponents are physically punished by what we have seen in Hungary. Hate speech is organized and funded today. It is guided and has the purpose – to sow fear, to pervert people and to open the way to power. The Slovenian opposition party SDS received funding from abroad, specifically Hungary, during the last campaign to finance its advertisements. Like nationalist ideologies, the outpouring of hateful feelings and primitive words in times of crisis is offered as an escape. It is mainly exploited by people who feel socially disadvantaged. However, we must be concerned that politicians such as Salvini, Orban, Janša are exploiting these people for their agenda. The authors of hate speech once hid in anonymity, but today they reveal themselves - and this is mainly because of the politicians who give them support and image. So it seems like hate speech is becoming something very normal, and that's why its power is growing. Yet, respected colleagues, hate speech, violence – mentally or physically – is not and should not be something normal. Inciting any hostility, both against politicians, officials or other citizens, is destructive and counterproductive. We Europeans do not deserve this, Europe does not deserve this.  I would therefore like to remind all those who are promising political gain from this that this will be very short-term, and on behalf of the Socialists and Democrats, I call on us to turn on common sense.

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I must say I would be rather cautious about regulating this so-called hate speech problem and what you call the political climate. It’s a very elusive, vague term and it’s usually used by politicians against their enemies. It is always ‘them’ that are hateful creatures. It is always our opponents. ‘They’ are bad people. You had a very good example: you had two interventions before mine, and in each of them it was ‘them’. It’s never ‘us’, even in this Chamber. This is a highly partisan and highly political institution. Whenever we hear offensive language – and we hear offensive language quite often – when somebody from this part of the chamber says something offensive and insulting then he’s usually punished or reprimanded, but when somebody from that part of the chamber says something awful and disparaging... well, it’s free speech. So the problem is, of course, who defines the rules and who will execute those rules? If I think of those two interventions, I say to myself well, if this is the language of love and tolerance then we don’t need hate and intolerance anymore. Let me state the facts. A couple of weeks ago, the mayor of Gdansk was assassinated by a man who we know was a convicted criminal, with a long psychiatric record and immediately – immediately – after the murder, the political opposition in Poland put the blame on the Polish Government, on the public media, making something utterly non-political a monstrous, horrendous act of murder, but it was absolutely non-political. They made a huge case against us. If you can think of the most immoral, vile, repellent, foul, wicked, disgraceful, outrageous example of political cynicism that is it, you have it, and you heard it here, you heard about the media lynching the late president. Is that the language of love? Should it be punished? Or should my EPP colleague get away with it if I say that they lynch me? Probably the authorities would not be as tolerant, but never mind. So the problem is that even this tragic death does not prevent some of you from using this death to pursue a political agenda. This is political cynicism incarnate. There are no inhibitions, no sense of shame, really! When, some years ago, Mr Schäuble was attacked by a lunatic, we didn’t talk about the political climate, and that was a good decision. When a couple of years ago a member of my party was killed and another gravely wounded by a completely sane man who wanted to kill the leader of my party, Jarosław Kaczyński, the reaction here was a sad reflection on human folly. Nobody talked about hatred or hate speech. I can’t remember any reaction from the European Commission – you were not there Commissioner so nothing against you. Probably they suffered from sudden fit of aphasia, I won’t exclude it. So I have lived long enough to see people fall and behave abominably, but in cases like this I always say to myself, my God is it really possible that people who could be called or considered civilized, is it really possible that they say such things, that they can fall so low?

name: Ana Miranda
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, in recent times extremist forces have succeeded in introducing hate speech into political debate, which attacks the survival of democracy. It is a climate of pre-fascist hatred that goes from France to Hungary, from Poland to Slovakia, from Italy to the Spanish state, and which, as the Commissioner says, has no political borders or international borders. Meps Eleonora Forenza and Judith Sargentini know this well; Jean Wyllys, brazil; or the murdered Jo Cox and Marielle Franco, among many others.  We know this well who defend plurality from democratic political choices and are attacked on the street or in communication networks day after day in the exercise of our public office. We also know this in this European Parliament where at the last session a MEMBER of the PP stated that the left side of this House, that is, we, are political slugs. Elected officials insulted by sexist, fascist, bigoted, degrading and tolerance-undervaluing words also know this. Therefore, we cannot stand by while this happens and we must demand that our ideas be free.  And in this Parliament we must also have a huge responsibility. They no longer serve empty statements, but actions not to silence in front of hate speech. It is one thing to be free speech, as the Commissioner says, and it is another to allow in this House speeches which incite violence, as you hear so many times in this European Parliament, in that part of the House. And continue to allow these speeches that the result will be in the following European elections.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, my condolences to the family of Pavel Adamovic, mayor of Gdansk and defender of open borders for refugees, who was murdered during a charity concert!  Enemies of democracy do not exist only in Poland. Have you followed the conditions in which the Prespa Agreement was passed in Greece? Are you aware that, while this agreement was welcomed by all the political groups in Europe, the Members who supported it were accused by some of being traitors? Posters were glued to their faces. There were attacks by hooded men with stones and molotovs on their homes, while their children were inside. Those who organised the attack on elected MPs were far-right and extreme nationalists. The politics of hatred and terrorism are the policy of those who hate democracy. The answer is one: education and democracy.

name: Jörg Meuthen
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the EFDD Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which I am grateful that we have this debate that I have requested on the agenda today. The many examples show how necessary it is. The mood in society is getting more and more heated. Too often, it leads to physical violence against elected officials. I am thinking in particular of the mayor of Gdansk, Adamowicz, who was the victim of a disgraceful attack. Mr Lewandowski has said everything about this. Rest assured: the concern extends far beyond Poland. Let me be very clear: we must all consistently condemn all forms of politically motivated violence. However, while – and I must criticise this – far-right violence is quite rightly outlawed, far-left violence is unfortunately often trivialised. German Social Democrats are fuelling this thinking: SPD party member Stegner believes that violence is not left-wing. His party colleague Martin Schulz – well known in this House – even claims that the left and the use of force are mutually exclusive. A look at the history books would do these gentlemen a good thing: the black books of socialism and communism fill thousands of pages. And far-left violence is also a problem of the present. Consider the aggression of the left-wing terrorist Antifa. Representatives of my party are now facing detailed calls for murder, including myself. Of course, it should be a consensus in this House to condemn Antifa for its excesses of violence. But quite the opposite! There are even members of the German Greens in this House who proudly show themselves in the Chamber with antifa flags, who are therefore basically committed to far-left perpetrators of violence. One of them has even made it to the group chairman of the Green Group, namely Mrs Keller. I ask – she is not here, so I am asking as an example: Mrs Keller, are you not really ashamed of this? "When fascism returns, it will not say, 'I am fascism'. No, he will say, "I am anti-fascism", that is what Ignazio Silone prophesied. Antifa stands for this return, and large sections of the left do not even manage to distance themselves from it. No, they even show solidarity with this batting squad. And that, if I may say so, is pathetic! When left-wing violence is played down in such a way, one need not be surprised that bombings are being carried out on the offices of my patriotic party and members are being beaten to hospital. That is precisely the difference: we will always stand up for the right of the left to represent any nonsense, no matter how great. The left, on the other hand, wants to silence us. I promise that they will not succeed! (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our debate aims to 'combat the climate of hatred and physical violence against democratically elected incumbents'. This is a subject that I am familiar with, since the elected representatives of my party, the National Rally, and even more so our candidates, our activists, have long been the subject of the constant lynching of the mainstream media, but also of the physical and moral harassment of the far-left militias. This is true in France but also in almost all Western European countries. Alleged experts are stealing from increasingly contested governments and spitting out their hatred of all those they scornfully describe as "populists" in order to prevent any democratic debate. This is particularly the case today in Germany. I did not hear any very strong protests when our colleague Beatrix von Storch had his car set on fire in October 2015. And we are still waiting for strong condemnations against the attack, as violent as it is cowardly, which targeted the Member of the Bundestag Frank Magnitz. On the evening of 7 January, in Bremen, Mr. Magnitz was beaten and left for dead by a group of leftist activists. Instead of finally attacking the far-left militias, the German government has found nothing better than putting all AFD elected officials under surveillance by the intelligence services. In this Chamber, however, there are still Members who openly claim to be from the communist ideology, which has nevertheless claimed millions of lives.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Mr President, freedom of speech is essential. The monopoly on violence, institutionally, is held exclusively by the state. As trustees, the rulers must realize that their words and actions can lead citizens to extreme events when they provoke public sentiment. Power is not exercised without limits or control. Those who foster a climate of hatred, violence and discord among citizens will inevitably accept similar behaviour as equal members of society. As now in Greece, where a traitorous government forbids the use of the term "Macedonia". History is being foreared. Folk songs and hymns are censored. Events are forbidden. Educators are being prosecuted. The right to freedom of speech and our designation for centuries as Greek Macedonians are being violently suppressed. Everything they sow reaps and will see worse in the future. Ordinary Greek patriots, who Tsipras tore into foreign leaders as populists and fascists, will not compromise on the unconstitutional, undemocratic and illegal Prespa Agreement. So don't expect even one Greek to have sympathy for political traitors. Now they're reacting to the citizens. Macedonia is the land of Greeks and is Greek.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Two people have come forward to speak from the chamber. I would like to remind you that this debate does not provide for an in-house application procedure and does not provide for the possibility of accepting questions raised by raising a blue card. I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. – The violence engendered by rising national populism across the EU continues to claim victims. One of the groups that is increasingly attacked is that of democratically elected representatives. This is the case of Pawel Adamowicz, the mayor of the Polish city of Gdansk, who has recently died from injuries caused by a man who stabbed him during an event in front of hundreds of people. The aggressor is a 27-year-old ex-con who murdered him in front of the crowd attending a charity event. After stabbing Adamowicz, the aggressor took a microphone to ensure that with his attack he sought revenge for being "unjustly imprisoned and tortured by (the party) Citizen Platform". In Poland, as in so many other Member States, threats and hate messages are increasing with fascist and Nazi language. This is a very worrying phenomenon which requires the strongest condemnation on the part of this Parliament. On the eve of the forthcoming European elections and in the midst of a climate poisoned by radical and extremist forces, the security of public representatives should be a priority. At attacking us, democracy itself is closed. The EU must not allow it.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. – The violence engendered by rising national populism across the EU continues to claim victims. name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the Statement by the Council and the Commission on the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary – developments since September 2018 (2019/2517(RSP)).

name: Melania Ciot
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, common values such as human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights are the cornerstone of the European Union. Both institutions and Member States must therefore respect, protect and promote them. The Romanian Presidency, and indeed all of us, agree that the protection of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights is essential in our Union. On 18 September 2018 the Council received the European Parliament’s reasoned proposal under Article 7(1) calling on the Council to determine that there is a serious risk of a breach by Hungary of the values on which the Union is founded. This issue has been on the agenda of the General Affairs Council in October, November and December 2018. At the 12 November General Affairs Council, we received Hungary’s written response to Parliament’s reasoned proposal, as well as a factual contribution from the Commission on pending infringement procedures against Hungary. In December, ministers had a first exchange of views on the next steps of the procedure. We will continue the examination of Parliament’s reasoned proposal. At this stage, I cannot prejudge or draw conclusions as regards the final outcome of this procedure. We will keep Parliament informed on the next developments. Indeed, we take seriously into account the concerns expressed by the honourable Members of this House. Let me conclude by saying that the issues raised in this debate go to the heart of our commitment to this Union. We therefore trust that all sides will act responsibly and constructively to reach an outcome in accordance with our core values.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Parliament very much for putting the situation of Hungary on the agenda today. The last time we discussed the situation of the rule of law in Hungary was on 11 September last year. The next day, Parliament adopted its resolution triggering Article 7(1) of the Treaty procedure against Hungary. As I explained then, the Commission shares an important number of concerns expressed in the reasoned proposal of the European Parliament, in particular, as regards fundamental rights, corruption, the treatment of Roma and the independence of the judiciary. Today, I would like to update you on the developments which have occurred since last September, including the developments in the Council.  First, as I already said in September, unlike the European Parliament, the Commission has a right under the Treaties to launch infringement proceedings and, in the case of Hungary, has launched many value-related infringement proceedings. The Commission is determined to make the best use of this power.  Last week, the Commission decided to send a reasoned opinion to Hungary concerning the so-called ‘Stop Soros’ legislation. This legislation criminalises activities that support asylum and residence applications and further restricts the right to request asylum. The Hungarian authorities now have two months to address the Commission’s concerns; otherwise, the Commission may refer the case to the Court of Justice. Furthermore, last December, the Hungarian Parliament adopted a new law on overtime, amending the Labour Code. As you know, this new law has provoked large street demonstrations in Hungary in recent weeks. The Commission is currently analysing the conformity of the new law with EU law, notably, the Working Time Directive, and sent a letter to the Hungarian authorities seeking further clarifications. In the light of the response received, the Commission will decide on potential next steps.  Also in December, we heard that the Central European University has now been forced to relocate its US-accredited academic programmes from Hungary to Vienna. Having a university forced to leave an EU Member State because of governmental measures and systematic pressure is unprecedented in the history of the European Union. It is sad and very worrying that this can happen in the EU, despite the Commission’s pending infringement procedure and clear warnings from many, many stakeholders. Another development in December relates to the merger of more than 400 media outlets into one single holding controlled by a board whose members are affiliated with the governing party. The situation has been aggravated by the subsequent Government decision to exempt this merger from the scrutiny of both the national competition authority and the media authority.  The Commission is also, through the European Semester, monitoring the functioning of the Hungarian justice system, including the regime for the appointment and promotion of judges, the organisation of the prosecution service, and the envisaged setting-up of a new administrative court system. In December last year, the Hungarian Parliament adopted two laws establishing an administrative court system envisaged to become operational as from 2020. It is regrettable that the Hungarian Parliament did not wait for the opinion of the Venice Commission, which is scheduled for March this year. The Commission is currently assessing the new laws in view of their compatibility with EU law and European standards. The opinion of the Venice Commission will feed this assessment.  In addition to infringement proceedings, the Commission is using other instruments, including audits and investigations relating to the use of EU funds and actions through the European Semester, the EU annual cycle of economic policy coordination. The Commission is also monitoring and assessing the implementation of the country-specific recommendations relating to the need to reinforce the anti-corruption framework, to strengthen prosecutorial efforts and improve transparency and competition in public procurement.  As regards the ongoing Article 7 procedure, I regret that, so far, the European Parliament has not been given a genuine opportunity to present its reasoned proposal to the Council. The Commission has made very clear that, whatever position the Council will be taking, it must ensure a fair handling of the reasoned proposal tabled by Parliament. This, I think, is part of the way European institutions should show respect for each other and each other’s role. Let me inform you that in November, following a request made by the Austrian Presidency, the Commission presented to the Council a factual overview on its actions as regards Hungary, in particular, the values-related infringement proceedings. These relate, in particular, to asylum and assistance to asylum seekers, civil society and higher education school segregation of Roma. Most of these cases are already pending before the Court of Justice.  As you know, the Hungarian Government already provided their reply to the reasoned proposal. I do believe the Council now has all the key elements necessary to start with its own assessment of the issues raised.

name: Tamás Deutsch
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Why did the left-wing majority again push the Hungarian question to the European Parliament's agenda? The official reasons for the initiative are purely pretexts. They need them to fight with Hungary again. The reason for the debate is that the European Parliament election campaign is taking place and the left-wing majority of the EP has also launched an attack on the Hungarian people in this campaign. But why do you have this temper with us? Because there is a question of fate that has dominated the lives of the people of Europe for decades, in which the overwhelming majority of Hungarians, regardless of party affiliation, want something very different from you. This is a matter of immigration. You, the left-wing majority in the EP, regard mass immigration as a fundamental right and support it. They want to introduce migrant visas and legalise illegal migration. You expect migration to solve europe's demographic problems. In order to support immigration, they want to take away the rights of border protection and asylum procedures from the Member States. You financially support the illegal activities of NGOs organising illegal migration. You want a quota system for resettlement and resettlement. They want to determine who we are obliged to live with in our country, and you are threatening, blackmailing, punishing countries that reject immigration. Unlike you, we Hungarians say no to immigration. We want to protect our country's borders against illegal immigrants, thereby protecting the Union's external borders. We are convinced that it is not the need to bring trouble to Europe, but to bring help to people in distress. In the interests of the security of Hungarian and other European citizens, we want to end immigration that threatens our European way of life. For no other reason than that, that is why they have a problem with us, but four months before the elections, there is absolutely no need to hurt the Hungarians. In this election, it will be up to the People of Europe to decide whether Europe should remain the europeans' choice.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The European Parliament has taken a historic decision by initiating Article 7 proceedings against Hungary. We did not take it easy at the time, but we were criticised for taking so long. This was necessary because we have carefully and thoroughly examined the information available and weighed all the pros and cons responsibly. In September, Parliament adopted the report by a qualified and very clear majority. In fact, one could have expected an appropriate response from the Council and Hungary. By no means. The Hungarian Government, which did not miss an opportunity to get involved in the process, has since preferred to show Parliament the cold shoulder. Your absence from today's debate clearly shows this. It refuses to debate, it has chosen to ignore not only all the concerns and objections of its European friends – indeed, we are friends – but also the protests of large sections of the Hungarian population. Hungary is increasingly becoming a facade democracy, where the press is on an equal footing, the judges are put on a short leash and non-governmental organisations have to fear for their existence. Academic freedom is under threat, and conspiracy theories replace political analysis. Against this background, it is more than surprising that the Council has still not taken any serious steps to move closer to Parliament's decision. It should not matter that a Member State is increasingly abandoning common values. To accept developments tacitly is to abandon the European project, the common European project. I hope that the Presidency will not put this on the back burner.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, it is interesting to once again see this Parliament bashing Hungary when it comes to rule of law and democracy. It’s the very same House where prominent Members have proposed to take away travel allowances for people that they disagree with. The same House where we, in this very plenary session, are going to vote on amendments regarding the Rules of Procedure that are clearly an attack by the majority against minority views in Parliament. If you cannot see that hypocrisy you must have been in the European Parliament for too long.  I don’t know the exact content of the allegations about Hungary but I do know that countries in this Union are not treated equally. If we see violent bashing of demonstrators in Catalonia, we do not see a reaction from his House. If we see a demonstration, a peaceful demonstration, carried out in Budapest, it is apparently a violation of the rule of law. It is fundamentally problematic that these attacks, that have been going on since the Jörg Haider case in Austria more than a decade ago and up to today against Hungary and Poland, are continuing from the European establishment’s side. It is profoundly dazzling to me that you don’t see in this House that the only thing you do is bash up more support for the people that want to get rid of: Mr Orbán, Mr Kaczyński, and whoever is next in that line of people that you don’t like, that the European peoples have elected democratically in the Member States. It’s a shame for Europe and it’s a shame for the European Union. (Applause)

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we have to conclude that, since the vote on my report in September, things in Hungary have actually only got worse. Hungarian citizens have every reason in the world to take to the streets and they deserve our continued solidarity. Let me list for you some of the developments of this autumn. Mr Timmermans has done so as well. The Central European University has to move to Vienna because the agreement with the State of New York is not going to be signed; homelessness was made a punishable crime; a new administrative court is being set up, overseen by the Justice Minister; the former Macedonian Prime Minister, sentenced for corruption, got refugee status in the blink of an eye; 450 pro-government media outlets were merged into a single conglomerate; and the Parliament passed the ‘slave law’. Internal memos of the Hungarian Government became public yesterday and they show what we all know: they are stalling for time. They are flooding their colleagues in the Council with paperwork and they suggest cooperating, but what they’re doing is stalling for time. Now that is not a surprise, but now that this is official, this demands that the Romanian Presidency come forward with its timetable. Hungarian citizens have the right to protection and the right to know what you’re planning to do. European voters have the right to know what their political leaders are going to do. So I ask you to take that responsibility, to invite me to the Council and start a real process. To my colleagues in the European People’s Party – some of you are there, I appreciate that, a lot of you are not there – I continue to appreciate that you voted for my report, but what have you been doing since? Where is your sense of responsibility?

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Hungary is a beautiful country, a crossroads of cultures of which Budapest is a symbol. No one here is trying to attack the Hungarian people. But today, Viktor Orban wants to champion a new European nationalist and anti-migrant model. It is the opposite of the history of this beautiful country and of the entire history of our continent. Since September, illiberal drifts have been worsening. Media and administrative tribunals charged with judging public affairs are under control. At the same time, corruption is on the rise and Hungary refuses to join the European Public Prosecutor's Office. An authoritarian neo-liberalism was established for the benefit of Mr. Orbon and some of his friends. Few neo-liberals would have dared to pass a law like the labour law, called the Slavery Act. Hungarian excesses have no limits and, to hide them, propaganda is in full swing. Mr Timmermans, these drifts started in 2010 and you are telling us that you are following developments. You are looking at the law and - I say to my Hungarian colleagues - there is no war. The migrant issue is just a diversion. To be European is first and foremost to respect the values of the European Union. Yes, Hungary is trying to buy time behind legal and procedural arguments, and the Council's response is distressing.

name: Olaf Stuger
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – The turnout in the Netherlands in the 2014 European elections was 37%. The turnout in hungary's elections to the national parliament was 70% and half of those votes were for Mr Orban. These are percentages, Mr President, which colleagues here do not even dare to dream of. What's the difference now? Here in the European Parliament - I have already seen this in recent weeks - we are talking about teenage pregnancies in Peru and about freedom of the press in Nigeria. Mr President, that is not in the interests of European citizens! Orban, on the other hand, is concerned with security in his country, with the protection of borders. He takes good care of the people of his country. That's the difference! Someone, a prime minister, who takes good care of his people does not deserve procedure 7. No, he deserves a statue! I would therefore like to make an appeal and ask you if there is any budget to be made available in the budget to erect a statue for Orban.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. The Orban system established in Hungary builds on the chain of vassals and corruption. As a representative of the Jobbik Movement for Hungary, the largest opposition party, I am convinced that our political struggle must not be won here in Brussels, but at home, together with the Hungarian people, using all constitutional means to replace Viktor Orban's regime.

text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The law is the only and most important instrument that allows us to operate in such a politically and ideologically diverse environment as we are in the European Union. name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. For example, the armed beaters of power in my presence, and even without disturbing me from live video coverage, beat up representatives in the public television building, and now the prosecuting authority is threatening the victims with criminal charges – classing them as agents of George Soros. This is pretty much what we can report from the new country of new slaves, namely Hungary. The only good news, Mr President, is that national democratic resistance is intensing.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Viktor Orban has run away from today's debate. That's understandable, since you have nothing more to say. Orban argues that this debate is already part of the EP campaign and that this is unacceptable. What should we talk about in addition to campaigns and campaigns, if not about the continuous undermining of the rights of Hungarian citizens and the values of our Community in Hungary for nine years. Since September, the situation in Hungary has deteriorated at the speed of light. From the extreme centralisation of the media to the establishment of fidesz courts to the sending of the State Audit Office to opposition parties. Everything else has fallen off Orban's autocracy and the facial features of Vladimir Putin's regime are falling behind him. What else needs to happen so that all of us, the EPP and the European Council, finally take seriously the threat that the illiberalisation of Hungary poses to the whole of Europe and take action against it?

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The situation in Hungary has not improved. name: Ingeborg Gräßle (PPE).
text: Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen. If there are any doubts as to why I am here, I am here because, for the Committee on Budgetary Control, I am concerned about what european money is in Hungary.  This money is doing a lot there: a constant improvement in living conditions, i.e. fewer unemployed people and rising incomes. That's how we actually imagined it. But we are concerned because we cannot protect EU funds as we should. Hungary has a problem with fraud, with sham legal tendering procedures, with corruption and with judicial authorities who do not want or are not allowed to prosecute these offences properly, because perhaps people who are wanted to protect are also involved. The budgetary controllers also have a problem with the fact that the Hungarian Government does far too little and sometimes does nothing about it.  That is why, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, please ensure that the Commission's Rule of Law Regulation can be launched soon in the trialogue, so that we can get this regulation soon.  The corruption index published yesterday shows Hungary in third place in the EU, in 64th place worldwide, just ahead of Greece. In Greece, however, the arrow points upwards. It is getting better, whereas things have gotten much worse in Hungary since 2012. That is sad.  I firmly believe that Hungary can do more, and it would be an important confidence-building step to join the European Public Prosecutor. There is no economically successful country that tolerates corruption at the same time. Vice-President Timmermans, I would like to thank you very much.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. A few days ago, the Hungarian Prime Minister called this debate a "Soros séance" and the Foreign Minister called today's debate a political charade. I think these two remarks accurately show the current Hungarian Government's view of democracy. The prime minister's absence is also proof that Viktor Orban is afraid to face the European Parliament. Orban fears democracy, fears democratic debate. That is why he has called for the end of media freedom and an independent judiciary, and therefore does nothing to prevent corruption that has already reached his family, and therefore seeks to make the functioning of NGOs impossible, which is why he wants to tie the country's chariot to various authoritarian regimes and dictators. Orban is not negotiating with the European Parliament, but he is going to Brazil or even Belarus. Nothing matters to Orban but power, and therefore betrays the interests of his own country, democracy, European values. We in the European Parliament cannot help with this policy. It must be said clearly that this policy has no place in the European Union.

name: Christophe Hansen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, if Hungary were to join the European Union today the country would not even meet the accession criteria. The Hungarian Government receives war refugees with barbed wire, and criminalises those who support asylum seekers. At the same time, Nikola Gruevski, a crook convicted for corruption, gets safe passage and political asylum to escape justice, and even Hungarian citizenship. Last year, Hungary became the first European Member State to expel a European academic institution. The list of European values that the Hungarian Government has corrupted is long and well-known, as pointed out by Ms Sargentini and several other colleagues. The European Parliament has spent years asking the Hungarian Government to rejoin the path of the rule of law. In vain. Now actions have to speak louder than words. The suspension or reduction of payments to Member States that undermine the rule of law is no less than a financial backstop to uphold fundamental values. To the Council I say: how much longer will we have to wait for you to act on our clear request to trigger Article 7? Reluctance in the defence of our common values is complicity in their subversion.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the European Union is not just a common market. It shares values enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the Treaties. Since September, when we last discussed this issue, the Hungarian Government has nationalised most newspapers, televisions and radio stations, closed a university, is said to be linked to the opposition, and insisted on the inhumantreatment of refugees. The Government continued to put the rule of law at stake to the detriment of Hungarian citizens and all Europeans. Orbán is a bad example to which others who deserve our concern in Poland, Romania, Slovakia or Malta join.  Mr President, we need to act and we need to adopt a monitoring instrument that gives consequence to cases of non-compliance with fundamental rights, we need to make the funds conditional on respect for our fundamental values and we need to require the Council to give a consequence to Article 7, as the treaties oblige. Freedom, Democracy and the rule of law are not beautiful words to memorize speeches. These are values that are part of our identity. An identity that's threatened. Let us have the courage to defend her.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Mr Niedermüller's speech reminded me of the Hungarian joke that you have a bunny, you have a hat on your head, you don't have a hat on your head: it doesn't matter, you're wrong anyway, you'll get it on your head anyway. If the Hungarian Prime Minister is here, the problem is that the Hungarian Prime Minister is not here, that is the problem. Every accusation that has been made is ridiculous, and you all know it here, colleagues. The facts are completely ignored, because many Member States could be prosecuted under the rule of law if they really mattered and were of equal standards. As we know very well, the press has not been nationalised in Hungary and universities have not been closed, just as CEU's accredited courses in Hungary will continue to be there and operate. You all know that, but these are the facts you always forget. This debate is an excuse. They serve as an excuse for the frustrated opposition performance in Hungary, which involves everyone from the far right to the Socialists, yet has dwindling support. And this whole debate that's going on here is about rousing their ridiculous production to a European level. Which our pro-immigration colleagues are using to increase pressure on Hungary because we do not want to join the ranks of immigrant countries. As Mrs Sargentini stated, Hungarian citizens have the same rights... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. This debate today is yet another proof of the double standards that have unfortunately become common practice in this House with some Member States. They criticise Hungary on issues that operate as existing practices in several Member States, such as overtime regulation or administrative arbitration. Moreover, they are clearly trying to influence public opinion with half-information, exaggeration and, in many cases, fake news. You cannot think that it will benefit the European Union and help cohesion between Member States if we deal with such non-coastal political debates instead of the real problems of citizens. Why, for example, do they not care that in Romania, students are constantly being veganed at the University of Târgu Mureş, they are not allowed to take exams, and they do not want to create a Hungarian faculty. The credibility of the European Parliament is damaged in the eyes of citizens when they deal with an issue so professionally, purely for political and electoral purposes. Especially if it comes up in the same country. It is not worthy of Parliament.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Vice-President Timmermans, for the first time in history since the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the European Parliament approved with a resounding two-thirds majority the initiative to activate no less than Article 7(1) in relation to Hungary. Because the drift described by Viktor Orbán's government can only be described as "putinization", a concentration of powers incompatible with the founding values of the European Union. Aggressions against pluralism and systematic disrespect against minorities, but also attacks on freedom of information and academic freedom.  The situation has only made it worse. What I want, Mr Timermans, is that, when the Council deliberates with the Commission on the consequences of that vote of no less than two-thirds of the European Parliament, the European Parliament , which had the initiative in the first place , is called to participate in that deliberation, and that the three institutions add their voices to say that enough of the putinisation of Viktor Orbán's government in Hungary.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, the European Union is a community of different countries with different traditions and development pathways. We are joined by some common interests and values, but they cannot erase our differences in culture and mentality. Insisting on universal solutions can only distance us from each other and quarrel because there will always be one side who feels that something has been imposed on it. Hungary is a country of long history and rich tradition that has a different view of some things in the Union than some other members. The Hungarian people choose the power they want, and it implements the political agenda for which legitimacy won the elections. It is the right of citizens who disagree with the authorities to protest peacefully and use other democratic instruments to express their views. The government must enable them to do so, and it is up to us to help citizens consume their democratic rights as easily as possible in dialogue with the Hungarian authorities. Everything else is up to the Hungarian people, and the Union must not undermine democracy in one sovereign state because of one's preferences.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, the European Union accuses the Hungarian Government of violating the principles of the rule of law and human rights, while for other countries it tolerates behaving in this way. The real reason why the European Union behaves in this way is that Hungary refuses to grant political asylum to migrants who are persecuted for criminal offences and to others who are controlled and led by corrupt NGOs. So instead of working with the Hungarian government to grant political asylum to the proportion of migrants to whom it owes it, it chooses the path of conflict.  But the Hungarian government protects the interests of the Hungarian people. It is not like the Greek government, which is introspective, is under pressure and has turned Greece into a vast camp of unhappy migrants, to whom they are neither granted political asylum nor accepted by any country, nor are they deported. I would like to end by saying that this attitude towards Hungary is a prime example of the hypocrisy of the European Union, because, while in Hungary it behaves like this, Turkey refuses to follow ... (The President removes the floor from the speaker.)

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. The new anti-Hungarian parliamentary debate, coerced by the Greens and their accomplices, is a direct continuation of the Sargentini report, which initiated the rule of law procedure under Article 7. The repeated pillory of Hungary rejecting illegal migration is nothing more than a targeted election campaign event for left-wing pro-immigration political forces. The most desithening actors in this pseudo-democratic scenario aimed at stigmatising our Hungarians are hungarian opposition members who, following old Communist practices, seek to destabilise the social order with coup demonstrations at home and denunciate their own country unscrupulously. Don't listen to them. Long live Hungary! Long live Europe!

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by When it comes to the debate on respect for human rights, democracy and the rule of law in Europe, President Timmermans usually says: now we are talking about Poland or Hungary. So I accept this convention, but now, Mr President, we will be talking about this alleged proposal that has been made against Hungary. The rule of law is now most threatened by the behaviour of the Authorities of the European Union. Article 354 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union expressly states: Parliament may request the triggering of Article 7 by a two-thirds majority of the votes cast, I shall repeat: the votes cast. This majority was not obtained, and yet parliament's authorities announced that the proposal had been adopted.  In order to falsify the outcome of the elections, a falsified result was given in totalitarian states, but the fact that some of the votes cast were explicitly annulled when the result is known is really an inventive one unknown to history. This is a very menacing memento. I will repeat once again: the illiberal democracy that Prime Minister Orban spoke about is not a demand, but a diagnosis of what is happening in this House.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me react to some of the things that were said. First of all, those who are saying, ‘there’s nothing to see here, nothing’s happening, it’s all a political game’, let me just refer to what I said in my introduction. We are looking at very specific issues and we are asking questions and if we believe that the answer to those questions does not deliver compatibility with EU law, we will proceed. I mentioned the so-called Stop Soros law. We will have questions about that. The relocation outside of Hungary of the US-accredited programmes of the Central European University – somebody here said ‘nothing’s changed’. Well, something has changed, very drastically, and we have questions about that. The merger of more than 400 media outlets without the competent authorities even being allowed to check whether this is in line with legislation. These are all very concrete things. The adoption of two new laws establishing an administrative court system – we have very concrete questions about that. The adoption of the new law on overtime – a lot has been discussed about that. We have questions about that, whether that’s compatible with EU law and this brings me to the point of principle I would like to make about this. Always, democracy is then invoked as justification for not complying with EU legislation. That’s not the nature of democracy. That’s not the nature of how this European Union works. Hungary chose, fortunately – and it was a wonderful choice – Hungary chose – it is a sovereign choice – to become a member of the European Union. It was a choice and it was ratified by Parliament and confirmed in a referendum by the Hungarian people. If you choose to become a member of a treaty-based organisation like the European Union, you – by that choice – say you will follow the rules of that Treaty. The European Commission has been given the task of looking into whether Member States follow the rules of the Treaty, and the rules of the Treaty are very, very clear on many issues and, especially, the rule of law is very clear. Article 2 and Article 19 of the Treaty stipulate very clearly the separation of powers, the independence of the media, etc., etc. That’s what we’re looking at.  This is not about a fight against countries who do not want migrants. This is not about attacking the democracy of a Member State or the cultural diversity within the European Union. This is about holding countries accountable for something they chose to do without any pressure from anybody else, a sovereign choice of countries to join the European Union and that is the beauty of this organisation – that this is a sovereign choice. By doing that, Hungary also had a lot of benefits, a lot of benefits. Many other Member States showed, over the years, huge solidarity with Hungary so that it could catch up with the rest of the European Union and prosper as every Hungarian citizen deserves. But membership doesn’t come with only rights; it also comes with obligations and the obligations are stipulated in the Treaty, and I think it is the duty of EU institutions – the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission – to hold each other accountable as far as the application of EU law is concerned. That is what we’re doing in the case of Hungary, like in any other Member State, nothing more and nothing less.  (Applause)

name: Melania Ciot
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me assure the House once again that the Presidency and the Council as a whole attach great importance to upholding the rule of law and the protection of fundamental rights. They are at the heart of our concerns. We are ready to keep you informed on developments, and I can assure Members that the Presidency will pay particular attention to the views expressed here today during this debate. We have heard your request and we remain open to a pragmatic approach. Thank you very much once again for your attention.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Haro on Hungary! This has been the Commission's watchword since Viktor Orbon bluntly signalled his rejection of the mass immigration imposed by Brussels. However, its popularity is on the rise, reaching between 53% and 63% in December 2018. It is not a matter of sounding, but of Viktor Orban's ability to respond to a fundamental concern: immigration, which 52% of Hungarians consider to be one of Europe's greatest civilizational challenges. In this, they are also supported by a majority of public opinion which, from Washington to Rome, via Brasilia, places the European Union a little more against the meaning of history. All the more so because by stigmatizing a legitimate concern, Brussels risks permanently alienating so many Eastern European citizens, quick to turn to more laughing horizons. Hungary's rapprochement with both the United States and Russia does not say anything else. Every autocratic regime has an end, and between an uncompromising European Union and a freedom-loving Eastern Europe, the rupture now seems consummated.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union is a community of different countries with different traditions. Although we share common values, they cannot undermine our identity.  Hungarians have their own tradition and culture and a democratically elected government that has a mandate to implement its political agenda. The allegations against Hungary are merely the result of opposition to the EU's migration policy. Hungary is to be punished because the nation has decided that it will not be a country of immigrants. You can't stigmatized him for that.  Moreover, the decisions of the European Parliament and the European Commission concerning Hungary demonstrate the enormous influence of the American financier George Soros, who launched a frontal attack on Hungary. Soros and European Commission Vice-President Timmermans have known each other for a long time and regularly discuss a number of topics relating to the EU. Timmermans himself has said that he has been working with Soros for about 20 years, and during their discussions the topic of how the unity of the European Union can be strengthened is constantly returning. Frans Timmermans, as the centre-left candidate for the future head of the European Commission, is therefore using Soros to launch an election campaign to flogging Hungary. It should be emphasised that the role of the European Parliament is to conduct dialogue, not to undermine Christian democracy in a sovereign country.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – Here we are again in the plenary session of the European Parliament, where for the utsith time they are trying to place Hungary on the bench of shame for reasons that have been made. The objection this time is a change in the labour code and alleged protest excesses. The overtime law clearly does not violat any Eu law, and throughout the protests the police have acted professionally and properly, which has been well documented in the impact videos of opposition activists. Now this antics are really ridiculous.  If the honourable left-wing Members really care about freedom of assembly and fundamental human rights, why don't they cast their watchful eye on Paris? How is it that the more than 100 permanently injured and more than 1,000 more easily wounded people are elegantly sithing through while they see the footing of rights in uninfree Hungarian events? Obviously, because this whole freedom of movement is just a hypocritical excuse to attack Hungary because it dares to think differently. We are Christian Democrats, we condemn illegal immigration, and we are not afraid to stand up for our values. The days of this parliament are already numbered until the next election. They may attack us with new pretexts, but empty slogans will not protect you from facing the will of the electorate for long. In May, people will decide.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. – Yellow vest protests in France have been going on for more than two months. In Paris, we witnessed violence and brutality under the guise of protest and the struggle for civil and labour rights. But in the European Parliament we are not discussing violence on French streets involving hundreds of thousands of people, and in which a dozen people have died, but we are again discussing Hungary and the reforms being carried out there by a legitimately elected government.  It is good to recall that the European Union is based on the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, although it often seems that the two principles are actually abused because they are sometimes violated and sometimes their violations close their eyes.  Unfortunately, this House also adopts legal acts that encroach on areas that should be directly under the competence of Member States, such as the health and education system. On the other hand, it calls into question the implementation of some reforms for which national governments are responsible.  In my view, we need to put the principle of subsidiarity back at the heart of eu decision-making and decision-making. The Union must respect the Member States in order to strengthen itself, its strength and the future of the European project lies on the one hand in the common principles and values on which it is built and respect for the sovereignty of the Member States and their powers on the other.

name: Christine Revault d'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. The historic vote of this Parliament against the Hungarian government should have sounded the alarm, but it was wishful thinking. In recent months, the Commission's warning against laws criminalising aid to migrants has not been heard, the University of Central Europe has had to leave Budapest and the Hungarian government has gone on a crusade against gender studies, an academic field that is essential to understanding the social relations between men and women. How can we resist such a situation? For we owe it to the Hungarian citizens who are the first victims. Viktor Orban may have made an illusion by pretending to protect his people, even if it means breaking the rules, but this did not last. Thousands of Hungarians are demonstrating against a labour law that legalizes the exploitation of employees and more broadly against Orban's entire policy. I'm sending them all my support. Getting out of this crisis and remaking the Union an area of democracy, freedom and justice will certainly take time, but it is not impossible with an alternative political project: a third way between, on the one hand, austerity and free competition and, on the other, authoritarianism that have crushed peoples.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – The examination of how the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary and elsewhere in the European Union are being respected needs to follow a transparent and objective method that is fair, is seen to be fair and not based on partisan polemics. I have already stated before that I am deeply sceptical as to whether this is happening in this Parliament, though many Members here clarioned their devotion to democracy. Without reference to Hungary, I deplore the ways by which members of the Parliament are manoeuvering to make Malta also subject to rule of law strictures. In this, they show a flagrant disregard for facts plus a willingness to underwrite comments and analyses that are politically skewed. They collaborate openly with anti-government forces in Malta while sharing in their hidden agendas. It is legitimate for the EU to ensure that the rule of law and fundamental rights are strictly observed. If, however, such assurance is sought on the basis of some ‘method’ or ‘model’ similar to the one being attempted for Malta by members of this Parliament, then the process is one that will shame and tarnish the EU’s proclaimed attachment to democracy, and indeed to the rule of law.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing – the European Union is founded on common values such as democracy, freedom, equality, the rule of law, human rights and human dignity. Not only the European institutions, but also the Member States must protect and promote these values. It is very worrying that the development of the situation in Hungary in the area of the rule of law and fundamental rights is constantly deteriorating and Hungary has long distanced itself from European values under Orbán's government. Since September 2018, when the European Parliament drew attention to violations of these rights, the situation in Hungary has deteriorated in a number of areas, such as freedom of the press, the judiciary, the position of NGOs, academics and journalists, but also migrants and women. Corruption has reached unprecedented levels, which is why, in the Committee on Budgetary Control, we are concerned about how European money is being used, as it is the subject of fraud and fake tenders for the benefit of orbán's government and its supporters. It is therefore very important that we respond to this situation, and it is in the interests of all of us that the Council proceed according to Article 7, as proposed to it by the European Parliament.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Venezuela (2019/2543(RSP)). Members will be informed that this debate will not give the floor on request and that blue card questions will not be accepted. I am told that Commissioner Stylianides will replace The Vice-President of the Commission, Mrs Mogherini, in this debate.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, these are really critical moments for Venezuela. The crisis unfortunately is worsening by the day and it risks destabilising the entire region. Millions of people have already left the country and many more are fleeing in these very hours. It is urgent to find a peaceful and democratic way out of the crisis, a solution where the people of Venezuela have the chance to determine their own future. Free and fair elections are the only way out of this crisis.  On 23 January, the people of Venezuela called massively for democracy. Regretfully, these demonstrations have been met with indiscriminate violence from the authorities, leading to numerous deaths and many more injured and arrested.  In these days, the European Union has made its voice constantly heard, with two statements by my dear colleague the High Representative, on behalf of all 28 Member States, and through regular contacts with our Latin American and international partners. We have called for the urgent organisation of free, fair and credible elections to allow the restoration of democratic and constitutional order in the country. By free, fair and credible elections, we mean that all political forces should be able to participate without any obstacles. We mean that a national electoral council should be established with a balanced composition. We mean also that international observers should monitor the whole process – any aspect of this process. The presidential elections last May were neither free, fair nor credible. As a result, they lacked all democratic legitimacy. The country urgently needs a government that truly represents the will of the Venezuelan people. In the event new presidential elections are not announced, we Europeans will take further action, including on the issue of recognition of the country’s leadership. The European Union fully supports the National Assembly: right now, it is the only legitimate political body that has been democratically elected by the people of Venezuela. The powers of the National Assembly need to be restored in line with the Constitution of Venezuela. The prerogatives and safety of its members must also be respected, starting with its President, Juan Guaidó. His personal and political freedom must be guaranteed. The priority now is to prevent a military escalation and to create the conditions for a peaceful and democratic solution to the crisis. With this aim, our High Representative is in constant contact with European capitals but also with our international and Latin American partners, as I already said.  Yesterday, the High Representative met with the Foreign Ministers of Bolivia and Ecuador. Since last weekend, she has spoken with UN Secretary—General António Guterres, and with the Vatican’s Secretary for Relations with States, Paul Gallagher, with Argentinian President Mauricio Macri, with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, and with the Foreign Ministers of Canada, Chile, Costa Rica, Cuba, Mexico, Peru and Norway.  With all of them, she discussed our proposal to create an international contact group. We believe it is important that regional and international actors work together to open up this space for a political process inside Venezuela. It should be clear to everyone that military intervention would only make things worse. The solution to this crisis must come from the people of Venezuela. At the same time, the conditions are not ripe yet for a dialogue between the different sides inside the country. So the contact group will not engage in a direct dialogue with the two Venezuelan sides, but we believe that an international initiative can help build the conditions that will eventually lead to relaunching a political process inside Venezuela, and to free and fair elections with all the necessary guarantees. We want to restart meaningful talks at the international level as an intermediate step and a precondition for talks inside Venezuela. The preparations for the contact group are ongoing and the High Representative will discuss this tomorrow with the 28 EU Foreign Ministers at Gymnich.  At the same time, the European Union is maintaining its position as set out in the Council Conclusions of May last year, with restrictive measures on the top brass of the Maduro regime.
