Allow me a final word on our humanitarian work, because the situation inside Venezuela, unfortunately, especially in the humanitarian field, is really deteriorating moment by moment, minute by minute. We remain committed to helping those in need in Venezuela and the host communities that have welcomed the many Venezuelans who have fled their country. In December, I remember, in Strasbourg, I announced an additional EUR 20 million in humanitarian assistance only. This brings total EU support for last year only to EUR 55 million for the Venezuelan people both inside Venezuela and in host communities, and sometimes our humanitarian partners provided assistance really behind the scenes, in very dangerous ways. Federica Mogherini met in December with Eduardo Stein, the Joint Special Envoy of the UN Agencies. We expressed our willingness to work closely with him to address these challenges and we very much support a regional response to the current crisis. We care about Venezuela and its people. Hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans are also European citizens or have family in Europe. We will do all in our power to prevent the first war in decades in Latin America and to help the people of Venezuela find a way out of this dramatic situation.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, on 23 January, the President of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, complied with the provisions of the Venezuelan Constitution and assumed the presidency of the country on an interim initiative. Its mandate has a unique and clear purpose: to lead Venezuela towards free and democratic elections in the shortest possible time; nothing more and nothing less.  Since then, many states, including major Latin American democracies, including the United States, Australia, Canada, Israel, have recognized the interim presidency of Guaidó. The question is: what is Europe waiting for? The whole of Europe is looking at us; all of Venezuela is looking at us, and what do we do? How long, dear colleagues?  Those who will be demonstrating today on the streets of Venezuela are not Europeans, it is true, but they fight for the same values that we fight for. They are not Europeans, it is true, but they struggle to have a dignified life like the one we have. They are not Europeans, it is true, but they fight for peace and freedom as we fight. They are not Europeans, but they fight to keep their children not in Maduro prisons, but in colleges and universities as ours are. They are not Europeans, it is true, but they fight so that more than two and a half million Venezuelan refugees or exiles can return to their country with dignity and with their heads high as we did after the war. They are not Europeans, but they fight so that the deaths of so many thousands of innocent men and women in these 19 years, 11 months and 29 days of tyranny have not been in vain.  They are not Europeans, but they are Europeans, because we too are Venezuelans, because when it comes to freedom, democracy, equality, dignity in the world, there are no borders. We ourselves could not, we would not have the right to call ourselves Europeans if we did not act today as if we were Venezuelans. When it comes to defending human rights, freedom and democracy, Europe cannot be neutral or equidistant. Europe is not just a place. Europe is also an ideal. Europe is an aspiration.  How many violent deaths, how many sick people died from lack of medicine, how many pregnant women without nutrition, how many elderly, how many helpless children will die from lack of food? How much longer does it have to happen in Venezuela for us to understand what's going on there? That is why we are asking this House, this Parliament, for three things. First, let us recognize the National Assembly and Acting President Juan Guaidó as Venezuela's only legitimate powers. Second, let us demand that the Venezuelan armed forces ensure a peaceful transition of powers loyal to the Constitution and the Venezuelan people. And thirdly, let us make available to the new authorities a first urgent aid package to alleviate the humanitarian crisis in Venezuela. If Maduro is a tyrant, we can't give him a deadline to call elections. If Maduro is a tyrant, we can't ask him to talk. If Maduro is a tyrant, we cannot expect him to rectify, because to expect him to rectify a tyrant is to give the tyrant a chance.  Tyrants don't call elections. Tyrants don't talk. Tyrants don't rectify. They're tyrants, they're not country flowers. Tyrants are dangerous and with tyrants you can only act with the head high and with the principles by flag, with severity.  That's why let's do Venezuelan history today, even though we're Europeans. Let us recognize the democratic and legitimate power of Venezuela; let us be as the European Parliament the first European institution to recognise Venezuelan democracy. Let's help change Venezuela's regime from Europe. Tyrants will never illuminate any democratic possibility.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, I think we all agree that Venezuela has been suffering for many years unfortunately a very serious, very serious political and democratic crisis, a huge economic and social crisis and, of course, a humanitarian crisis, which has ended with everything we have said.  The international community did not recognize last year's May elections and has therefore not recognized Mr Maduro as President of Venezuela as of January 10. Mr. Guaidó, President of the National Assembly, has declared himself president of Venezuela and we have a country in a situation of enormous crisis and volatility.  I am going to start by defending Europe, Mr González Pons. I believe that Europe has established a reasonable criterion, which is preferably to establish an agreement between government and opposition; between the government that has, say, the electoral apparatus and the new president declared under the Constitution, which has 30 days to call elections. An agreement that allows elections to be held with guarantees. And you have set a deadline and told Mr Maduro: if you do not fulfill this purpose, I will recognize Mr Guaido, and you are doing so. And, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow, with the agreement reached by the political groups, this House is going to do so. And the Member States of the European Union will do so in the following days. Yes, they're going to do it. And this is the consequence that a legitimately reasonable development of this situation has not been possible.  Our agreement — which we are going to vote on tomorrow, ladies and gentlemen, all political groups - also includes the rejection of any kind of intervention that may occur from a violent or armed point of view, and I think it is important to highlight this because we must reject and condemn any attempt or proposal involving violence - military escalation, the Commissioner said - or the use of weapons for an alleged solution to the Venezuelan crisis. But also, our group believes that we must give enormous support to the contact group that the European Union is creating. Because this is political, ladies and gentlemen, and the European Union wants to play a role, not exactly like that of the United States — which is its own, I do not dispute it now — but ours is the role of facilitator, mediator, controller, of ensuring that the democratic process and the electoral solution are the only peaceful and democratic solution to the Venezuelan crisis. In any of the scenarios, in any of those that come—that maduro elections be called; that they are called by Guaidó, or not called by anyone—the European Union, with its contact group in the key countries in the region, must continue to establish a peaceful and democratic exit to Venezuela, ladies and gentlemen. It is the European Union's proposal.  Of course we're going to say that Guaidó is president, yes. Are we going to recognize him? Yes. Are we going to help the people of Venezuela and their opposition? Yes, as we have always done; but having the political hand to act on the political stage.  We have long been declaring— the Socialists in particular — that socialism is freedom and that there can be no left against democracy. I would like to reiterate this again here and I want to say it loudly against Mr Maduro, and that is why I would like to reiterate an agreement reached by the political groups to strike this balance between our proposals, so that there may continue to be important political action by the European Union, in order to give a democratic and peaceful way out - I repeat, peacefully - to Venezuela, on the basis of the political action that we Europeans can take.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, with Venezuelan inflation at a staggering 10 million percent, with three million people having fled the country and the security forces under Maduro’s direction employing ever more authoritarian tactics, the recent developments can hardly come as a surprise. I strongly welcome the decision of Juan Guaidó to declare himself interim President and I welcome the recognition that this has received from democratic governments across the globe. The EU’s turn is next. The presidential elections held in May of last year have been wholly discredited, marked by a distinct lack of political pluralism, democracy, transparency and the rule of law, as was highlighted by the High Representative at that time. Such is the strength of opinion across the region that the Secretary General of the OAS, Luis Almagro, has gone further, openly accusing Maduro of perpetrating crimes against humanity and the violation of fundamental human rights, noting that, whilst diplomatic actions should be the first priority, we shouldn’t rule out any action. Diplomatic efforts and dialogue sadly have clearly failed and the recognition of Guaidó is the first step in moving to a more assertive set of actions by international actors. I now welcome the decision of the Bank of England in my country to prevent Venezuela from accessing USD 1.2 billion in reserves held there. I think that the EU should consider mirroring the actions of the US in sanctioning its oil companies, which are being employed by Maduro to buy support from the armed forces. Clearly Venezuela finds itself at a difficult moment and nothing that we must do now must result in an escalation of violence or a military intervention.

name: Javier Nart
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Venezuela is the abyss. It is the social, economic, institutional and national abyss. Hundreds of dead, thousands of prisoners and tortured and more than three million exiles. I remember a phrase from Lenin— I say this to anyone who follows him — who said that exile is a referendum in which you vote with your feet. Well, three million votes for that referendum—according to Lenin, with which I agree as a reference.  Still. Maduro is the de facto power based on fraudulent elections and is only based on the power of brute force, the capacity for repression, supported by the Cuban intelligence system. It is the antipodes of freedom, the antipodes of revolution and the antipodes of an idea that to me is noble and called socialism.  Venezuela's rightful president, the constitutional president, is Juan Guaidó. Just read article 233 of the Constitution: it ceased to be President Maduro when he called an election, ended his deadline and were perfectly fraudulent. Therefore, asking a president who is not president to act as president and, depending on that supposed presidency, calling an election is not only a surrealism worthy of Salvador Dalí: it is simply Marxism, but in the Groucho Marx version. Because throughout that period there have been more than a thousand more prisoners, in the days since elections are asked to those who cannot call them.  So, all the mediations have failed, all that remains is a clear and decisive action by this Parliament, which is what we are going to vote on tomorrow. And we are going to vote on the recognition of the legitimate president of Venezuela, who is Juan Guaidó. We will vote for the maintenance of the recognition of the one Assembly, of the only true popular power, elected in a democratic way, which is the National Assembly of Venezuela. We will also call for the condemning of Maduro's liberticidal regime and demand a full investigation into the crimes carried out by the tyrant.  Consequently, something that is very simple and very dramatic: it is called dignity, democracy, human rights. It's called freedom. And, therefore, from the bottom of my soul to the Venezuelan sister people what I have to tell you is: Long live Venezuela free!

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, like our colleagues from other Groups, we utterly deplore the actions of the Maduro government. Economic mismanagement, the violation of human rights and undermining the rule of law has pushed Venezuela to the brink and led to the exodus of three million citizens. However, in responding we must not abandon key principles of international relations: the right of countries to self-determination and the right of people to choose their own leaders through a fully democratic process. Latin America has a long and tragic history of intervention by foreign players, motivated by self-interest and greed for its resources. Such interests must not be allowed to undermine the integrity of Venezuela or put the security of its citizens at even greater risk. The crisis in Venezuela must be resolved peacefully and this can only be achieved through political dialogue. We support the efforts of High Representative Mogherini to achieve this by working with Latin American leaders to create a contact group which can facilitate a rapid move towards free and fair elections.

name: João Pimenta Lopes
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, the European Union wants to legitimise the coup in Venezuela orchestrated by the United States and the self-proclaiming of a Trump puppet to assault power and control the country's wealth. This is an affront to constitutional order and international law. Is this the EU that legitimised the fraudulent elections in Honduras, which questions the presidential elections in Venezuela? Why did they reject the Venezuelan government's request to participate as observers?  Are the systematic actions of destabilisation, terrorism, speculation and hoarding, increasing economic and financial sanctions, which the EU and several Member States have been fuelling, that will solve the problems of the Venezuelan economy and the difficulties that its people face?  Will the EU seize the threat of imminent military intervention by the United States or embrace the path of peace and dialogue that Mexico and Uruguay have set out to mediate? It is with the suffering and blood of the Venezuelan people that you are playing. Get your hands off Venezuela.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I’ve met Venezuelan citizens, refugees from the Maduro regime, a country which should be prosperous but whose inflation rate is over 100 000%... or 10 million percent because, frankly, you can’t even measure it when it gets to the stage that it’s got. People are literally starving because of food shortages caused by the Maduro government. Millions of people have fled Venezuela. Dissidents are jailed. When 40 people are dead, 800 people seriously injured in protests, when the leader of the opposition is banned from leaving the country and has his assets frozen... this is an unprecedented humanitarian crisis in South America and, quite frankly, all our governments should be working together on this. Left wing, Right wing, Centrists, I don’t care, either you believe in democracy or you don’t believe in democracy. And when Maduro is saying today that they can have presidential elections in 2025, those who side with Maduro are siding with tyrants and dictatorship. And it is a source of shame for the UK, Mr President, that I see the Shadow Chancellor in the UK signing a letter speaking out against regime change in Venezuela. That Jeremy Corbyn, who has many times hailed Venezuela as a beacon of socialism, does nothing and leaves his previous support for that regime unchallenged. The international community really should be united on this. I’ll finish, Mr President, in Spanish. Maduro no es un presidente legítimo: es un tirano; y hay que cambiar el régimen en Venezuela. Ingleses, españoles, americanos, europeos, debemos todos reconocer la verdad. La solución es la democracia.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, I do not like Mr Maduro and I am fighting these regimes, but either you are for the rule of law or you are for the coup d'etat, you have to choose. One thing is certain, the approach of the President of the National Assembly, Juan Guaid, is illegal. Article 233 of Venezuela's Constitution provides for five cases that constitute impediments to the exercise of the presidential office: death, resignation, physical incapacity, impeachment and abandonment of office. None of these conditions have been met. Second, the president can only be impeached by referendum, not by the National Assembly. The guarantor of the Constitution is the Supreme Court of Justice, before which Mr Maduro has just been sworn in. He is constitutionally the president. Moreover, in the event of a vacancy, it is not the President of the National Assembly who replaces him, but the Vice-President. Juan Guaida was not a candidate in the May 2018 presidential elections. He's a stranger in politics. In the name of what mythical political support and rule of law would he now be the legitimate president? Tell me! In this confusion, there is only one legitimacy: elections. I'll...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Mr President, we denounce the brutal intervention of the United States of the European Union, NATO, Latin American governments in the interior of Venezuela and their attempt to impose a puppet president in a coup d'état. And there they threaten military intervention to promote their dangerous plans, as they do everywhere internationally. We denounce the attitude of governments such as Germany, Spain and Portugal. As for the Greek government, it makes no sound about the United States' intervention in Venezuela and claims that the European Union is supposedly unable to have its own foreign policy, while it is the European Union that does not recognise President Maduro and provocatively threatens ultimatums. Only the Venezuelan people have a responsibility to defend their interests and elect the leadership of their country. We express our solidarity with the Venezuelan people, who are experiencing the capitalist crisis and exploitation. We support the Venezuelan Communist Party in its battle for the rights of the working class, for the people to live without exploitation and ... (The President removes the floor from the speaker.)

name: President. –
text: These are the issues and the moments where I regret that, as the Chair, I cannot intervene on substance, but unfortunately I can’t, although I would love to.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank colleagues for their really useful and bold interventions. As I said in my first intervention, the EU strategy will continue to be multifaceted and encompass both elements of pressure, but also a political channel through which we can contribute to a peaceful and democratic solution. We will continue to use all the instruments in the EU’s toolbox to accompany the country towards a peaceful and negotiated solution. It is a difficult journey, but it is the only way that can foster a democratic and sustainable solution to the country’s ills. Of course, Venezuelans – both in Venezuela and abroad, where millions have sought refuge – will continue to be our key concern, and we will continue our efforts to help address their needs. Democracy is about all. I would like to close by signalling once again my appreciation for your support, for your role, in keeping this important issue on the international agenda and, as always, the Commission relies on your efforts and support in order to see democracy in Venezuela.

name: President. –
text: Thank you Commissioner. I must say that, for a Chair of the plenary, it is a pleasure to chair such a debate, which shows such a broad consensus. I must say that it is a very pleasant feeling. it is not always that the Chair has the possibility to experience the alignment that the Commissioner has spoken about. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow.  Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – I express deep concerns about the unprecedented social, economic and democratic crisis which Venezuelan citizens are currently facing, and I strongly condemn the disproportionate and extraordinarily violent response of the Maduro Government towards social protesters and opposition activists. As the legitimacy of the May 2018 presidential elections was not recognised by many international democracies, including the European Union, I find it feasible to support new elections in the region as soon as possible and ensure that the electoral process will be held in line with international standards, the rule of law, democracy, political pluralism and transparency. In this context, it is of paramount importance that the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Madame Federica Mogherini, hasten the collaboration with all relevant actors in order to establish the International Contact Group stated in the Council conclusions of 15 October 2018. I stress that, once created, this Group should under no circumstances provide direct mediation between the Venezuelan parties but ensure the conditions for a legitimate electoral process and enable Venezuelan citizens to choose their own future and stabilise their country.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Venezuelans have suffered for too long from humanitarian, political, economic and social crises and urgently need a government that represents the will of the people that can find solutions. Juan Guaidó has a democratic mandate, Maduro does not. The recognition of Guaidó as interim President of Venezuela by the European Parliament will be an important step in helping to solve the crisis peacefully and democratically, but we need a strong and united position on behalf of the EU as a whole if we want to remain credible defenders of human rights and democracy. I therefore call on all EU members to also recognise Juan Guaidó. Another next logical step for the EU should be to make the targeted sanctions in place more effective in pressuring the regime; that is, by extending these sanctions to include close family members of those sanctioned and to the state-owned oil firm PDVSA. It would be a mistake for the EU to just leave the sanctions as they are now and wait passively while the situation worsens before deciding to take further action. The EU cannot fall behind on its values and principles in Venezuela.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. – I believe that Venezuela needs the restoration of democracy and the rule of law through a credible political process, as the elections held on 20 May 2018 were not implemented in accordance with minimum international standards for ensuring a credible process and political pluralism, democracy, transparency and the rule of law were not respected during these elections.  On 10 January 2019, Nicolás Maduro illegitimately appropriated presidential powers before the Supreme Court, a violation of the constitutional order. The EU, together with other democratic countries and regional organisations, has recognised neither these elections nor the authorities set out in this illegitimate procedure. Furthermore, I strongly condemn the violence that leads to the killings and wounding during this emergency in the country and I believe that the Venezuelan authorities should put an end to all human rights violations and hold the perpetrators accountable. All this is mentioned in this motion of resolution, which I supported, because it recognises Juan Guaidó as the legitimate interim president of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in accordance with Article 233 TE. Venezuela's constitution.  This document also asks the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to take a firm stance together with the EU Member States and also recognise Juan Guaidó as the only legitimate interim President by the time new elections can be called.

name: David McAllister (PPE)
text: Writing. – Venezuela is currently experiencing a conflict of pioneering international relevance. It is about nothing less than the question of 'freedom or despotism?' Russia, Iran, China, and Cuba – behind Maduro are authoritarian powers that reject and fight our liberal world order. In Venezuela, it is once again clear that without minimum democratic standards, there can and will not be lasting stability in any country. Caracas must now consistently follow the path of change. This can only be done through free, transparent and credible presidential elections that comply with international standards and the national constitution. If Mr Maduro does not immediately clear the way for new elections, the Member States should immediately recognise Juan Guaida as interim president. Tomorrow, EU foreign ministers will discuss the situation in Venezuela in Bucharest. As chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I will attend the meeting and present the clear message from the European Parliament, which stems from today's debate and from our resolution.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – Throughout this mandate, Parliament has repeatedly addressed the political situation in Venezuela. Resolutions called for dialogue and respect for democracy have been adopted. There was dismay at the social and humanitarian catastrophe that the political crisis has generated, causing hundreds of thousands of citizens to escape and severe lack of access to basic products for those who remain in the country. Calls were made to respect the rules of democratic transparency and sanctions were adopted to signal the unacceptable character of the distorted model of recognition of the popular vote. The political situation in Venezuela has reached a red line that can only democratically be resolved. Resolved through the immediate call by the Government in functions of free and internationally supervised elections, or, if not done, creating the conditions for the National Assembly to take into its hands the fates of the country and call these elections. Venezuela needs the people to democratically choose their destiny and the European Union, out of respect for their values, must continue to do so to make that happen.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the latest developments in the cross-strait relations between China and Taiwan (2019/2529(RSP)).

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, since the beginning of the year, tensions between mainland China and Taiwan have risen again after leaders from both Beijing and Taipei restated their positions on this issue. We Europeans have immediately confirmed where we stand: we want to encourage dialogue between mainland China and Taiwan, and we regret that cross-strait relations have remained frozen in the past two years. We maintain our ‘One China’ policy. This means that we recognise the government of the People’s Republic of China as the sole legal government of China, but at the same time, we have an interest in developing closer relations with Taiwan. Our cooperation and dialogue with Taiwan are getting more intense on a broad range of issues – and this is because we very much respect Taiwan’s system of governance. It is a system based on democracy, the rule of law and human rights. In many ways, the European Union and Taiwan are like—minded. So we have always encouraged Taiwan to be an active player in international affairs. In short, we do engage with Taiwan even in the lack of diplomatic recognition. We Europeans have a strong interest in peace and security in Asia. We are very distant geographically, but we know that tensions in the Far East can only have a negative impact on our own security, as well as on our trade and our economies. Also for this reason, we keep following closely all developments around the Taiwan Strait. In recent years, both sides have taken a tougher stance on the possibility of a cross-strait rapprochement. Beijing has cut high-level channels of communication. Since 2016, China has increased the diplomatic pressure on Taiwan to limit further its international space and to convince Taipei’s diplomatic allies to switch recognition to Beijing. On their side, Taipei’s leaders have explicitly refused the formula of ‘one country, two systems’. At the same time, economic and trade relations between the two sides have been flourishing – and mainland China is now Taiwan’s main investment destination and trading partner. Against this backdrop, we Europeans have asked both sides to avoid actions and words that may increase tensions around the Strait. We have always encouraged mainland China and Taiwan to engage constructively with one another, and to restart dialogue between them. We are willing to support all initiatives aimed at promoting dialogue, cooperation and confidence-building between the two sides. I am really glad for the European Parliament’s focus on this issue and for this debate. We should take all opportunities to promote a more positive dynamic between mainland China and Taiwan, while also seeking closer cooperation with Taiwan where our interests and values converge.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, relations between Taiwan and China have never been easy, and the peace has been guaranteed due to enormous diplomatic efforts by Taiwan to defend its self-rule, democracy and way of life. Recently, Chinese President, Xi Jinping, said that China reserves the right to use force to bring Taiwan under its control. Even though President Xi mentioned that China would strive to achieve peaceful reunification with the island, this is a very worrying tendency. This statement clearly implies a new era in China-Taiwan relations. The statement that Taiwan is part of China and that people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should seek reunification under the 1992 consensus is clearly out of date. As we know, Taiwan’s President Tsai promptly rejected the one country, two systems principle as a basis for negotiations. Madam President has a very strong argument. Seventy-five per cent of Taiwanese people refused to accept the 1992 consensus. The clear wish and the right of the Taiwanese people to live in freedom and democracy must be respected. China must face the reality of the existence of the Republic of Taiwan and handle cross-trade disputes peacefully on the basis of equality and non-conditionality. On the other hand, the EU must express its strong opposition to the use of force to settle cross-trade disputes as it undermines peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the Asia Pacific region and our message is very … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jo Leinen
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The Socialist Group is committed to the one-China policy. That is the leitmotif that we have pursued over the years and continue to pursue. At the same time, however, there is great sympathy for Taiwan in this House and also in our country – firstly because of the functioning of democracy in this region and, of course, because of the country's integration into the world economy because of the market economy that prevails in Taiwan. Parliament has repeatedly called for the conflict between Mainland and Taiwan to be resolved through peaceful dialogue, cooperation and confidence-building measures. This continues to be the case. I believe that there is no military solution, only a political solution – through all these forms of dialogue, which lead to closer cooperation. Many have been alarmed by President Xi Jinping's speech that China would also be willing to use force. However, one should also read the speech carefully. It says at the beginning of this chapter: "Chinese people do not fight Chinese people." That has also been said, and in the diction, therefore, measures against external intervention are envisaged. We know what is being talked about, namely that Taiwan is being used as a pawn in the conflict between the United States and China. I do not believe that this would also be in Europe's interest. Xi Jinping said "one country, two systems." That is nice to say, but there are completely different political systems, and they are moving away from each other rather than towards each other. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – On the second day of this new year, the presidents of China and Taiwan set off verbal fireworks. In order for it to remain in the cold fire, the EU must use all its resources to maintain the status quo in relations between Beijing and Taipei. A combination of domestic problems for China's political elite led President Xi Jinping to show strong leadership on January 2 in connection with the well-known nationalist trauma known as Taiwan.  Meanwhile, the danger of escalation lurks, from increasing Chinese military pressure on Taiwan. There's evidence of that. Western and regional counter-pressure is really needed here. Contrary to what President Xi believes - he says that the Taiwanese issue is an internal matter - democracy, human rights and the rule of law are not only at stake for Taiwan's 23 million inhabitants. No, three core political values of the EU are at stake here at the same time. Also at stake with us! That is why we must make every effort towards Beijing, to make it clear where we stand, and also to Taipei, to support Taipei.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, according to international law, one can argue that the Republic of China (ROC), often referred to as Taiwan, has never been part of the so-called People’s Republic of China (PRC), often referred to as China or mainland China. This would mean that PRC claims that it has sovereignty over Taiwan are invalid. That could be said.  However, both the PRC and the ROC have maintained a status quo. That status quo has made it possible to have cross—strait relations and has secured peace in the region, so I’m for that status quo. The status quo has been broken by China’s leaders. Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, said on 2 January 2019 that the use of military force is an option for the so—called reunification of Taiwan with the motherland. Other pressures include economic and political sanctions and isolation.  ALDE does not accept the use of military force, or the threat of the use of military force, and other blackmail. The Taiwanese people should be able to determine their future. The EU, together with the United States, should protect Taiwan and its democracy. China should know that the use of force, the threat of the use of force and other pressure will have serious consequences for China itself.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the China's Taiwan policy is changing, it is becoming more aggressive. That is what President Xi Jinping has said. His threat of military force is wrong. But we also make the issue of China putting pressure on Taiwan at very different levels: economic pressure, pressure at the diplomatic level by buying Taiwan away from its partners, and, above all, the militarisation and armament in the Taiwan Strait, which concerns us.  According to our one-China policy, only a peaceful future on both sides of the Taiwan Strait is acceptable. That is why we stand in solidarity with democratic Taiwan.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the On foreign policy towards China, the EU has a very clear common position: the one-China policy. Article 2(5) of the Lisbon Treaty states that the Union contributes to peace, respect for one another among peoples and respect for international law. There is nothing to sow discord, neither in China nor in the Caribbean. No one should love the sound of sabre-rattling, not here, not in the Caribbean, nor in the Strait of Taiwan.  Domestic conflicts in all their complexity must not be exploited. That would be the Trump method. Our commitment is to promote dialogue and to find solutions. It depends on the correct order. We must talk to each other, we must promote dialogue, we must enforce the complex issues, including the questions of sovereignty and the right to self-determination at international law. First of all, let us agree from the EU side on an investment or even trade agreement with the People's Republic of China, after which a ...  (The speaker spoke without a microphone)

name: President. –
text: Once again, for those who came late, we have a time problem. We have a delay, we have changed the programme and I will only have catch—the—eye on this item with a maximum of three for one political group, and then no catch—the—eye for the following debates. I have no other option. My apologies for that.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, since 1949, when the civil war in China ended, China regards Taiwan as Chinese territory, which must return to the country as Hong Kong and Macau have returned. But because Taiwan wants to become independent, there are constant frictions between these two countries. With both countries, the European Union has good relations, both commercial and, above all, of a different nature. That is why, in this conflict, the European Union must look to serve its political and economic interests. When it considers that it should coincide with China, it should support the doctrine of a single China. However, when it considers that its interests are served by cooperation with Taiwan, it must cooperate with Taiwan.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Mr President, there is something terrible in Xi Jinping's speech because it is basically a communist regime that wants to intimidate its democratic neighbours by invoking the use of force. It is clear that the Beijing authorities misinterpreted the results of Taiwan's local elections last November, because at no point in the election campaign was the issue of reunification with China addressed. Let's get to the bottom of this: the Taiwanese did not send a message to Xi Jinping, they spoke on local issues and an overwhelming majority of them are vehemently opposed to the idea of a country and two systems. What Taiwanese want above all else is to protect their democracy, their rule of law, their freedom. That is to say all these things that remain unknown to the communist regime, which makes itself famous instead with arrests of rights defenders, religious persecutions, attacks on freedom of expression and all this, of course, under the guise of national security and a so-called fight against separatism. In view of the growing tensions in the Taiwan Strait, I propose that a delegation from the European Parliament go to Taiwan as soon as possible to take stock of the situation and support Taiwanese democracy.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, relations already strained between China and Taiwan have been rapidly soured in recent times. Chinese President Xi Jinping reiterated that the island must be reunited with China, in compliance with the One-China Policy decision, not excluding the use of force if necessary, and the Defense Minister kicked off a military exercise in a swath of the East China Sea, designed to simulate real combat.  Further complicating matters is the side offered in Taipei by Trump's United States, which has also been in contact with Taiwan for military supplies. The situation is not easy, both because of the geographical distance and the weight of the interests at stake. But a peaceful reunification of China is in everyone's interest.  The international role of the European Union is not yet as desired and the need is felt, especially in an increasingly conflictual world. We must use the good relations we have with China, but also with Taiwan, to reach a high-profile negotiated solution.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am concerned, and I think we should all be concerned, at the growing tensions in the cross-strait relations between China and Taiwan. We need to call for a diffusion of the tension that came after the speech of Chinese leader Xi Jinping earlier this year. It must be clear that we have an interest in keeping peace and stability in the region. This should lead to our support for handling any disputes peacefully by diplomatic means with constructive dialogue and direct talks between the two partners.  It should be clear that the EU does not believe that any coercive means should be used in addressing the current tensions, especially when it comes to security and the social and economic system chosen by Taiwan. In this context, imposing the question of reunification on Taiwan is very dangerous. I think it is in our interest to call on both partners to find a way to intensify their dialogue in order to appease the situation. We should also underline the values which we share with Taiwan and be supportive in its contribution to the region. I would also like to call on the High Representative, Ms Mogherini, to use all our diplomatic means to assist in sustaining peace and stability in the region.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, China's credibility is based on its global influence, but also by the fears it inspires in its own region in the South Seas. Taiwan is a democracy and chose for President Tsai Ing-wen of a party tempted to declare the island's independence to preserve the rule of law and democracy that obviously do not exist in China. With the threat of strength and dollar diplomacy, Xi Jinping wants to show Taiwan that renouncing the consensus that there is only one China is forbidden and paid for by crushing. But Chinese reunification can only be achieved if the Taiwanese want it if they vote democratically. An armed conflict would destroy China's legitimacy and influence globally. Military provocations, which endanger peace and security in the Taiwan Strait, must be stopped. You have to bet on dialogue. Disputes must be resolved by peaceful means on the basis of international law, in particular by a permanent member of the UN Security Council, such as China. It can't be any other way. Or China will have lost Taiwan long before it even tried to integrate...  (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker).)

name: Christophe Hansen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, on 30 December 2018, the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) entered into force, creating an immense trading area between 11 South—East Asia and Pacific countries, covering half a billion people. It is economically and strategically of the utmost importance for the EU to deepen its relations with this rapidly integrating and developing region. In December last year, we ratified the EU-Japan Economic and Strategic Partnership Agreements. Last week in the Committee on International Trade (INTA) we ratified the Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA) and the Vietnam FTA will be next. Negotiations are underway with Australia and New Zealand.  Yet there is one persistent blind spot in our engagement with South—East Asia. It is Taiwan, especially in the light that Taiwan is hindered by China from joining the CPTPP. In 2018, we celebrated 30 years of bilateral relations. The EU is Taiwan’s single largest foreign investor with 43%, whereas Taiwan’s investments in the EU amount to only 1.9%. Deepening our economic ties is our most efficient approach to supporting Taiwanese freedom and democracy. Waiting for an investment treaty with China is waiting for Godot. It is time to move forward.  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Werner Langen (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the As chairman of the Friendship Group, I would like to thank my colleagues who are fighting for democratic Taiwan. And I would like to agree with Mr Bütikofer: the one-China policy since 1992 can only be held responsible in a completely peaceful environment. And I am astonished that the chairman of the China delegation, Mr Leinen, who is now gone, is pretending that this was just a statement. No! It was a highly political declaration made by President Xi not alone, but in the presence of the entire leadership, with the threat of military force. And if this kind of threat continues, then there can only be one answer for the European Union: we must recognise Taiwan diplomatically! China will not understand any other language. And we must help Taiwan so that the Chinese, with their means of pressure, do not throw the Taiwanese out of international treaties and negotiations.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Taiwan is a reliably functioning democracy in East Asia. It is not a problem, not for Beijing, not for the outside world. The problem is that mainland China, whose goal is the complete unification of Taiwan, remains a communist dictatorship which is responsible for the annihilation of tens of millions of its own citizens, and which continues to repress civil rights, minorities and individual freedoms. The Chinese president’s warning that Beijing is not promising to renounce the use of force is ominous and deserves firm international reaction. We have to clearly support the democratic choice of 23 million Taiwanese. They have proved for decades what a free society can achieve. Before insisting on reunification, mainland China must reform itself into a democratic society which is finally willing and can respect the free choice of all its citizens.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, under the leadership of Xi Jinping, the Chinese government has been increasing pressure on Taiwan on all fronts, undermining the status quo of the Formosa Strait and jeopardizing peace and stability in the region.  For years, intimidating pressures range from blocking Taiwan's participation as an observer in international organizations to intensifying military intimidation, sending troops and sending frigates, and aircraft carriers, to the Taiwan Strait to patrol along it. Not forgetting that China reserves the use of force for reunification.  But Taiwan is a democracy. Look what President Tsai says: a liberal democratic order can survive only if like-minded countries, including European partners, work together for the greater good. That is why the European Union must become more engaged and support democracy in Taiwan.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Beijing increasingly tries to isolate Formosa globally and has signalled for years that it wants Taiwan to be reunited with the mainland, by force if necessary. Taiwanese anti-invasion exercises and Chinese patrol flights are regular occurrences in the Taiwan Strait. China’s intensifying political and economic pressure campaigns are also aimed at pushing Taiwan back towards a more China-friendly government in its 2020 presidential election. Although the European Union sticks to the principle of ‘One China’ – which I think is wrong – that doesn’t mean that we are any less engaged with Taiwan, a more-than-open and tolerant democracy and an important economic partner of the EU. The European Union must appeal for moderation on both sides of the conflict, firmly opposed to the use or threat of force across the Taiwan Strait, and urge China to abstain from any coercion that would jeopardise the security of the social-economic system of the people of Taiwan.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I wanted to thank you very much for your voice and I will say right away that if I had known the speeches of my colleagues Langen, Kukana or Preda before, I probably wouldn't have performed. I would like to sign their opinion, adding only two things. Firstly, I would like to draw attention to the fact that Taiwan has done a great deal, really much, to improve relations with the People's Republic of China, and the People's Republic of China should appreciate this, respect it and not treat Taiwan as a territory that needs to be appropriated. Secondly, I draw attention to the achievements of Taiwan itself – not only the one we have already talked about, but also the technological and cultural acquis. The respect expressed in this Chamber for Taiwan is truly valuable.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, China considers Taiwan to be part of it. As I have come to know Taiwan and its political representation, I see it as a successor to the interwar Republic of China and part of Chinese civilization and culture, but not as part of the PRC. In particular, because, unlike the PRC, it develops democracy and economic prosperity based on a market economy. This year, Chinese President Xi Jinping spoke very aggressively about taiwan's possible military connection to the PRC. That's intimidation from a position of strength, and it's not acting from a position of law. I believe that Taiwan is an example of a functioning democracy that protects the same values as the EU and deserves our full support and recognition, as my colleagues have already mentioned here. I expect the EP to support Taiwan. The EU should not only continue to rely on the US, but must begin to fulfil its international role.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, to understand Xi Jinping’s New Year message to compatriots in Taiwan on 2 January, one has to look both at context and content to understand that these words mean to lay down a new Taiwan policy implying a new era in China-Taiwan relations. As regards the staging, in a clear departure from the 2009 speech by President Hu Jintao, the Head of the Taiwan Affairs Office was conspicuously absent from the stage. In terms of content, Xi Jinping effectively removed the ambiguity of the ‘One China’ principle of the 1992 consensus, using the ‘One country, two system’ governance term, the same one that he used for China’s governance of Hong Kong. However, we should bear in mind that Taiwan’s President Chi had never accepted the terms of the 1992 Consensus. China must face the reality of the existence of the Republic of Taiwan. China must respect the choice of Taiwan’s 23 million inhabitants to live in freedom and in a democratic system. China must handle cross-strait disputes peacefully and on the basis of equality. China must hold government-to-government talks with … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the fact that the Chinese President, Xi Jinping, when delivering a speech on China—Taiwan relations, refuses to rule out the use of force and reserves the option of taking all necessary measures to push the ‘One China’ principle must be a matter of concern to all of us. Since there is so much at stake in settling their political disputes, the two sides should take a pragmatic approach. We from the EU should encourage the resumption of official dialogues between Beijing and Taipei. All cross—strait disputes have to be settled by peaceful means and on the basis of international law and the principle of equality. At the same time, I strongly believe that the commitment of the Taiwanese people to freedom and democracy and towards the democratic system that they have tenaciously built together must be respected and taken into account.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this has been a very useful exchange and I thank my dear colleagues for their interventions. From this debate I conclude that we all maintain the EU’s ‘One China’ policy and, at the same time, we share the common commitment to continuing to develop our relations with Taiwan, as defined by the EU Strategy on China of 2016. In this regard, we definitely need to foster our engagement to make sure the status quo remains the norm in the Taiwan Strait. May I close by stressing my appreciation of Parliament’s role in putting this important issue on the international agenda of the EU.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. I will utilise the half-minute before Commissioner Malmström takes her seat in the front row just to once again reiterate that, for time reasons, there will be no catch—the—eye in the following debate or in any other during this evening. My apologies, but it is not my preference. That’s reality. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I observe with great concern the harassing rhetoric and hostile steps taken by communist Beijing towards the Republic of China (Taiwan). A year ago, at the SEDE meeting, we discussed the dangers of changing air corridors in the Taiwan Strait and military expansion in the South China Sea region. Recent words about the possibility of using force to force "unification" uttered by The President of the People's Republic of China Xi Jinping raise further concerns.  I am convinced that Beijing's pressure on taiwan isolation on many levels will not be effective. The West and Taiwan have much more in common than just trade relations. We Poles are well aware that the people of Taiwan, despite some historical and cultural ties to mainland China, do not want to live in a communist, totalitarian state. I therefore call on the High Representative to be more active. The free world must not succumb to the pressures of the strong, forgetting the values.

name: Andrey Kovatchev (PPE)
text: in writing. – I would like to call for a peaceful solution to the recently increased tension in the cross-strait relations between China and Taiwan. The preservation of the status quo between these two actors is of utmost importance for safeguarding the security and stability of the region. According to recent polls, 75% of the people living in Taiwan reject Beijing’s view of ‘1992 consensus’. Disregarding their beliefs will constitute an obstruction of democracy. Moreover, China’s intention, expressed recently by President Xi Jinping, to impose a ‘one country, two systems’ model on Taiwan sends a strong signal, given how the implementation of this formula has been politically challenging in Hong Kong. Any statement which could lead to an escalation of tensions should be avoided at all costs as this would not be in the interest of the people of the region. Respect for each other and constructive dialogue are the only way to a sustainable solution of disputes.

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – Like many others here, I am concerned as to the state of cross-state relations between China and Taiwan. The current situation is both concerning and unnecessary and I believe all parties should seek to resolve any differences through peaceful means, on the basis of international law, and to refrain from taking unilateral action to change the status quo. Above all that means China putting an end to its military actions in the Taiwan Strait. To that end, I fully support Taiwan’s meaningful participation in relevant international organisations and a resumption of official dialogue between Beijing and Taipei, both of which are in the best interests of all concerned. Numerous European Parliament resolutions have stressed the preservation of peace, stability and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region, which is of substantial interest to the EU and its Member States, and for that reason I urge the EU to continue its efforts to support the development of peaceful relations between China and all its neighbours, notably Taiwan.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the state of the US—EU trade negotiations (2019/2530(RSP)).

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission is always at the disposal of Parliament even if the timing of this debate has been a challenge. With the adoption of the joint statement from last July by President Juncker and President Trump, we entered into a new stage in our relationship with the US, our first investment and trade partner, and we identified a focused and positive trade agenda. Since then, I have met with my American counterparts many times in an effort to implement the joint programme that we identified last summer. We have identified future avenues on voluntary cooperation with the US and a number of regulatory sectors of major economic importance, such as pharmaceuticals, medical devices and cybersecurity, and the progress achieved so far has been reflected in a public report that we released this morning and is available for all of you to read. We will continue to engage with the US in order to respond to the global challenges, notably the WTO reform and the need to update rules to respond to the challenges posed by state capitalism.  Trends: trade in liquefied natural gas and soya beans are developing in line with expectations expressed in the July joint statement and have contributed to EU energy security and provided our farmers with protein at competitive prices. Two weeks ago, the Commission adopted two recommendations for opening negotiations, one on industrial tariffs and one on conformity assessment. The one on industrial tariffs is quite self—explanatory and it does not include agriculture, as agreed in July. The proposed mandate on conformity assessment maybe deserves a little explanation.  Both the EU and the US have in their respective practices of conformity assessment the purpose to ensure that manufacturers can only place a product on the market when it meets all the applicable requirements to ensure that unsafe or otherwise non—compliant products do not find their way to unsuspecting consumers. In some cases this requires mandatory third-party certification. Differences in approaches to conformity assessment can result in significant additional costs without improving the safety of the products. So our aim with this recommendation for negotiations on conformity assessment is to reduce the unnecessary costs while making sure that we fully maintain our respective levels of protection. The two recommendations thereby fulfilled the commitment that we took in July. They recognise that progress with the Trump administration is at this stage only possible with individual projects agreed on both sides. So I believe that the various strands of work we have initiated together through this process since July will add to a significant agenda with benefits from both sides. We can make every effort to project a positive trade agenda with the US on its own merits and also it is important not to fall back into a destructive cycle of trade restrictive measures and counter actions. At the same time, we must be very clear that any thought of going beyond the joint statement and negotiating a comprehensive and all encompassing trade agreement with the US is neither feasible nor advisable at this time. The US is also not ready to negotiate on its sensitivities, such as public procurement by American maritime services, or geographical indications.  In addition, one of the important lessons that we have learnt during the TTIP negotiation is that the regulatory agenda with the US is best developed in full transparency, but outside the context of FTA negotiations. Furthermore, there are differences in some important trade-related rule areas where opposition will be very difficult to bridge.  So our efforts are more likely to bear fruit if we seek to cooperate with the US in reforming certain multilateral trade rules that are ripe for an update. We are of course remaining vigilant and we will be ready to respond firmly in case the US would no longer respect commitments given in July and would adopt further restrictive measures vis—à—vis the EU, but this scenario would not be of our choosing.  I’m looking forward to the debate.

name: President. –
text: Once again, for those who came later, I am afraid that for time reasons there will be no catch—the—eye either in this debate, or in any other to follow.

name: Christophe Hansen
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, John F Kennedy once said that we cannot negotiate with people who say ‘what’s mine is mine and what’s yours is negotiable’. Donald Trump seems to disagree, judging by the American negotiating mandate. Its objective is to reduce the US trade deficit, contrary to the usual win—win approach. From the continued push to include agriculture products to downright hostility on the protection of geographic indications, the American negotiating objectives at times seem geometrically opposed to what Presidents Juncker and Trump agreed on in July last year. Nevertheless, we should not forget that, while we are talking, we are not escalating the trade war. President Juncker stopped the devastating downward spiral of tariff upon tariff. Our negotiators should be ambitious yet stay within the confines of the joint statement. That means categorically that agriculture cannot be up for discussion. But with 50 million jobs depending on transatlantic trade, it also means that we shouldn’t be afraid to explore a positive agenda in lowering tariffs for industrial goods and facilitation of conformity assessments. Let’s put this conflict to bed once and for all and demonstrate that cooperation is still the best way to shore up the international rules-based trade order. As the same Kennedy once said, we should never negotiate out of fear, but let us never fear to negotiate.

name: Maria Arena
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, Commissioner, I will never understand your stubbornness to open negotiations with the Trump administration. In 2018, when Donald Trump decided to apply illegal tariffs on European steel and aluminum, you were saying, I quote, "I will never negotiate under threat." Yet these tariffs are still a threat to European products. The threat is not lifted and you are entering into a negotiating proposal, which you make to the Council. As Donald Trump challenges the multilateralism to which we are so attached at European level, you decide again to start negotiations with the Trump administration. Is that not to accept the bilateral logic imposed by the United States at the moment? On climate, the United States remains climate sceptic, rejecting COP21 commitments. Negotiating within this framework would be to deny the climate emergency to which we, as Europeans, are particularly attached. And finally, when we compare the limited offer you make in the negotiations and the extensive and offensive offer that the U.S. administration is making, one wonders what the commonality will be, the point that you will be able to share with the United States in these negotiations. And so, for us, it seems that the opening of these negotiations is a tactical error, a political error, and we hope that the Council will not accept the mandate that you have proposed to it.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, some of us expected this debate, along with the resolution, in March, but here we are. Quite sadly, we could actually be having a debate about EU-US trade relations on almost a weekly basis if we look at what is going on these days. A truce was reached last summer, but the illegitimate US steel and aluminium tariffs remain and the Trump administration continues to block the appointment of judges on the World Trade Organisation (WTO) appellate body. Only this week, President Trump threatened the EU if it does not follow the US on banning trade with Iran.  It is important that we stay on our own course and continue to move forward with rules- and values-based trade agendas and plans. Working together with like-minded partners like Canada, New Zealand, Japan or Australia, we continue to raise the bar to protect rights, the environment, to instil high standards and principles and new sets of rules for trade in the digital age. I welcome the initiative launched last week on e-commerce at the WTO. I call on all those allies in the US to join our ongoing work to strengthen and reinforce the multilateral trade system. There are many.  In the meantime, in the dealings with US administration, I support your work, Commissioner, in bringing forward focused trade talks with the US on the removal of tariffs on industrial goods, but not on agricultural products, and on the mentioned conformity assessment. It is not ideal, but it is the best option for now and it is certainly important to keep the dialogue going.

name: Yannick Jadot
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Commissioner, you have an incredible capacity this evening to tell us a fairy tale. After months of discussions on reviving these negotiations, we finally come to say that this is a free trade agreement that we are having with the United States. But above all, for months too, the European leaders, the European Parliament, yourself, you have said, and fortunately: there is no question of negotiating with a revolver on your head. Where did you see that Donald Trump pulled his finger off the trigger? On steel as well as on the automobile, he continues to threaten us. It continues to threaten the international multilateral order. And then you tell us: we were the good students of the July declaration. Well done! We import a lot more shale oil and gas. Well done! We have doubled our imports of American GM soybeans in six months, because we are very good students. Then, as with Canada, and that is where you, the European Commission, take out your magic wand, you are able to transform the fuel quality directive. With Canada, it was on oil sands fuels, and that is soybeans. You manage to kill European climate regulations. So, frankly, negotiating with Trump, negotiating under these conditions, negotiating against the climate, against our food sovereignty, it's nonsense, it has to stop!

name: Emma McClarkin
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, thank you for your support for rugby. I do hope you will come and support my rugby union World Cup event that I’m hosting on 19 February. But dear colleagues, we are here to discuss something very important. The ECR strongly advocates free trade with all of our trading partners, not least our largest trading partner, the United States. And we supported the TTIP negotiations, and our preference is always to negotiate comprehensive free trade agreements that liberalise trade in goods, services and procurement. Nonetheless, given the current circumstances with global trade tensions, I welcomed the July EU-US agreement not to impose further tariffs on each, whilst both sides scope out the room for negotiation. And the ECR continues to support the Commission’s action to begin negotiations with the US. Having two separate agreements with the US – one on tariffs on industrial products and another on conformity assessments – provides a clear structure to negotiations. On the industrial tariffs negotiations, it is particularly welcome news that the Commission’s mandate for negotiations includes auto products, owing not least to the reciprocal interests of exporters on both sides of the Atlantic but also to ensure the compatibility of any agreement with GATT. On conformity assessments measures, the duplication of procedures to demonstrate conformity is a significant trade barrier to SME exports in both the US and the EU, and we must look at this. I would add that one crucial condition for these negotiations is that they cannot be successfully concluded without the tariffs on steel and aluminium being removed.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, you are in favour of fair and ethical trade. You told us you were not negotiating with a revolver on your head. Trump hasn't taken anything back. Europe's steel, aluminium and car industries remain under threat, and the strengthening of multilateral world trade remains somewhere in the fog. You have submitted a draft mandate to the Council which is either unrealistic or dishonest. You will not be able to enforce the demands and red lines. Trump will not commit to waiving punitive tariffs for the future. The US will continue to push for the entry of agricultural goods into this agreement, because that is the core of the current fast-track mandate of Congress. Contrary to your claim that you are refusing to do so, you have already made the United States the largest supplier of soya in Europe over the last eight months: 77% market share. Before the Juncker-Trump deal, it was 9%. They are also preparing a special law to bring American gene soya into European biodiesel production. For our companies, competition is about fair production conditions, costs for environmental protection and decent jobs.

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, five years ago I began my term of office in the European Parliament with a question: why are TTIP documents secret? Today there is a new TTIP on the horizon but this time the documents are not secret. No, this time a more devious strategy was adopted, because the documents made them public immediately but they are white, they are practically white: a page and no details for what is the negotiating mandate between the two largest economies in the world.  In words, you say that the new agreement will not affect agriculture, that it will not bring in GMOs, meat with hormones and that the industry will be limited. But what is the evidence we have? We have your fine words and then we have two negotiating mandates so general that it is as if they are blank: it will forgive me if I do not feel very reassured. Who knows, perhaps it is also because a few months ago you said that you did not want to negotiate under the threat of American tariffs, but now you are doing just that.  Of course, you have obviously decided to reward their calm and constructive attitude. But the Americans continue to throb our industry with tariffs on steel: they have formally asked for subsidies to be cut for our farmers; they forced us to buy their soybeans and now they have also threatened further duties on made in Europe cars. So, the famous gun to the temple is always well pointed. But you want to sit at a table with them. I have read their demands: they could not be more incompatible with us. They want free access to our agriculture, they want every product approved by them to be authorised by us, they want to enter our public procurement without allowing us to invest in theirs.  We are not there in this way and we will not be there until America shows goodwill and stops blackmailing us. Today, as in the last, it is no to TTIP.

name: France Jamet
text: on behalf of the ENF group. "Mr President, Mrs Malmstrom, ladies and gentlemen, either you do not tell us what you know or you do not know what you are telling us. Because you are telling us that agricultural products will be excluded from the negotiations and you are careful not to tell us that seafood will in fact be included in these negotiations. The special relationship between the United States and Canada and Mexico will open the door to American products to the European market, with the cocktail effect we fear for our economies. And personally, I believe that we can also ask ourselves what will prevent Mr Juncker from going to negotiate alone and without a mandate the importation of tonnes of GMO soybeans and shale gas, as he did last summer. Mrs Malstrom, we will not compromise on anything, health, security or food sovereignty.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, transatlantic relations do not rise and fall with one particular administration, and especially now, both sides should take the transatlantic bond seriously. Setting out a positive transatlantic trade agenda is necessary to reinforce this bond. I share your view, Commissioner, that it is important to move towards this limited trade deal with the US, based on a narrow negotiating mandate. I believe this can help to create a more positive atmosphere with a view to countering the current global mood towards trade wars. Transatlantic relations are much more than just trade relations, so I am sure that if we can find a way to accommodate our mutual interests in new trade arrangements, this can help to salvage our broader relationship. Let me finish by saying that we in this House look forward to working with the new Congress on constructive trade and bilateral relations.

name: Aleksander Gabelic (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner Malmström, I would like to thank you for your The EU-US trade relations are of great importance. They're very important. We're very important to each other. Nevertheless, we are now in an exceptional situation with the threat of a trade war. There's a lot at stake. We're both losers if the situation gets worse. It can affect a lot of people. That is why I am in favour of negotiations with the United States, and I welcome the efforts to find a viable way forward.  The Commission has certainly been clear that steel tariffs must be removed and that we do not accept car duties. But – it must be just as clear to Trump. That is why it is important that we in the European Parliament now send clearly the message that the steel tariffs and the threats of car tolls must stop. Finally, I would like to call on the Commission to continue to keep us updated on what is happening in this important dossier. Clarity and transparency are needed to ensure that negotiations with the US – although limited – do not create more concern and unnecessary hesitation.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am glad that we are discussing this issue today, because we must warn against the wrong choices. Nobody is against reducing tariffs. But I believe, Mrs Malmström, that, overall, the mandate you are proposing is unrealistic. The US does not want to abide by the agreement that President Juncker made in July – agriculture. What about the contribution of trade to the fight for sustainability and climate change? What about President Trump's promise that he would remove all trade barriers if he refused to negotiate public procurement rules in the first place? What about the risk that mutual recognition of standards will lead to standard dumping? I am afraid, Mrs Malmström, that, to put it in English, you are doing a kind of can-kicking, but we are just running out of road.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is quite interesting to see how the fact that a President Trump is now a negotiating partner in the United States at least influences the debate in this Parliament. When I recall the enthusiasm for TTIP, even though it incorporated enormously restrictive regulations, one can only wonder what concerns are already raised before the start of negotiations in this House.  Donald Trump has made a very simple and very obvious proposal – and since everyone in this House is basically in favour of lowering tariffs and only in principle and now and then against it: he said, let us cut all tariffs, let us all eliminate them! That is a sensible proposal, Mrs Malmström. Negotiations could be very simple with Donald Trump.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Europe-United States relations are driven every day by the chaotic Trump presidency, which instigates Brexit, withdrew from the climate agreement, the Iran agreement, opened the trade war, offends European leaders while being putin's server. But we can't be uninterested in the relationship with the transatlantic side. On the contrary, we need to invest more and more in contacts, and especially in Congress, and also with those sectors of the Administration that resist the destruction of Trump. As far as trade relations are concerned, let us hope to see what these parcel agreements will now be reached. At least the Commissioner has finally come to the conclusion that a comprehensive trade and services agreement with the United States is not possible for now. It was no longer before, because it had that clause of the special courts, shameful, and did not have a chapter on an essential issue that is the regulation of taxation to prevent the diversion of resources from our treasures to tax havens.  More than ever, now that the possibility of following the universal health care system to the European health system is accepted (the President interrupts the speaker) it is time to work on this for a future trade agreement that includes taxation regulation.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, yes, we do have differences with the US administration in several areas – also in the trade area. What we are doing and what was the purpose of the meeting in July was that, despite those differences, we tried to find a common agenda, a positive platform in the trade area and to avoid further escalation, which would be bad for us, for them and for the world. This was agreed in July and what we agreed upon was published immediately. What we do now is that we are respecting that agenda, and it is also following what the European Council unanimously concluded in their Sofia meeting in June. There was unanimity on proposing this to the US. We have been talking with the US during this six months in full transparency. I have many times in the European Parliament Committee on International Trade (INTA) to report on this, and as I said, the full report on what has been discussed in all areas here has been online since this morning – you can read it. What we are asking the Council for is two mandates: one on conformity assessment and one on industrial goods. It is industrial goods, all industrial goods including the car sector and fisheries, that are included here.
