It is common in the WTO context that you include fisheries and industrial goods together, and it makes for a WTO-compliant agreement. This is all and there is nothing else; there’s nothing hidden. This is what we propose. Nothing more, nothing less. This is not a free trade negotiation that we are proposing. A full FTA would, of course, include everything that you have mentioned – difficult issues for the US on public procurement, on geographical indications, on maritime services – difficult issues for us on agriculture, and a few other things. These things are not included. And furthermore, we would, of course, have urged our partner to be a signatory to the Paris Agreement. But this is not a free trade agreement. It’s very limited, albeit beneficial for us and for them. We’re talking about billions of euros from both sides if we were to eliminate tariffs on this. That is why the mandate is short, because this is what it is: nothing else. It is also clear that this agreement cannot be concluded unless there is a solution to the steel and aluminium issue. The tariffs have to be gone, as was said here, and it would not go ahead if the US imposed other tariffs, as is being discussed right now. So this is also clear and it is also reflected in the mandate. That was not funny, that is very serious. So this is something that would be good for mutual trade relations for our business and our consumers, and I can promise you that I will continue to keep you fully informed on where we are going on this. But what you see is exactly what there is. There is no hidden agenda here.

name: President. –
text: Thank you, Commissioner, for being with us at short notice. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – At the beginning of his term of office, the new US President not only suspended the TTIP negotiations, but also showed his negative emotions towards his European partners at every opportunity. It was possible to get the impression that Washington's new allies are Moscow and Beijing, particularly in a bid to weaken the Union's economic position.  However, the European Commission has adopted a good strategy to focus on developing those elements of mutual relations where progress is most likely. It seems, therefore, that the transatlantic trade war has been avoided, which was not so obvious until a dozen months ago. From the point of view of Europe's energy security, an agreement on the possibility of exporting liquefied gas to us is particularly important. I would remind you that this was not agreed during barack Obama's presidency. With this agreement, we are now less energy dependent on Russia or the Countries of the Middle East, which should please us.  Finally, I would like to thank Commissioner Malmström for saying that the Commission is analysing the reasons for the failure of TTIP. I would remind you that this agreement was also controversial for a large part of European societies, and many breathed a sigh of relief after President Trump suspended the negotiations. However, if the Commission wants to pursue further liberalisation of international trade, it should take into account the concerns of Europeans.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D)
text: Written. It is extremely important that we continue to discuss our trade relationship with the United States. In my opinion, the European Union should go for an agreement that focuses not only on industrial goods, but also on workers or the environment. A possible trade agreement must therefore be social. Although the conversation must continue, the EU cannot do so at any cost. It cannot be the case that the EU is being pressured by US President Trump who is constantly threatening to impose tariffs on European products. That is not an equal relationship. The United States also continues to impose import tariffs on European steel and aluminium. In my view, the European Union does not sign an agreement while these tariffs still exist. Finally, I am concerned about the American commitment to include agricultural products as part of this new agreement. Let me be clear: I want to keep the American chlorine chicken out of these negotiations.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - The joint statement agreed by President Trump and Juncker on 25 June 2018 was intended to prevent further increases in tensions between the US and the EU in trade relations between them. In its statement, the Commission has made an overview of the implementation of the agreed, which has now been presented to the European Parliament and the Member States, including the Commission's initial proposals and negotiating powers. It is important that the negotiations are transparent and can continue provided that the US does not impose new tariffs or taxes on EU exports. However, in all this, the important role of the US as an EU security partner must also be borne in mind. Further strain on EU-US relations must be prevented, as the US is the most important partner in the world for the EU.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Fredrick Federley, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the implementation and functioning of the .eu Top Level Domain name and repealing Regulation (EC) No 733/2002 and Commission Regulation (EC) No 874/2004 (COM(2018)0231 – C8-0170/2018 – 2018/0110(COD)) (A8-0394/2018).

name: Fredrick Federley
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I probably won’t use all my time. First of all, I’m very thankful to the colleagues who have been working very swiftly to get this regulation through. It sets new standards and simplifies the administrative procedures connected to the running of the .eu domain name. In line with the objectives of the digital single market strategy, this regulation will do its part in further strengthening the EU as a digital market by providing a digital EU platform for companies and cities, for example, and especially encourage EU citizens, regardless of their country of residence, to obtain a .eu domain name. With this regulation we ensure that we can keep up with the rapid evaluation of the top—level domain name market and the dynamics of the digital landscape that require a future—proof and flexible regulatory environment.  The existence of a specific domain name for the EU is very important for the EU online identity. The .eu domain name provides an opportunity for institutions, companies and citizens to have the possibility to access a .eu TLD. They will therefore be easily identified as part of the EU community, sharing the same set of values and standards.  In Parliament we accepted the structure as proposed by the Commission but wanted to provide for additional safeguards, such as for the respect of users’ privacy and security, consumer protection and human rights. I am especially glad that we could strengthen the text on safeguarding human rights and the rule of law. Parliament also wanted to have better control on the establishment of the criteria and the procedure for the designation of the registry by using delegated acts. I am glad that during the negotiations we were able to secure this.  The Commission proposed to delete the limitation that the registry can only be a ‘not for profit’ organisation, and Parliament endorsed this. However, this was a strong and important point, pushed by the Member States. What we could secure is that the Commission should do a specific review on this point and if needed propose changes.  I’m also glad that we could manage to push for action to secure EU agencies, such as EUIPO, playing a bigger part in preventing cyber—squatting and simplifying administrative procedures. Once again, this is a regulation where the EP has made a difference and secured important points and it would not have been possible if not everyone involved – staff and Members – had been so committed to the task. All in all, Parliament was really united across party lines. There were basically, in the one and only trilogue, three outstanding points, where Parliament was pleased to gain several victories.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I wish to thank the rapporteur, Mr Fredrick Federley, as well as the shadow rapporteurs, for the political agreement reached by the co—legislators on 5 December and endorsed by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy on 14 January. The Commission fully supports the agreement. This concludes what has been a very fast—track process since the adoption of the Commission proposal for a .eu regulation in April 2018. The political agreement of the co—legislators strengthens the regulation on a number of important points. In particular it clarifies that the legal framework for the .eu top—level domain respects the fundamental rights and observes the principles recognised in the Charter of Fundamental Rights, in particular the protection of personal data, the freedom of expression and information and the protection of consumers. It provides for additional safeguards against the abusive registration of .eu domain names, including an assessment of how the registry may operate as the European Union Intellectual Property Office in the future. It applies swiftly, six months after the entry into force of the new regulation, a new eligibility criterion, which will allow all EU citizens to register a .eu domain regardless of where they live, be it inside or outside the EU. Today the .eu domain is available to 500 million people and to businesses across the 28 countries of the European Union as well as in Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway. Our common goal is to establish a future—proof framework, which allows the .eu to continue to grow and provide best—in—class services to EU citizens and businesses. I believe that the compromise reached between the co—legislators fully meets this objective.

name: Gunnar Hökmark
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for a rapid and efficient negotiation process and now the final decision.  This is a small but important piece of the puzzle in developing the digital single market. The .eu domain name can contribute to strengthening the online identity of the Union and simplify and increase cross-border trade. However, the credibility and trustworthiness of the .eu domain can also be abused by those who seek to undermine the legitimacy of our democratic system through cyber—attacks, disinformation and domain squatting. This is happening all the time and at all levels. That’s why it’s important that we look upon our digital infrastructure as a critical infrastructure, which needs to be resilient towards outside pressure and attacks. The new rules are clear that when a domain is registered or used in bad faith, it should be blocked. Those who are responsible for the .eu domain should work with all relevant actors to ensure that this is done swiftly and efficiently. It is a small step for the digital single market and a small step for the cybersecurity of the Union, but it is a step in the right direction and it will be one of very many other steps.

name: Carlos Zorrinho
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, in order to consolidate its shared values and make them structuring in the development of the new digital society, the European Union needs to develop this identity around three pillars. First, give priority to people and their needs. Secondly, to ensure fair access to equipment, and, thirdly, to respect privacy and transparent use of data. The new .eu regulation makes a relevant contribution to this. I would like to congratulate all those who have worked on this dossier, in particular the rapporteur, Fredrick Federlay, and the shadow rapporteur, Csaba Molnár, of S&D, who cannot be present in this debate. The dissemination of a safe but flexible area, aligned with European rules and accessible to citizens, is very important. But we have to dare go further. The strengthening of a network of access and sharing of services with unique authentication, as foreseen for example in the WIFI4EU initiative, opens a line of differentiation from the European approach to the digital society, making its economy more competitive, its knowledge centres more robust, its public services closer to citizens and its people more connected to the opportunities created by technological development. It underlines some structuring aspects of the assessment regulation: the management of the domain by a non-profit organisation is maintained, the European digital identity, its values and the internal market are promoted, citizens are allowed to register regardless of their place of residence, the registration of companies and companies located in the European Union and the European economic area is allowed, registration is allowed in all languages and alphabets , clear rules are created for the management of the domain by users and for the prevention of the inappropriate use of this resource. Therefore, Commissioner, rapporteurs, colleagues, in short, the .eu domain is part of our digital heritage and also of our digital identity. And we need to keep defending it and strengthen it.

name: Ralph Packet
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The introduction of the ".eu" domain name has a goal that I can support 100%: to strengthen our online European identity.  However, the domain name has not been a great success. ".eu" scores poorly in the ranking of the most widely used domain names in the world, and that is obviously not in the interests of the European Union at world level and our economic weight. So there is still a lot of room for improvement. Perhaps this has to do with the many rules and bureaucracy that exist around the ".eu" domain name. Strict management may ensure a high standard of cybersecurity, but I do wonder whether we do not go too far in using the domain name and over-regulating it. The new proposal will give a little more flexibility as to who can apply for the ".eu" domain name, but I am concerned for businesses in the UK after Brexit. The ".eu" internet addresses of British owners who make up a large proportion of the whole should not be taken away suddenly. That would be a major overreaction.  That is why I am calling for more flexibility here.

name: Benedek Jávor
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, more than branding, a domain name is an important tool for sharing knowledge, exercising freedom of speech and conducting business. Therefore, the existence of the .eu domain needs to be regulated with the goal of serving European values and contributing to supporting them. Through this regulation, we give the Union a balanced set of rules on how the registration and maintenance of .eu domains will be managed in the future. However, there are still challenges ahead of us. In a time where the truth is under siege by alternative truths and disinformation is happening on an industrial scale, the websites that uphold European values need to find a safe harbour under the .eu domain and keep sharing the knowledge.  The European Parliament should have a close look at any attempts to censor content and stifle dissent in EU Member States and react swiftly if it happens.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the work done to reach a broad consensus. In the course of the negotiations we have defended the need to think about this tool beyond its economic dimension and to see it in a context in which symbolic aspects take on great relevance and meaning.  This means worrying about ensuring proper and respectful use of human rights and what we consider to be shared values of the Union. It means opening the use, so that citizens can benefit from this domain, in addition to public institutions.  It also means, in our view, ensuring that the public regulator ensures fair and balanced use of the domain in its different dimensions. And it also means ensuring that private intervention in domain management is subject to appropriate controls, safeguarding the public dimension of this domain. As we see, despite its obvious technical dimension, this debate will also include other, more clearly political aspects.

name: Christelle Lechevalier
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, if the establishment of a domain name '.eu' starts with a good intention: adaptation to the market, flexibility, fight against speculation, fraud and abuse, it is above all ideological and you do not hide from it. You want to reinforce in the minds of internet users the idea of an identity of the Union at the expense, therefore, of national identities. It will also promote online the values of the European Union, the EU: multilingualism, respect for security and confidentiality but above all your vision of human rights. Human rights have become the right of minorities of all kinds. Institutions, businesses and citizens who do not meet your criteria would be penalized to the point of losing their website. Additional safeguards have even been provided to protect the rule of law. Countries whose policies contra veras your view of the rule of law would therefore be punished. I am thinking of our friends in Hungary, Poland and Italy, whose migration policy is regularly criticised in this Chamber. As defenders of freedoms, including freedom of expression, which is non-negotiable, we cannot support such a project.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to thank you for the positive remarks today. This final text not only modernises the .eu legal framework but also promotes the rule of law in the online environment and aims to strengthen the multi—stakeholder approach in line with the EU approach on internet governance.  As the digital single market grows and develops, we look forward to seeing many more people and businesses making use of the .eu domain as an important way to participate in the Digital Single Market (DSM) and mark their European identity online. I look forward to a positive outcome of tomorrow’s vote.

name: Fredrick Federley
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, it’s not often that Parliament is as united as we have been in this process. It has been, I would say, a work of excellence – and not just because I was the rapporteur, but I had the good help of Mr Gunnar Hökmark and a few other shadows.  I’m also looking forward to the vote tomorrow. I think it will be a rather swift and smooth one – just like the one and only trilogue, which lasted one hour and 17 minutes.  So thank you Commissioner, thank you Council and thank you to all the staff who have been helping in preparing all our meetings, and thank you to the shadow colleagues.

name: President. –
text: Thank you too. It’s nice to hear when things go smoothly, once in a while. That’s always very welcome. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 31 January 2019. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The top-level domain (TLD) .eu is the domain name of the European Union and its citizens and was introduced by Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 733/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 April 2002 on the implementation of the level 1 '.eu' domain. The assessment of the implementation and functioning of the domain name of the European Union and its citizens revealed that .eu is a well-established TLD, which continues to function well, but is governed by an outdated and rigid legal framework. Moreover, the political and legislative context in the Union, the online environment and the market have changed considerably since the adoption of the .eu regulations. We agree that the new regulation will make it easier for EU citizens to register a .eu domain name and update the principled regulatory framework adapted to the demands of the future to keep it attractive to businessand citizens, strengthening the EU's digital identity. Thus, as many Union citizens as possible will reap the benefits of the .eu TLD. The proposal will also encourage innovation in the .eu ecosystem, both at registry level and in downstream registries and registrars markets.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The revision of the .eu top-level domain management rules is part of the Digital Single Market Strategy and the Regulatory Fitness Programme (REFIT) established by the Commission, in accordance with Union law and standards. The existence of a specific domain name for the EU is very important from the point of view of the EU's digital identity. This is an opportunity for institutions and businesses to become easily recognised as part of an EU community with the same principles and values.  Moreover, it will contribute to creating a secure online environment, building quality and trust and ensuring a Europe-wide presence on the global digital market. .eu, seen in Europe and beyond as innovative and modern, is also an opportunity for smaller EU entrepreneurs whose business will enter the European community, thus going beyond their own borders. Please note that a web address is often the first line of contact between a customer and a company, and a European domain can become a validation of their business. It indicates that the company is subject to European Union law and thus entails the responsibility of all users for its proper use.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Michel Reimon, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Annual Report on Competition Policy (2018/2102(INI)) (A8-0474/2018).

name: Michel Reimon
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As rapporteur for the competition report, I can also report that Parliament has worked very constructively together, has pulled together in a very uniform manner. It is a pleasure to work on competition policy, in this Parliament, at this time, because the Commission takes very clear decisions, which are very comprehensible, are very well documented and, even if details are discussed, are supported and approved in Parliament. What was interesting about this competition report was that we discussed four areas more intensively: the general enforcement of competition law, digital developments, environmental developments and finance, the banking industry. It turns out that, although competition law is a sharp and functioning weapon, a sharp and functioning instrument, we need to think further in the future, especially in the digital sector. There was also a great deal of agreement among the shadow rapporteurs that we need to develop here. Digital companies, which hardly demand sales from end customers, offer services for free and then sell advertising that try to build market power over the years without making a profit, cannot be judged on traditional competitive conditions, not on sales, not on profits, not just financial figures. You have to respond to the market power of such companies in a very different way and adapt to it differently. This is where we need to develop. In the digital sphere in particular, we must also consider whether we are either developing competition law or developing something similar when it comes to protecting democracy. If we have a well-functioning instrument to protect the market from too much power from companies, then democracy should also be worth it in principle. You will understand when I say, as a Green, that the environment must also be worth it: externalities which are not to be accounted for in price, not in the pure market behaviour of companies and which must be examined under current competition law. We should at least think about developing these instruments. As I said, in this report we are dealing with the work of the Commission and not yet with the task of developing it, but I have heard a willingness across all the groups here to continue to work on this issue and to develop it further in the future. Commissioner Vestager has made a very intensive contribution. I am sorry that she cannot be here today because she is ill. It is also important to mention explicitly once again that cooperation between the Commission and Parliament is working very well. I would ask you to discuss this.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf Commissioner Vestager I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Reimon, and the shadow rapporteurs for an excellent report. Mr Reimon, I will be happy to give my colleague, Margrethe Vestager, your positive message and your positive assessment of the cooperation with her. The report shows why competition is at the heart of politics and will be part of the debate in the upcoming European elections. We all buy in the marketplace every day. We want to be confident that companies are giving us a fair deal, and if we are in business we want our factories to grow, not to be squeezed out by a dominant player or by a rival getting unfair subsidies. By keeping markets open we give everybody a fair shot at success. That goes to the heart of our democracy. At the Commission, we will continue to do our part to ensure that every business pays its fair share of tax. For us, the state aid rules are clear. EU countries cannot give some companies a selective tax advantage that others don’t get under the normal rules. The Commission has taken eight decisions on selective tax benefits for multinationals. The decisions have ordered the recovery of more than EUR 15 billion in unpaid taxes from more than 40 companies, most of which are European. This month the Commission opened proceedings on Nike’s tax arrangements in the Netherlands. In parallel, the EU and its Member States need to continue their efforts to reform their corporate taxation framework to make it both fairer and more efficient. Only better taxation rules will close loopholes that are available to everyone. The Commission is also reflecting on our digital future. This month in Brussels, Commissioner Vestager hosted a conference with leading experts on technology and competition. They discussed our digital world and what it means for competition. In the conference, as in the more-than 100 written contributions the Commission has received, some issues kept coming up: access to data; threats to competition when big businesses buy innovative start-ups and dodge the disruption they once caused to others; and the possibility for platform businesses that are also users of their own platform to deny rivals a chance to compete. The Commission will reflect deeply on all these issues because if competition fails, if prices go up and quality falls, we lose that fundamental promise of our digital world that tomorrow’s technology will be better than today’s. Your report makes the important point that markets should also deliver for our environment. We agree and the Commission’s decision to approve the Bayer—Monsanto merger was taken only after the companies committed to sell Bayer’s seed and pesticide business to a new rival so that farmers keep a choice of supplier, and competition drives the businesses to deliver novel products that are safer for the environment. Within the boundaries of the Treaty, we will make markets work for our climate and for our environment. As this Parliament says, openness and fair competition benefit our entire industry. We need European champions, but we need the right ones. When companies compete, and are crowned champions because customers choose them to win, that benefits not just consumers but also other businesses – small and medium enterprises, which are the backbone of our economy, and large companies alike. For every company that wants to see a merger there are many European industries that buy their inputs, such as steel or cement. European business customers rely on open competition so that they can get a fair deal, and also so that they can grow on global markets.

name: President. –
text: Thank you, Commissioner. I will be taking catch—the—eye for this debate if there are colleagues who are interested.

name: Adam Szejnfeld
text: draftss author of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Trade. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This is a good report. I would just like to draw attention to a few important aspects, in my opinion, or to highlight them. Firstly, companies with new technologies, including the digital sector, and competition, often unfair competition, outside the European Union. I am referring, for example, to the takeover of European companies by foreign companies, especially dangerous ones in sectors important for public security. Secondly, the question of transport. We are increasingly seeing more and more efforts to distort competition, not only from the company versus the company, but also from the Member States that restrict this competition. Thirdly, the issue of small and medium-sized enterprises. Unfortunately, bureaucracy continues to distort competition between small and medium-sized companies and large companies. Finally, I would also like to emphasise the issue of asymmetry sometimes occurring in trade relations between Member States or the European Union and third countries. This needs to be eliminated.

name: Gunnar Hökmark
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, first of all, thanks to the rapporteur for well-implemented negotiations and good compromises. Competition policy is very much at the core of the European Union – not because the European Union is about competition but because we are open to new ideas, innovations, new alternatives, new products, new services and new entrants. Competition policy means allowing consumers to be the masters of the market and that means we will ensure not only that no one can abuse market dominance but also that we can always have new entrants in all sorts of markets; not only maintaining pressure on prices but also ensuring we have dynamic development of our economy. That’s why we need legal certainty and the rule of law, and that’s why my political group and I are sceptical about naming and shaming from this Parliament, or politicising how the Commission implements the competition rules.  We must have the rule of law and fair competition, and that also means we need to consider the energy union and big, dominant operators such as Gazprom. They must be judged in the same way as any others and their abuse of market dominance must entail a reaction. Competition is for the consumers, and for a Europe that is open to change and dynamic development.

name: Tibor Szanyi
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. The annual report on competition policy 2107 has been enriched with a number of forward-looking elements in the inter-parliamentary discussions between the Commission. For this reason, I would like to express my sincere congratulations to all my colleagues and officials involved in the preparation of this report. It is gratifying that this report also focuses on issues that significantly improve the quality of life of citizens, and let me give an example of some, such as the very serious emphasis and the increasing urgency of caring about accelerating the need for energy supply and decarbonisation in Europe. That's what happens in that report. The case of the elimination of geoblocking is also given due prominence in investigations. Data protection and transparency issues are also a very important part of this report. And what I am very pleased about personally is that there is also a very strong emphasis on issues relating to making the digital economy consumer-friendly. But obviously, a competition policy report cannot be idle if it is a question of value analysis from other economic areas. Thus, to contribute to taxation and, above all, to the principle that taxation must be carried out by making value creation a reality. Moreover, there are also plenty of challenges within the EU, such as issues relating to the ethic of calls between countries within the European Union in the field of telecommunications, which are the same as local calls. In the same way, the competition report still abounds with the spread of the fifth generation and the guarantee of free bank current accounts. Not least, I must mention that there is also due attention to the further development of the smart villages project, which is the new European rural development concept.

name: Stanisław Ożóg
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We all agree that a strong, effective competitive policy has been at the heart of our single market from the outset. However, I have mixed feelings when I see how double standards are used here, even in this House, to criticise specific states, institutions or organisations. The rapporteur did not have a problem in identifying specific US companies, but when it comes to European tax pathologies, it is sufficient to say here that some governments, jurisdictions – luxembourg, the Netherlands or Ireland, for example – had a kind of special immunity in this matter. Similarly, in terms of energy competitiveness. The text calls for respect for the principles of solidarity and the rule of law, but lacked the courage and political will to clearly point to the draft of the second Northern Gas Pipeline. It's disappointing and not entirely fair.  Nevertheless, I acknowledge that many paragraphs of the report on tax avoidance, money laundering deserve support, which is why my delegation will support the report in tomorrow's vote.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his Welcome to the "nightclub", where the music is not so funny, and the psychedelic lighting does not make it any easier. All discussions on competition policy in europe will at least be about three different poles: firstly, preserving europe's global competition against strong forces outside, secondly, preserving competition within its borders and, thirdly, ensuring that businesses pay their taxes and, firstly, creating a reasonably equal level for both small and large companies.  Getting these three different aspects to always go together is not always a very easy operation. When we preserve europe's competitiveness against global adversaries or global competitors, it can sometimes be at the expense of small businesses and the ability of national companies to cope. If we try to keep small businesses out in the national Member States, we may at the same time be a little hindering our international competitiveness. This is therefore not always in balance, and when it is at the same time in a technological development that is breathtaking, we may face major challenges. During the discussions with the rapporteur and the other shadow rapporteurs, we have been particularly pleased with the effort made by Commissioner Vestager in this area. She has shown that women in a responsible position in the European Union are capable of things that men cannot always do. I would also like to thank Mr Reimon for his good cooperation. I'm always afraid when we make our statements that we create little Christmas trees. I come from a country where we like to see Christmas trees and maybe wanted to sell them. I am therefore glad this still contains the fewest Christmas trees possible.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his work and on the sensitivity he has shown in incorporating aspects relevant to our political group. We are aware of the political constraints to go further in some content, but we regret some significant absences.  We defend public intervention in the form of aid as an instrument to be put at the service of majority and should not be seen as a problem, but as a solution. Unfortunately, competition policy does not.  It is therefore paradoxical that public aid is given to the financial sector, which is primarily responsible for the crisis and which nevertheless appear to be outside the sanctioning capacity of competition policy, especially when these banking aid has served as an excuse for cuts precisely in the public sector.  Another element is that, even if the right wants to keep looking the other way, energy poverty is the consequence of a policy to dictate the economic interests of multinationals in the sector. These are aspects which unfortunately do not make it possible for us to vote in favour of this report.

name: Barbara Kappel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Unlike previous reports, this report on competition policy has a very special focus on two areas, namely digitisation and harmful tax practices – and for good reason, in my view.  Digital and Internet companies in particular are facing completely new challenges in competition policy. Not only because technological development is progressing rapidly, but because the definition of new criteria and competence thresholds is necessary. And this is what the report points out: on the one hand, it is the amount of data as an indicator of the existence of market power and the proposal not to fix the thresholds of competence for triggering EU merger control on turnover. I believe that both are very sensible proposals.  With regard to tax policy, the report calls for greater harmonisation of corporate taxation, including a common consolidated corporate tax base. More transparency and simple rules are good, but fiscal policy should remain separate from competition policy. Competition policy is not a suitable instrument for harmonising fiscal policy.  With regard to this aspect, which is mentioned in the report, I would also like to mention the following: in the planned merger of the train divisions of Siemens and Alstom into the second largest train manufacturer in the world, the Commissioner has endorsed the rapporteur's critical attitude. A decision is due by February 18. I hope that there will still be an opinion on the Commissioner. I believe that this would be a very sensible step towards remaining globally competitive.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, i would like to thank the rapporteur and the colleagues who have worked on the report. Gunnar Hökmark has already said the essentials from the point of view of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats. That is why I would like to add to a point that Mrs Kappel has just mentioned at the end. I believe that enough has been said about digital companies and how competition law should be applied there, and has already been applied in part by the Commission.  In the area of fiscal policy, I think that the Commission has done an excellent job of simuging the inconsistency of the behaviour of the Member States. However, the key issue we are faced with in competition law and, above all, in the area of merger control, is how we include the larger, the large economic regions of the world with the existing market structures there in our decision-making. I am not deliberately mentioning any countries now, because it is leading the debate on the wrong track. In the long term, however, it is dangerous, of course, if we try to enforce competition rules that are strict, which may actually bring together all the relevant criteria on a case-by-case basis, but then large players in the world do not care about these rules at all and simply ignore them. This makes no sense to us as Europeans in the long term.  I believe that we need a new idea for the coming years of how we can use not only the customer markets in the European Union to assess market concentration, but also the subcontracting markets, which are often located in the Far East and which present us with difficulties that we do not manage today. This will be a task that I believe the new Commission will have to deal with.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: – I take the floor to express the main concern, namely that tech giants such as Google have a monopoly position and are taking power. The power over our data, the power to buy up competitors. The power also to influence democracy, directly or indirectly. The spread of knowledge and power must be the starting point of competition policy, and by tackling the monopoly of these tech giants, we can put an end to the situation of unhealthy power.  That is why I have also again mentioned in the report that Google's search engine must be detached from the other internet services in order to create a more level playing field. It seems ambitious, but it's certainly nothing new. The American company Microsoft has previously been forced by the European Union to release separate versions of Windows.  The European Commission previously concluded that Google is using its position and exploiting its power to favour its own services. Splitting up Google is therefore a logical and just next step.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I congratulate you all for this report. It is a good Parliament contribution to the Commission, identifying the key important or hot issues on the table.  Let me start by saying that I welcome Commissioner Vestager’s work and concerns raised regarding the Siemens-Alstom merger. She has and is facing very strong political pressure, but, as always, confirms that she stands firm. As I raised in the past, I feel that negative consequences for high-speed rolling stock and signalling systems could arise if this merger was to be authorised. Regarding authorisations misused by big tech firms, I am very proud that many of my amendments are included in the final compromises. I also welcome that, once again, this report calls on the Commission to organise a hearing with tech companies, the CEOs of Google and Facebook.  Let me conclude by saying that regarding the several Google anti-trust cases, this report invites the Commission to consider the possibility of setting deadlines for anti-trust cases, as it does in merger cases.

name: Jacques Colombier (ENF).
text: Madam President, at first reading, this report contains remarks that may be partly relevant, particularly in the area of agriculture. It is true that our fight is now receiving more attention in the area of industrial concentration of companies operating in the agricultural input sector, but, overall, this report is part of the endless globalist logic that the European Union has sought since its inception. We, for our part, cannot give the Commission the slightest quitus in this area, as in so many others. It has a very questionable policy in terms of decisions on mergers, cartels and competition rules. As it stands, this report finds, by necessity, a very degraded and worrying situation to which the Commission's policy is far from foreign. We cannot accept the logic of that.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Madam President, at the beginning of this parliamentary term, I was telling Commissioner Vestager that the logic of the market and competition should not affect sectors as important as social services. And he did so in reference to the problems that the King Aurelius Center for Persons with Disabilities, in El Entrego, Asturias, was having to maintain a service provided by the association of family and friends of the people who receive support in that Center. Finally, thanks to the efforts of the Principality of Asturias, the association, the City Council and all the Asturian social agents, it has been possible for this association of relatives to maintain the provision of the service of the relatives who are, as I said before, receiving services in that Center. But it is an ongoing threat to introduce that market logic into social services that must be exempt from market logic. My support for the association of family and friends and my wish that this Centre will continue to maintain this public provision of a third sector and recognized by all.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for presenting a very good draft report. Indeed, when it comes to competition, we all feel that the internal market is the fundamental focus of our values within the EU, and the open market in which we are looking for a balance is between the various players in this market, whether, of course, consumers or companies. This contact between those elements of competition is done within a certain legal framework.  That is why unfair competition, unfair competition and, of course, unfair competition outside the EU are also unacceptable to us. I am very glad that this report also affects the issue of just smart village. I appreciate this very much as a member of the REGI Committee, and it is also crucial for me that the rapporteur deals with the issue of the sustainability of market forces, the operation of the market, i.e. their responsibility for the environmentally friendly environment and the sustainability of these trends. So I would also like to appreciate this.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the report is welcome. Competition policy is very important for the internal market, we all want a well-regulated internal market, but not only well regulated, but also with fair competition and - as another colleague said here - we are talking about competition in the internal market, but also competition outside the internal market, because - we know very well - we have giants, very large companies, who have outsourced their business from the internal market to third countries and come and make an unfair competition. There has also been talk here of the power of large companies that can influence public policy after all. I want to refer to the fact that we have a competition - and I say since I have been here - an unequal competition between SMEs and big companies, between trusts. There is still not enough oversight, although we have antitrust regulations, there are unfair competitions and recently we have very relevant cases in this regard and I hope, Commissioner, that we will find new solutions.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, in Venezuela these days we can see what companies where there is no competition fall. The elimination of economic freedom necessarily leads to the extinguishment of other freedoms, because a policy that does not allow citizens to manage their wallets, very quickly begins to dangerously indusize other spheres of their lives. A free market is a prerequisite for economic development and prosperity. It must be reasonably regulated so that everyone has a level playing field on it and that no entity is privileged in the competition. The legislator is there to set the rules of competition, not to decide the winner, and therefore we must be careful not to overregulate the market and thus upset the balance of these particular entities in a privileged position. Competition is a major guarantee of the global competitiveness of the European economy, innovation and investment in development, quality of products and services and more affordable prices for consumers. The more competitions, the better for everyone.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to thank you for the very interesting and important strategic discussion on competition policy.  Let me add one comment relating to some of your contributions, about the need to strengthen our global competitiveness. It is absolutely clear that Europe must stand up for our industry when necessary. We need the right trade defence instruments, the ability to screen foreign investments affecting our security, and we must help our industries to adapt so they have a future on our continent. The state aid rules help industries to invest in new skills and innovation. The Commission is working on state aid rules that are as simple as possible and fit for the future. We will involve Parliament on any significant proposal for change. Honourable Members, in May, voters will want to see what Europe brings for them. We will do our share. We must prove that a vote on Europe matters by giving our citizens a competition policy to believe in.

name: Michel Reimon
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As we have seen, a thoroughly constructive debate. All that remains for me is to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their constructive work. The fact that we are not all 100% happy with the final result is in the nature of the matter. That's the way it is for me. But it was very constructive and consensus-oriented, and by and large, I think everyone is moving in the same direction. This will also be important – and I would like to stress this once again, Commissioner – in the European elections in May. The European Union, here in Brussels, often gets populist accusations that this is just about lobbies, that everything would be negotiated with the big corporations, that shadow business would be done here and that the Union would be firmly in the hands of large corporations. In the area of competition law in particular, this Commission, including this European Parliament, has shown time and again in recent years that this is about taking clear decisions that are taken, that we are not in the hands of any dark forces, but that the European Union is a functioning, valuable and defendable political project. We should take this up actively in May, the competition policy for which this Union does not have to be ashamed, but can be proud, and we should tell the stories that we have experienced and made here over the last five years.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 31 January 2019. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. Competition policy, which has been in place for over sixty years, is one of the major pillars of European integration, ensuring a level playing field in all sectors and ensuring the proper functioning of the internal market. In view of the continuous changes in the digitalisation of the modern economy, competition policy must ensure the coherent development of the digital single market. We need to promote data innovation and new business models, and counter asymmetries between the traditional economy and new digital economic practices, preferring international solutions and common approaches to taxation in the digital economy. In addition, it is necessary to address market distortions resulting from unfair commercial practices and to ensure a level playing field worldwide, which benefits workers, consumers and businesses. Further protection measures will have to be introduced, including the establishment of a European framework for the control of foreign direct investment, anti-subsidy instruments and initiatives to support small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Carolina Punset (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The concentration of companies in the agrochemical sector is a problem that deserves all the attention of the European Union. We are not looking at a sector governed by criteria of free competition, but in the face of a broad value chain controlled by large business groups which do not pursue, nor the interest of small producers, nor guarantee the rights of European consumers. Competition is always necessary, and I support the work done by the Directorate-General for Competition to ensure that European and third-country companies participate in the Single Market under the same conditions, prohibiting any abusive agreement or conduct that underscores freedom of access and trade in goods and services. Therefore, we cannot tolerate that, as in the agrochemical sector, the breeders of transgenic seeds are also the owners of the active materials used in those materials necessarily because of the genetic resistance condition acquired. An oligopoly of this nature is not market leadership; is the denial of the market itself. The Commission should ensure the public interest and dismantle, on the application of European Union law, a business structure which, moreover, does not take into account the environmental cost.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Marian—Jean Marinescu, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on the Annual Report 2017 on the protection of the European Union’s financial interests – fight against fraud (2018/2152(INI)) (A8—0003/2019).

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, European money fraud amounted to almost THREE billion euros in 2017, and the VAT carousel of European money costs us EUR 50 billion annually. Illicit trade in cigarettes continues to cause damage to the European budget and the Member States. According to OLAF's estimates, the illicit trade in cigarettes results in annual financial losses of more than EUR 10 billion in the budgets of the Union and the Member States. Overall, almost 21% fewer irregularities were reported to the Commission in 2017 than in 2016, around 15 000 fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities. As rapporteur, I want to focus on prevention, because it is good to find irregularities, it is good to detect fraud, it is good to take the money back, but I think the best thing for the European budget would be to prevent and spend the money effectively. We have proposed that all stages of development of a European project be digitised, all stages of the evaluation and selection of tenders, as well as implementation, be carried out electronically and transparently. Given that more than two trillion euros a year is spent on public procurement, I recommend the use of e-procurement to combat fraud. Worryingly, we are making a very difficult recovery of the fraudulent funds - only 37% of the European funds defrauded between 1989 and 2017 have been recovered. I call on the Commission to continue its efforts to standardise the nomenclature of expenditure errors.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Thank you for the opportunity for the Commission to take a stand here in your parliamentary debate. Parliament and the Commission agree that the protection of the European budget, the proper use of our budgets, both on the expenditure side and on the revenue side, is a very, very important commitment and responsibility. We want the European budget, with its limited resources, to be able to reach its full potential and for all the money, projects we want, programmes that we need, to be able to serve the promotion of the economy, society and our fellow citizens. That is why the fight against fraud, infidelity, abuse and irregularities is very important to us. This fight must be fought at The Level of the European Union and at the level of the Member States and the regions – a commitment for the Commission, for the European institutions, but also for national governments and administrations. I read Mr Marinescu's report a lot last night. I think it is comprehensive and very balanced. It covers most of the important aspects, it also criticises the Commission, including OLAF, where this is justifiable or even necessary, but it also highlights many of the activities of the Commission and our services in a positive way. Thank you very much for this fair evaluation of our work. Parliament and the Commission have jointly made considerable efforts in the fight against fraud in recent years, and we have made progress. Last year, we presented our multiannual financial framework, where the implementing rules also make it more difficult or impossible to make fraud, corruption and infidelity impossible. And we have incorporated a proposal for a new anti-fraud programme into this budgetary framework. If the rule of law in the Member States is threatened and there are deficits and can increase, thereby increasing the risk of harming the European Union's financial interests, we must take action against it. Our proposal on conditionality and the possibility of cutting or cutting budgetary resources when the rule of law is no longer fully respected was accepted by A European Parliament a few days ago in Strasbourg by a large majority. Thank you very much for this support on the way to a consultation and adoption between the Council and Parliament. 2018 was a year of intensive work to establish the European Public Prosecutor's Office – a joint effort by my colleague, Mr Jourova, who was just sitting here, and by myself, by your services and by OLAF. We have now appointed an interim administrative director. It has the power to implement the budget and to recruit staff so that the European Public Prosecutor's Office can start operating at the end of 2020. The procedure for appointing the European Prosecutor General, that is to say the Head of EPPO, is ongoing, and we will inform you in the future and shortly and ask for your consent. As part of your efforts to improve the European Union's response to fraud, we have also presented the proposal to amend the OLAF regulation to you and to the Council. In this way, we want, above all, to ensure close cooperation between OLAF and the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the effectiveness of OLAF investigations. This reform should, if possible, be taken forward in the coming weeks. OLAF and the European Public Prosecutor's Office will cooperate closely within their own competences. We must ensure full complementarity in the overall response to illegal acts to the detriment of European finances, fill all the gaps, avoid duplication of effort and optimise cooperation. This is a common objective of ours – Parliament and the Commission – and Mr Marinescu's report underlines this, and OLAF and the strengthening of OLAF's powers in a number of important areas are also highlighted. Indeed, EPPO is a partner of OLAF, but EPO must not weaken OLAF, but OLAF must move more into the future from this joint work. This Commission proposal is on your table, and I am counting on your support so that this dossier gets the attention it deserves. It is important to have the adoption process as rapid as possible so that THE start of EPPO at the end of 2020, before that the modernisation of the rules and the reorganisation of competences between OLAF and EPPO in the European code, takes place. I would like to thank Mrs Gräßle, who, as chair of the Committee on Budgetary Control, presented a comprehensive report yesterday, which was based on the Commission proposal to amend OLAF Regulation. It is very comprehensive and ambitious. I believe that Mrs Gräßle's report must be incorporated in two stages in Parliament and the Council. Stage one: the small reform to rebalance OLAF and EPPO. Stage two: in the new mandate of Parliament and the Commission, a major reform of OLAF so that Mrs Gräßle's ideas can be taken into account at the latest. I would like to warn against one thing: if we approach too ambitiously, I think a decision is possible in Parliament, but not in the Council. And nothing would be worse than to approach this year with great ambition and then to have nothing at all next year and to see unresolved competences between OLAF and EPPO in the operational business at the launch of EPPO. We should avoid this. A final point that was and is important to Parliament: illicit tobacco trafficking. Here, too, I can report significant progress. The new anti-cigarette smuggling treaty, the so-called FCTC protocol, came into force in September last year. It has been ratified by the European Union and now by 47 countries. The European Union has always been at the forefront of this, and our joint efforts are now paying off. Thank you very much for your expectations and support. In December last year, a few weeks ago, we adopted a new action plan to combat the illegal trade in tobacco. It builds on the old but good strategy of 2013 and on the analytical progress report presented two years ago. All these are activities and proof of continued commitment to the fight against fraud. I am pleased that Parliament is fully uptosining its task of monitoring and controlling us, criticising us and supporting us. This is also shown by the Marinescu report. Thank you for your patience.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for your comprehensive report. I think I could dissect the individual points, but unfortunately I do not have 8 min like you, I only have 1.5 minutes, so I will focus only on the last point, and that is the point of cigarette smuggling. I returned to this again 4 and 3 years ago, this was the topic of smuggling cigarettes from Belarus towards Poland. There, the Commission took some steps in conjunction with the Polish Government and the problem began to be addressed. But where this problem has not been addressed at all is France. Every day, a boat with smuggled cigarettes arrives in Marseille from Algeria. I have repeatedly pointed this out, even published my article in Le Monde, where I actually say how the process is going. Europol has repeatedly pointed this out here, OLAF has repeatedly pointed this out, but France rejects any greater cooperation with OLAF. Here is the question for you, Commissioner: Isn't it time not just to pay attention to the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe and to systematically start paying attention to France? Isn't it time to force France to really stop underestimating the trade in illegal tobacco and cigarettes? After all, 30% of cigarettes smuggled into France are from Algeria.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, I am very grateful to Mr Marinescu for his report and I also welcome the presence of both Commissioner Oettinger and the Director-General of OLAF, Mr Itsel.  Since 27 January, the Spanish Central Bank has stopped issuing 500 euro banknotes. This measure, which may seem apparelful, is nevertheless also a measure to combat fraud, although unfortunately there are some countries where it still resists.  I welcome the fact that this report for 2017 also shows that the number of cases of fraud has been reduced, thanks to work between all – OLAF and all systems, both at national and European level – by more than 20% compared to 2016. We have also managed to save a very large amount of millions of euros; However, in the case of the VAT gap we still have a lot of work to do. I must also take into account that my country, Spain, is noted for being above average in 2017 – almost double the average – in relation to fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities; but the truth is that there are still elements of improvement and the objective of the current Government is precisely the direct fight against fraud.  I am also pleased that in the agricultural area — when farmers are so often denigrated - complaints and fraudulent situation have been reduced by almost half in the field of rural development, but we have problems related to direct support again, and I hope that Mr Hogan and the new CAP reform will also take these problems into account. We welcome in a very special way the current efforts to parallel and without duplicates the OLAF Regulation with the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, to whom we give a pre-eminent role in this fight against fraud.  We also believe that it is important to strengthen the customs situation and we also agree with Mr Zdechovsk- although I do not point to France, but in general to the system — on the need to continue to combat the illicit trade in tobacco products, which entails a loss of EUR 10 billion. And finally, the protection of whistleblowers.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The protection of the Union's financial interests is key to increasing citizens' trust in the Union as such and must be supported, but making unrealistic proposals to investigate citizens' trust in public administrations or even democratically elected structures of the Member States in the fight against corruption is too far-reaching a step that de facto undermines the competences of the Member States.  Furthermore, under the guise of combating fraud and protecting the interests of the Union, there is support for the Commission's controversial proposal to link the Union budget to the rule of law in the Member States. However, I would stress that the Commission is not entitled to investigate and publish assessments of threats to the rule of law in the Member States. Moreover, the Proposal of the European Prosecutor is a very controversial proposal for many of us.

name: Nedzhmi Ali
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, we are satisfied with the fact that in 2017 the total number of irregularities reported to the Commission were 21% fewer than in 2016. Their value of approximately EUR 2.58 billion was a 13% decrease from the previous year.  However, not all Member States have adopted national anti—fraud strategies and there is still a gap between the Member States in the reporting process. Member States have to establish a uniform system for collection of comparable data on irregularities in cases of fraud in order to standardise the reporting process and ensure the quality and comparability of the data.  We welcome the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, for which purpose, for the first time, the European Union budget 2019 includes appropriations of EUR 4.9 billion. We also welcome the Commission’s proposal for a regulation on the protection of the Union’s budget in the case of generalised deficiencies as regards the rule of law in the Member States. We expect objective and systematic assessment based on a set of indicators and independent report. The report includes also some aspects related to public procurement such as digitalisation and prevention at the early stages of the tender procedure as well as import procedures, expenditure problems identified and measures required, investigative journalism, as well as transnational fraud.  Finally, we welcome the Commission’s proposal to empower OLAF to investigate value added tax matters and call on the Commission to establish a certain level of transparency of OLAF reports and recommendations.

name: Benedek Jávor
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to say thank you to the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation. This is the last ‘PIF’ (‘protection of financial interests’) report of this term, so we should see where we stand regarding the protection of the EU’s financial interests. The picture is very mixed, although we have adopted the PIF Regulation, including VAT within its scope, we have adopted the provisions for the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) and we have started reform of the VAT system in the EU. But the EPPO will include countries only on a voluntary basis; the Commission has abolished the bi—annual Anti—Corruption Report; the EU is still not a cooperating member of the Group of States against Corruption (GRECO). The EU seems to be financing Member States which are openly misusing the funds, large-scale corruption is spreading and the EU is not equipped with proper tools to address it. It is clear what we need right now. We need the Commission and the Council to be firm on corruption. The EU needs to improve all the policies I have mentioned, and it definitely needs the so—called Rule of Law Regulation, with the option of allowing the EU to spend EU funds directly in those Member States affected.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this year too, the report on the protection of the Union's financial interests shows an encouraging decrease in the total number of irregularities. However, despite the positive trend that has been going on since 2014, it is clear that the level of fraud in EU funds still remains very high – we have heard this: almost three billion euros in 2017 – just as corruption cases remain high.  Much remains to be done: several Member States, for example, do not yet have specific laws against organised crime, even though the participation of criminal groups in cross-border fraud against the Union's financial interests, such as cigarette smuggling, currency counterfeiting or carousel fraud, is constantly increasing. Furthermore, despite the recent adoption of important legislative measures, such as the PIF directive or the Regulation on the European Public Prosecutor's Office, I believe that not enough has been done in terms of preventing corruption or in recovering funds that have been the subject of fraud.  It is precisely for this reason that the Commission's decision not to publish any more specific reports on corruption continues to give cause for concern. It is true that this issue is included in the Governance Document of the European Semester, a document which, however, only considers the economic impact caused by corruption, leaving aside its negative effects in terms of civil coexistence and public confidence in public administration.  Finally, in this debate too, I believe that it should be emphasised that the role played by whistleblowers – the so-called whistleblowers – should not be underestimated in the fight against fraud and corruption. Because of the importance of their contribution and the sensitivity of their role, we hope that the legislative proposal establishing their rights and obligations can be approved in good time. I would like to thank my fellow rapporteur for his work and thank all of you for the attention that has been paid to me.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about fraud. I don't want to repeat what was said here. I want to focus on a few things that weren't touched in the report. Fraud is not solely made of European funds and cannot OLAF solve everything. Here we need to act systemically, Commissioner, and I raise the issue that the customs union is still being postponed, the computerisation and systemic functioning of the customs union are still being postponed. We have a lot of counterfeit goods, a lot of dumped goods, that go into the internal market, and obviously it's fraud. We're talking about fraud that, lo and behold, happened most - say the experts, right? - in 11 countries. For a few years nothing has been resolved, we do not know the result. Fifty-five billion! We are talking about fraud in Germany, for example, the sale of cars in Eastern Europe without being highlighted, and we are talking about very large sums of around 50 000 vehicles. There must be new and, of course, prevention measures here, as the rapporteur said, but, Commissioner, I believe that much more needs to be done and that OLAF's tasks with the tasks of the EPO and other institutions do not overlap.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, the protection of the Financial Interests of the Union is one of those important topics where it is particularly important to be guided by the principles of balance and proportionality.  The mechanisms necessary in the fight against fraud bear some burden on the economy. We must make sure that this burden is the least possible and that the legal mechanisms are maximally selective, i.e. that they take into account with great accuracy those who cheat.  Also, this necessary administrative and financial burden must not fall on the backs of SMEs, which could be an unbearable burden. We must never forget that small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of the European economy and employ the vast majority of employees in the private sector and that any unnecessary burden can cost some of their employees their jobs.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Oettinger, it is impossible to exaggerate the importance of this annual debate we are holding about fraud in the Union's financial interests. And this European Parliament has done all it can: it has criminally legislates — the Criminal Directive on the protection of the Union's financial interests, which creates not only criminal rates binding on the Member States, but also minimum penalties, penalties - but above all, we have given the impetus to the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which will complement the architecture of fraud prosecution.  And the fact that fraud appears to be decreasing by up to 20% and in the amounts let down cannot be related—right?—to the fact that detection or investigation is failing. Because the European Public Prosecutor's Office is still six states short. Some of them have historically been characterized by their opt-out of European criminal law and the area of freedom, security and justice. But there are two who distinguish themselves by having the highest levels of fraud and corruption in the management of European funds.  It is therefore important that we complete the European Public Prosecutor's Office with the OLAF Regulation — the Regulation of the European Anti-Fraud Office — which is still under impetus by the Romanian Presidency. We want it to be completed so that their investigations are relevant and complementary to those of the Member States and their evidence can be used as evidence in criminal proceedings in the Member States.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to address key issues, but I would also like to thank you for the expertise you have shown and for the commitment you are putting forward here, together with the Commission. This supports and strengthens us very much.  The case was mentioned in which illegal tobacco imports, cigarettes, reach Europe, namely the port of Marseille. Indeed, it must be clear that corruption, fraud, infidelity, illegal trade is not an issue for some Member States. It is an issue for the whole of the European Union. In some Member States this is more, in others less, but no Member State, no region is free of it. There is no East-West divide, no south-north divide, and OLAF, with its officials and expertise, is investigating this French case, this presumption that a ship from the Maghreb reaches Europe via Marseille every day. We will inform you about the progress.  Secondly, the so-called VAT fraud, VAT fraud: the current OLAF regulation is not entirely clear in its text. Are revenue from VAT own resources? Are they and the control of OLAF's competence, or is it not? Some Member States dispute this. The country in which I was at home also denies this, which is why, by amending the OLAF regulation, we want to clarify exactly this, thereby removing any legal uncertainty. The lower limit of EUR 10 million will also no longer exist. We want OLAF to have or have full competence to investigate abuses and frauds on the important VAT revenues, at least whatever the legal situation may have been, that it will be indisputable in the future. Several colleagues have raised the question of why the Commission is no longer presenting an anti-corruption report: this is true. We are no longer presenting it as our own report. Why? The fight against corruption is important to us. It is a feature of our assessment of policy and conditions in the Member States. That is why we have integrated this anti-corruption report into the guidelines of the European Semester in a separate chapter. The European Semester is our general ledger to define the situation of the Member States on strengths and weaknesses, criticism. There you will find our assessment on the freedom of corruption, the fight against corruption in the Member States, and we can also go through our country specific recommendations, sanctions are also legally possible on the basis of legal.  When it has been said that there is a lack of a written strategy to combat fraud in many Member States, in many Member States, this too is true. Unfortunately, there is no legal obligation for the Member States to present an anti-fraud strategy. Some do this, others don't. We encourage all Member States. We are pushing them, but without a legal instrument. We also advise them. We are sure that more and more Member States are presenting an anti-fraud strategy for their work and as a template for European work, also in their own interests. name: Marian-Jean Marinescu
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, thank you very much for your words of appreciation, and I also thank you on behalf of my colleagues who have contributed, the shadow rapporteurs who have contributed to this report. It is clear that the detection of fraud and the recovery of fraudulent money, both of these activities are extremely important and must strengthen and continue if fraud decreases to 0.1% of the budget.
