name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Richard Corbett, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on amendments to the Rules of Procedure affecting Title I, Chapters 1 and 4, Title V, Chapter 3, Title VII, Chapters 4 and 5, Title VIII, Chapter 1, Title XII, Title XIV and Annex II (2018/2170(REG)) (A8-0462/2018).

name: Richard Corbett
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, this report is the culmination of a year and a half’s work by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, which set up a special working group that was very ably chaired by Mr Wieland, with a representative from every political group. Our main task was to look again at our rules, two years after the big rules revision that we adopted two years ago. Some things needed tidying up, some things hadn’t worked so well – there was the question of this new device of interpellations, which I think we adopted by accident in plenary, and which didn’t sit very well with some of the other aspects of the rules. We’ve tidied all that up. But there are three big issues that have caused some controversy.  The first is how to deal with the fact that Parliament lost the court case that Mr Korwin—Mikke brought against the European Parliament when he was censured and fined by the President for using quite violently inappropriate language. The Court ruled that the balance in our rules between the right of Members to express themselves and the protection of Parliament and the public from hate speech and defamatory speech was not quite right. So we have very carefully, with the help of our Legal Service, rewritten that rule so that the emphasis now is on the use of offensive language, not so much on the content but on the intent to offend. We have defined that very carefully and we’ve even got a reference to Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights so that it covers a wide number of ways in which people may well feel offended by hate speech. We think we have that balance right, and I hope all groups accept what we have done there.  The second interesting subject is that of transparency, where we’ve been quite modest but we’ve wanted to increase the transparency in our rules where Members are dealing with lobbyists. At one level, for all Members, we say that Members ‘should’ only meet lobbyists who are on the transparency register and they ‘should’ publish their meetings online. The word ‘should’ is different from ‘shall’. It is not an obligation. It is more a recommendation. But it is an important recommendation for Members. We go further, though, for rapporteurs, where we say that rapporteurs, shadows and committee chairs in dealing with a report ‘shall’ – in other words, they have to – publish a list of scheduled meetings that they have had with lobbyists and interest representatives. ‘Shall’ but it’s only scheduled meetings. If you happen to bump into somebody on a train or in the corridor, you don’t of course necessarily control that as a rapporteur, but when you have arranged a formal meeting, it should be reported and it should be transparent.  Remarkably, the PPE Group has, I understand, asked for a secret vote on transparency. You couldn’t make it up really. It does seem to me a bit bizarre. Perhaps it’s not too late for my PPE colleagues to reconsider.  The final issue difficult issue we’ve tried to grapple with is the question of fake groups – political groups that have no political affinity as required under our rules. We had this, you may remember – some people will remember – some 15 years ago when we had a technical group composed of a political party from the far right and one from the far left. They had no political affinity. They were creating a group simply to avail of the resources that you get from Parliament – staff, money, speaking time – to use that, but were not acting as a political group within our rules. That may be a situation that repeats itself after the elections. We should protect ourselves and have a mechanism for making sure that affinity – if there is a doubt about it and we are very careful in our wording there to say that Parliament normally need not evaluate political affinity – but if there is manifest evidence, then Parliament as a whole, by an absolute majority – that’s a high threshold as a safeguard – can decide that a group has not been properly constituted. I think that’s not unreasonable.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission welcomes the fact that, in line with the framework agreement between our institutions, the European Parliament has sought the opinion of the Commission on amendments to the Rules of Procedure which affect us. We have set out our opinion in the letters addressed by First Vice—President Timmermans to Ms Hübner on 9 October, ahead of the committee vote, and to President Tajani yesterday, ahead of the vote in plenary tomorrow. I will not repeat in detail now what you will all have seen in writing, but I will flag just a few points. We welcome several amendments, such as those on the transparency of intergroups, the abolition of minor interpellations, the improvements to public hearings and the ‘unfinished business’ rule as concerns citizens’ initiatives and the threshold for the verification procedure for citizens’ requests under the statute of European political parties. We remain concerned that some of the amendments on parliamentary questions could reduce the efficiency and quality of this important means of democratic accountability, in particular with regard to the removal of the limit on the number of questions and the introduction of very tight target deadlines for replies. With regard to the transparency—related amendments, the Commission looks at this issue from the angle of the negotiations on the draft interinstitutional agreement on a mandatory transparency register. The objective of the Commission’s proposal is to make the register de facto mandatory for interest representatives through a conditionality principle, requiring that decision makers in all three EU institutions meet only with lobbyists who are registered. Unfortunately, so far the European Parliament and the Council have put forward only voluntary approaches. Tomorrow you will consider the amendment that would provide that Members shall adopt the systematic practice of meeting only those interest representatives who have registered in the transparency register. The Commission would welcome such a move in the context of our negotiations on the interinstitutional agreement. By contrast, we are concerned about another amendment which would weaken the existing provision in the Rules of Procedure. Other amendments seek to increase the information published about meetings with lobbyists. The Commission would like to point out that they solely concern the publication of meetings and so fall short of applying the conditionality principle: not on the register, no meeting. The Commission will assess the consequences of the outcome of your vote tomorrow in preparation for the new political meeting on the proposal for an interinstitutional agreement, which we hope will take place in the margins of the February plenary session.

name: György Schöpflin
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, there are two issues that I would like to touch on. First, the reform of the Rules of Procedure will give this Parliament a much stronger connection with the European Citizens’ Initiative – it has already been mentioned – so that whenever there is a successful initiative, Parliament will be in position to discuss it in plenary. Now this represents a major improvement in the process and will give initiatives much greater visibility. That, in turn, will enhance the relationship between citizens and the EU – something that is badly needed.  The other issue is evidently much more contested. How are political groups in this Parliament to be constituted? On paper, those who launch a group do so because they are linked by a political affinity; they have enough in common, politically, to act together. Hitherto, affinity has been taken on trust and mostly it has worked, but this the system can be gamed and it has been, by the EFDD, for example. Wholly divergent actors say they are linked and, thereby, they come to enjoy the rights and benefits of being a parliamentary group. Through that, they claim to represent the citizens, except as such divergent groups, they cannot and do not and that, of course, makes Parliament looks absurd – hence this reform, which is overdue.

name: Jo Leinen
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to thank Richard Corbett and the working group most warmly for the immense work and balanced report that has been presented here. There have been far more radical proposals, but sensible compromises have been made here. Transparency is the mantra of this parliamentary term. We have promised that our work will become more public and comprehensible, and with the amendments to the Rules of Procedure we are doing our homework here in Parliament. In fact, Members have a free mandate, we cannot be forced not to meet anyone. So we are free to meet anyone who has a concern. But we also say that lobbyists must register, and that when we meet them, we will, if possible, communicate it to the public ourselves. We have now realised that this is not compulsory for Members. This required a law and not just the Rules of Procedure. But it is very much possible to ask officials here in Parliament to put their meetings with lobbyists online. That is precisely the point of this regulation now. I cannot understand why we should vote on it in secret – so, as Richard Corbett said, voting on transparency in a non-transparent manner is a piece of the madhouse here from the history of the European Parliament. This will also go into the annals, if it is so tomorrow. Then I want to talk about the formation of political groups in my time. I know that some of them are still intervening here. So a political group, as the name suggests, must have some kind of political affinity, otherwise it is not a political group. We cannot simply come and say that we are going to come together to reach the figure, then we will have all the advantages, but we will not meet together, we will not vote together, we will not have a common programme. This is not a political group – there is still so much to protest about – that is against the meaning, really also against the seriousness here in Parliament. I hope that tomorrow this will get a majority, because we could indeed run the risk of having more than one fake group here after the next election, which then does not make sense and does not promote the work. All in all, Richard, thank you, and I hope that will have a large majority tomorrow.

name: Marek Jurek
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by September 12, 2018 will be a historic date, but not only because it was the 335th anniversary of John III's re-election from Vienna, but also because that day the European Parliament decided that the votes cast had not been cast. This is the first such event. We are now going a step further, and now Parliament will decide whether or not Members have the right to join, because it is parliament's leadership that is going to decide whether members who want to unite have logical links. Such a fundamental attack on the right of association has not yet been seen. The question is which way we go. When, for example, will the European Commission decide whether the electoral committee in elections is based on logical conclusions or not, because it does not like it? We are really going in a very dangerous direction. The fundamental rights on which the rule of law is based are called into question, and it is by the Authorities of the European Union who like to declassify them. Indeed, if we go this step by step, then from this place, which should be a guarantee of freedom of expression, there will be the greatest threat to freedom of expression in Europe.

name: Max Andersson
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In a democracy, you should not be able to buy political influence. There are more than 30 000 lobbyists in Brussels, and most work for commercial special interests to help their employers get their way. Time and again we see policy proposals being eroded by lobbyists. The committee has a good and balanced compromise proposal on lobbyism, which means that it should be done openly, not in secret. For example, if an energy politician only listens to the gas lobby, and never to the environmental movement, the voters should know. The proposal encourages politicians to listen to both sides, and the transparency of this proposal means that the playing field between those who have a lot of money and those who have good arguments is more even.  When I hear the arguments against the proposal, I wonder whether the EPP has even read it at all. It does not apply to all meetings with people on the street or in elevators. This applies to scheduled meetings, which are planned and entered into a calendar. If you do not want to have a meeting with someone in an elevator posted, do not book a meeting with someone in an elevator! It's that simple. Support the compromise proposal!

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the It is good that we at least have today's debate in plenary. Any Rules of Procedure and their amendment must be subject to an unhindered and intensive democratic debate on the purpose and content. This is important, also in terms of the credibility of our work as a representative of the people. We can only demand and represent to the outside world what and how we practice on a daily basis in our dealings here in this House and with the other EU institutions themselves, how we organise the work of the European Parliament.  Firstly, our group strongly supports the proposed changes to the transparency and traceability of our legislative work, including the mandatory proof of meetings of committee chairmen, rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs with representatives of the so-called lobby structures. I hope that you, ladies and gentlemen, will follow this recasting of the Rules of Procedure by a large majority. It does not restrict the freedom of the mandate, but can help to counteract political disaffection among the general public in all EU28 Member States.  Secondly, we believe that the Rules of Procedure should not be politicised, which could be done with Amendments Nos 86 and 87. We should have discussed this at length in committee. The criteria for this to be used remain completely open to the proposals, and Amendment No 88 only provides a little more assistance.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is late at night for such an important debate; it is late at night for democracy! A debate that you did not even want because you are probably ashamed of it; and good thing "transparency" was the mantra of this mandate. A chetichella revision: a debate as crucial as the one on the composition of the political groups that you have never raised either in the working group or in committee and which comes with three last-minute amendments from three Members of what I can now call the ancien régime, which put the decision on the survival of opposition back in the hands of the majority. The exact opposite of the profound meaning of the word democracy.  Tocqueville would have agreed with me: this is a tyranny of the majority. It believes that Parliament can decide by an absolute majority – not even by qualified majority – on the survival of the groups. But are these oppositions so uncomfortable and annoying? An assessment of political affinity without providing any definition of the same, nor any parameters or objective criteria of measurement. What can we say about your political affinity? What can we say about yours, given that there are delegations in the PPE that have been distrusted by more than half of their political group – right, Mr Schöpflin? Pretend to fight, but in reality, from the Socialists to Fidesz, you all agree when it comes to crushing the rights of groups that can somehow annoy you. And here you also want legal legitimacy to do so, to ensure that Members who are not aligned, or who are judged to be members by an absolute majority, end up in the non-attached Members, who often cannot work because they are not only in a position to do so, given the low allocation of resources and officials who are given to them. Instead of remedying this asymmetry, you have done the exact opposite: you have tried to put as many alternative movements as possible under those conditions, perhaps because, all things considered, you are perhaps afraid of the terms of comparison.  Ladies and gentlemen, this is a real attack on the foundations of democracy, an attack perpetrated by a single majority without any objective criteria: you have tried in every way to keep it hidden, even avoiding a debate, but the citizens – I assure you – have eyes to see and ears to hear, and I also remind you that there is no worse dictatorship than a false democracy.

name: Rainer Wieland (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Blue card is not the same as speaking time. In fact, this report is a re-enactment of the major reforms, and the vast majority of things are largely indisputable. Unfortunately, the report has now been used as an opportunity to undermine the freedom of the mandate. I disagree with other speakers. An attempt is being made to burden the Bureau's organisational mandate with small-scale rules to which the Bureau is to be obliged. That does not belong in the Rules of Procedure. And there is an attempt to turn MPs into accountants of their work. To say that there are no plans to include unplanned meetings – but in the end it would be the case that even a shake hands on the street would come into a certain greyish light; We will oppose that. But it is simply an election campaign, and anyone who has read Gabriel Garcia Mérquez – "Love in times of cholera" – involuntarily comes to mind on this question: "reason in times of election campaigning". We obviously have an election campaign. And now, in the last few days, there has been a bit of excitement about the question of the secret ballot. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has nothing to hide, and the voting list will be available to everyone tomorrow. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has made it clear that it is opposed to this regulation. But we see that MPs have to do their job under group pressure, under the risk of stigma. That is why we want to give everyone the freedom to vote here. Mr Corbett, your press release that the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats wants to hide has, let me say, fall far short of the intellectual brilliance that we are accustomed to from you. That was a very simple argument. And Mr Castaldo, you are grabbing money here and forming a group, and I would have liked to ask you: how many times has this group met in the first place? Not once, sir. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome this initiative in order to enhance transparency. I must say that there is a clear problem here with the freedom of office. I must say that I am clearly ore against this idea of making representative democracy a kind of direct democracy. Representative democracy should not go after populism and populism wants voyeurism and that is what is essentially in Amendment No 20. It is a voyeurism that brings us closer, not to representative democracies, but to direct democracies and this is a bad way. But precisely because we are a representative democracy, I also want to say here, on my own behalf and on behalf of the Portuguese delegation of the PSD in the Ppe Group, that I am frontally against the secret vote. I believe that the secret vote is not compatible with representative democracy on such an issue. And so I am sorry, despite voting with the line of the Ppe group, that we are not here to vote openly in front of all the people who elected us, because that is precisely the way to make representative democracy and to show that colleagues who want to turn Parliament into a kind of open box in which we are just puppets and we do not have a role of our own with freedom , this cannot be done openly before everyone. So i do not follow my group on this point and I think that the vote should be a transparent and open vote, even though I voted fully with the Ppe line.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I will speak to you here, as chair of the harassment committee, about the appropriate code of conduct that you have inserted, Mr Corbett, into your report. Since 2014, I have been working in this parliament on the goal of 'zero harassment'. I am subject to confidentiality and, rest assured, I will not break the secret tonight, but I know by heart all the complaints I have had to investigate since 2014, the whole process of investigating these complaints, which I had to put in place. I would like to tell you here: let us not shelter behind the freedom of mandate because harassment is a crime. It is a crime for all of us who would commit it, and you risk being brought to justice and you risk criminals. So you don't hide behind the secret when it comes to harassment. That is why the law, which is the same for all, must allow us to have an open, incisive, serious anti-harassment policy, and that it must and must, here in this Parliament, refuse that a person who rejects the code of conduct should be able to obtain representations from Parliament, important positions. It is our honour, your honour, the honour of Parliament. We owe it to all our fellow citizens: I call on you to vote on Amendments 13 and 68.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would first of all like to say, as a member of the PPE Group, that it is also not very understandable to me why we should vote non-transparently on this issue and on transparency. I think that either we have an opinion and we are able to kidnap it and declare it publicly in front of the public, or then we hide behind a secret ballot. I certainly want to vote publicly on this. I would also like to comment on what the rapporteur, Mr Corbett, has said about the question of the rapporteurs and their reporting of the contacts they are supposed to have with lobbyists. I think that the adjustment that is being proposed – that is, they have to report those lobbying contacts – is the right one. I just want to point out that the planned negotiations, I assume those calendar meetings, should perhaps be better lit up. I can also imagine a situation where someone uploads a particular situation to a Member, i.e. it will have some effect, the appearance that such an act is planned, and then he will then, for example, be publicly coated. These can really be very politically sensitive things, I think it would be good to clarify that further.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I think we agree, all of us here at the debate, that there was a need to improve the regulation. And, lo and behold, this debate has been offered, and I see that even the colleagues who asked for it are not here in the room. If they were interested, they should have been at the debate. I hope that through this regulation we will improve not only formally, in writing, but also on the application of the regulation, that we will no longer meet that a committee chair decides without consulting the group, or a committee coordinator decides to send a letter to the President of Parliament without consulting the group, as has happened now, even these days, with the mobility package. I believe that Parliament's responsible parties must follow this, and yes, they want transparency! Why do we have to vote secretly? The people need to see, they need to know, we need to take our vote, and I very much believe that there must be no more incidents in Parliament. We must set an example for those we represent, and I do not agree with language as we have learned so far here, because I do not believe that a man who represents citizens should behave indecently with his colleagues in Parliament.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, I have repeatedly pointed out in this Chamber that the Rules of Procedure restrict the exercise of Members' mandate. First of all, it limits the number of questions to five. Secondly, with a recent change in the Rules of Procedure, the Member can only submit amendments to his own committee. If the Member wants to submit amendments to another committee, he must find a colleague of the relevant committee. Thirdly, as it appears, there are now restrictions on the formation of political groups. Because they say there should be political affinity. Who's going to judge political affinity? It seems that the major political groups want to dissolve any new groups that will be formed in the European Parliament and, of course, to 'grab' the resources as well. These are things too simple. Finally, the preventive scrutiny of questions must be stopped. We ask questions and the Bureau rejects them by saying that they are outside the jurisdiction or that the Commission has no competence. Who's going to judge that? We as Members will ask the questions and if the Commission considers that it has no competence it will say so. The Bureau will not say that, Mr President.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr. Reiner Wieland is worried here that grouping is money. Well, I ask why you have created a system where money for a Member depends on his or her membership. This is unfair and it creates inequality. You have the full mouth of equality in your declarations, and you create inequality here, because the money you receive depends on which group and how large a political group it belongs to. This is political corruption and it is reprehensible, not that you can form groups as you wish. So it's that it's limited here again in these subsequent free speech amendments that feminists once again want to close their mouths to awkward topics. Only voters can take away a Member's right to speak because he speaks on their behalf and not on behalf of the President or anyone else. There can be no censorship in Parliament, no European censorship, no other censorship. The groups are to confirm that they will pursue the objectives of the Treaties. And why? If citizens want to change the objectives of the Treaties, then Members have the right to do so. And it is not possible to prevent any political initiative at the outset simply because it does not agree with the objectives so far decreed. If you want to introduce such restrictions on the formation of groups here, then immediately enter the leading role of the Chadecko-Socialist Group into the Treaties and we will have a deal done. Let's play fair cards.

name: Richard Corbett
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I wish to thank all the colleagues who have contributed, and indeed the Commission. I think we are making progress, too, on that other front you mentioned, on the work on the transparency register. This is, I hope, not incompatible with that, but rather complementary. However, there are certainly some misunderstandings. These issues were discussed at the committee stage – they have not suddenly come out of the blue. We had quite long discussions. And, Mr Sośnierz, we’re not saying that no groups can propose changes to the Treaty. Of course, they can propose changes to the Treaty. But mostly there seems to be a high level of support for most of the proposals in my report. The controversial one, it appears to me, is the secret vote, and I’m glad some PPE Group members are not going to support that. On this question of political groups, there is already a requirement in our rules – there always has been – that political groups have to have affinity, as they do in most national parliaments. We have already, on one occasion, dissolved a political group because it did not have political affinity. That case went to the Court. The Court ruled that Parliament was right to dissolve such a group. So it’s not unreasonable to check that this existing provision is actually applied properly and that we have a procedure for dealing with it. In those cases where there is serious doubt, we have to have the possibility of examination – where there is serious doubt and it warrants investigation. Creating a political group in the European Parliament is much easier than in national parliaments. You only need just over 3% of the membership. If you have that you have access to significant resources: you can effectively help yourself to taxpayers’ money. If you’re not really a political group – if you are a fake group set up just for that purpose – then it’s right that we defend the taxpayer against abuse. This Parliament gives equal rights to all its Members as individuals, but the right to create political groups in any Parliament is intended to facilitate the work of the Parliament, so that people can speak on behalf of large numbers of other Members, to improve the work of the Parliament – so that you, Mr President, have an easier time giving the floor to different people, and every view can be expressed in a coherent way. Fake political groups do not help the work of the Parliament – they abuse the work of the Parliament.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Only that doubt is sometimes a very subjective feeling. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 31 January 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – (2008) The deep and dragged-down crisis of the European Union, along with the attack on social achievements and rights and the setback of the civilizational dimension associated with it, also entails a disturbing dimension of attack on democracy itself. The attack on social rights and the attack on democracy go hand in hand. Thus one must read the successive attacks on the national sovereignty of states, the attempt to empty their institutions of sovereignty and the concentration of power in supranational for a, at the service of great capital and the great powers. In the light of this more general reality, the successive amendments to the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament should also be read, with a view to limiting the intervention of Members and smaller political groups, bureaucratising the functioning of parliament and reducing and weakening instruments for scrutinising the legislative process and action of the different EU institutions. It is significant that these efforts unite the right and social democracy. Here we strongly denounce and repudiate the attempt to create new and serious obstacles to the formation of political groups, based on an arbitrary and subjective criterion of "political affinity". This is a step further in the journey that has been jeopardising democracy and pluralism which, hypocritically, right and social democracy claim to defend.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE)
text: Written. – Procedural rules are important for a parliament. They are the foundation of parliamentary interaction. Continuity in procedure ensures predictability, which is a good thing because that makes parliamentary work clear and transparent. But a procedure should never become a law of Meden and Persians. Society is constantly evolving and that is true of social and political debate. Well-informed and empowered citizens rightly expect a transparent political process. It presupposes an openness of both the office itself and its implementation. The changes to the parliamentary procedural rules, as initially proposed by Mr Wieland in an internal working group, largely meet this changed public expectation. A large part of Parliament also shares this view, which makes it very easy to approve the basic report in AFCO. However, in the run-up to the plenary vote, the text was amiced on crucial points. Among other things, the publication of planned meetings with official lobby groups or their representatives, transparency on the use of expenses and the compulsory signing of a code of conduct were hotly debated. However, I myself have not had to think. On each of these points, I voted for the greatest possible transparency.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Ordinance 114/2018 on the imposition of taxes in the financial, telecom and energy sectors is a terrible blow to the Romanian business environment, but also to Romania's credibility at European level. In the financial-banking field, the tax that has been arbitrarily linked to the ROBOR level will lead to a reduction in lending, with a strong negative impact on consumption, production and investment. In the field of energy - and I have also asked the European Commission - measures such as capping the price of natural gas, setting electricity-administered prices by ANRE and charging energy companies' turnover by 2% are in clear contradiction with European legislation. Ironically and painfully, although the public discourse was directed against multinational companies, the most affected were Romanian banks and companies, some of which had as majority shareholder the Romanian state itself. The increase of the energy turnover tax by up to 20 times will certainly be reflected in both energy bills and energy security, just as the fees imposed on banks and telecom companies will be found in higher costs, which will be paid especially by the poorest of Romanian citizens.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Article 14 of our Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union proclaims the right to private property. And that's what I wanted to talk to you about. In Spain, in the Balearic Islands, a left-wing government has just published and passed a Law on public roads and hiking routes that affects Mallorca and Menorca and implies an indiscriminate conversion of private rural roads into public roads, giving the Administration uncontrolled power.  What it entails is a conculcation of the right to private property, an intolerable attack and also, at the same time, a hit-and-run to the right to personal and family privacy.  It also affects all agricultural activity, all livestock and forestry activities. That is why, from here I would like to call on the Balearic authorities to return to the path of sanity, to the path of European values and to protect that right to property, that right to privacy and, therefore, to return to the path set by Europe, which is nothing more than that of law and the rule of law.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to draw attention in my intervention to the intention of the PSD-ALDE government, headed by Viorica Dancilă, to cut from the income tax budgets that belonged to local communities. He thus wants to steal the money paid by Romanians, as income tax, from their honest work. Instead of these sums reaching the local communities, it is intended to direct them to Bucharest, where they are to be divided at the will of the government. This practice primarily punishes the liberal administrations, which are the best performing in Romania, wishing to make them dependent on the government, which seriously violates local autonomy. Local governments are thus condemned to underdevelopment, as they will have to give up important investments, including from European funds, seriously affecting the safety of citizens and their daily lives. Mrs Dăncilă, I ask you once again, from the height of the European Parliament, to take your hands off this money! They are not mayors' money, they are citizens' money and they must be used only for the development of local communities.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. The European Parliament raises its case in countless cases where civil activists, artists, journalists or anyone is persecuted for political reasons in any country. If Europe speaks, many governments will back down. Many people owe the return of their freedom to the voice of Europe and many are honored for their heroism. However, there are also less visible forms of deeds. I ask respectfully how the European Union will act if the right to work, housing or a decent life is harmed even on its own territory. More broadly, I am talking about the lack of social rights. In the same way, we can ask, even geographically, whether there are areas of Europe where the right to medical care, the right to access information or the right to access education are very limited. This is being remedied by the concept that we have developed here in the European Parliament and marketed as a smart village, which, by the way, seeks to give new opportunities for legal protection with the technological possibilities of today.

name: Rory Palmer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Clumber Park is a wonderful place, a historic part of the Dukeries countryside, a place of significant natural beauty and habitat, including designated sites of special scientific interest. It’s where I went on days out as a child. It’s where I take my daughters today.  It’s also where INEOS wish to carry out geological surveys for shale gas. The National Trust attempted to prevent this through the courts, but the legal process offers limited scope to challenge proposed surveying for shale gas.  So I speak today to ask INEOS to think again on this and not to compromise the natural beauty and important wildlife habitats in Clumber. I also speak to give my ongoing support to the National Trust in their efforts to prevent fracking in Clumber Park.  I don’t believe the many, many people who visit and enjoy Clumber want to see fracking take place there. It would be devastating to see fracking in Clumber and I will do all I can, alongside others, to prevent it.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, today in the European Parliament we have honoured the millions of victims of the Holocaust who were murdered by Nazism. We in Greece do not forget the thousands of our compatriots who were executed by Nazi occupation troops in our homeland between 1941 and 1944. We do not forget the Greeks who were murdered in the Nazi concentration camps. But greek relatives of the victims, executed by German occupation troops, are still awaiting vindication, as Germany continues to refuse to pay German reparations. Even today, Germany refuses to repay its debts to Greece. Debts including: the war reparations granted by the Paris Peace Conference in 1946, the compulsory occupation loan, the reparations of the relatives of the victims executed by nazi occupation troops and the return of archaeological treasures. Berlin must therefore assume its responsibilities. To pay the damages he owes. The Greek people demand it. Relatives of the victims of Nazism demand it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Europe is a territory free of the death penalty, an inhumane and cruel punishment which degrades those who apply it. That is why the Union developed a strategy to eradicate it from all countries, and one of its pieces is to be interested, and to intervene if necessary, in all cases where European citizens are convicted. And especially if the evidence on which the conviction is based is inconclusive.  This is the case with Pablo Ibar. A European citizen who has just been convicted of a triple murder committed twenty-five years ago. To call evidence to the faint signs that do not allow or place it in the place of events seems like a joke. Reading what counts some of the jurors, who have just retracted their decision, explains the prejudices and pressures that could lead to the conviction.  We therefore call for a swift and forceful European intervention, because we are in time to turn pablo Ibar's horror feature film into a film with a just and therefore happy ending for two decades. That is why, Commissioner, I ask you to do everything in your power to deal with this case.

name: Ana Miranda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, our decisions as political representatives that we are have direct consequences on citizenship, sometimes a serious consequence, sometimes very serious consequences, as in the case of the Accident of the Alvia train that occurred near Santiago de Compostela in Galicia in July 2013, which caused 80 deaths and 140 injuries. To clarify their causes, we have always been at the side of the victims in the search for truth and justice incessantly in these years, in an intense work with constant meetings with the Commissioner for Transport, in constant contact with the European Railway Agency. And so firm has been our presence with the victims that the European Commission last week opened infringement proceedings against the Spanish State for non-compliance with European railway safety legislation. Because the People's Party and the Socialist Party in Spain cannot be allowed to continue to maintain an complicit silence to conceal the true causes of the accident, because those who made the wrong decisions cannot go unpunished and because it was not only the driver's fault. Truth and justice for the victims of europe's most serious accident of 25 years!

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, in Portugal, the CTT, Correios de Portugal, have been privatised. The results are disastrous: brutal increase in tariffs, 564 stations and stations closed, mail distribution slower than 30 years ago, 900 fewer workers. Since 2014, the company has distributed more than 240 million euros in dividends to shareholders, distributing dividends in excess of net income this year. They are now announcing the dismissal of 800 more workers in addition to the 340 whose redundancies are underway, as well as the sale of more assets and the closure of 22 more stations. The post office is an irreplaceable instrument for the social, economic and territorial cohesion of our country. The post office must be the guarantor of a public postal service at the service of the country and the people. It is necessary to free the CTT from the ruinous private management and regain public control of the Post Office of Portugal. There is also a need to put an end to the ruinous liberalisation and privatisation processes sponsored by the European Union.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, on 5 November 2015, the rupture of the Mariana dam gave rise to a river of mud that, traveling 633 kilometres of watercourses, hit 39 municipalities, victimised 19 people and caused the biggest environmental disaster in Brazil. To date, investigations into those responsible have continued without any conviction. Three years later, the new dam, the Feijão Mine, the Brumadinho Complex, the same owner of Mariana, vale, collapsed again and the avalanche of mud and mining waste already caused 75 dead, 279 disappeared and left several indigenous tribes without their plantations and without drinking water. When only 3% of Brazil's 24,000 dams were surveyed and the Brumadinho dam identified by the National Water Agency at the end of last year as one of the 45 at risk of rupture, the question that now arises is not whether there will be another tragedy, but when it will be repeated. In view of the imminent threat, the European Union cannot but urge brazilian federal and state authorities to identify those responsible for this disaster and to toughen the licensing rules for new mining dams and to implement more effective and more demanding surveillance systems.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I will raise a case of which you are aware. In 2017 I made you a letter. It's about Finland and it's about how the laws work there. You know, I am sure, that in Finland there are laws giving the child the right to appear in court. The case of Dr. Camelia Simimal is already well known in the world, not only in Europe. He's been trying to get his kids back for three years. Children have been institutionalised, although Finnish law also says that children are only taken from the family if there is a danger of violence against children. Then the children are entitled, at 12, to the court and are not allowed to go to court. The woman wants to repatriate, not to a third world country, in Romania, back with her children. Is there nothing we can do? What Europe are we talking about? What rights of the child and about what the citizen's right to free movement? Please, Commissioner, try to ask Finland how it respects the rule of law and the laws of justice, because I see that resolutions on eastern countries are being made, on the rule of law.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – A Uachtaráin, closim nach bhfuil comhaltaí an tí seo sásta go gcaithfidh siad a dteangacha féin and labhairt; with gabháil leithscéil. Cén fáth? Sub álainn agus is iontach an rud é teangacha éagsúla and chloisteáil. Ba mhór an botún é by an áilleacht chéanna and chaomhnú agus, cosúil le bláth álainn, by chaomhnú, gheobhaidh sí bás. Beatha teanga í a labhairt. Bígí on an airdeal mar sin, and chairde. Má ghabhann tú leithscéal i leith do theanga inniu, tá an baol ann go gcaillfidh tú on fad í agus beidh sé deacair í a fháil ar ais. An rud atá éasca do mhórán inniu, b'fhéidir go mbeidh sé deacair do bheagán amárach. Gach focal ina chnocán, gach abairt ina cnoc, gach alt ina shliabh, with dreapadh Everest gach scéal. Bígí on airdeal, and chairde. Bígí on airdeal.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Mr President, MAT, repression and persecution are an indispensable complement to the unpopular political government of SYRIZA. Now, we also have fast track trials for militant farmers, as moral perpetrators, to seize pavement from tractors for their roadblocks. The terror of the people will not pass. Small and medium-sized farmers are struggling to stay in their fields, against concentrating the land in a few hands. They call for the abolition of all direct and indirect restrictions on agricultural and livestock production imposed by the common agricultural policy of the European Union and the Government of SYRIZA. They oppose new cuts, subsidies and aid. They are fighting to reduce the cost of production - which, together with the low prices of the traders, leads the farm to a dead end - for duty-free oil, cheap agricultural electricity and irrigation water, the abolition of VAT on agricultural means and supplies, for their immediate relief with compensation to those affected, reduction of insurance contributions, tax exemptions, increase of an unsealed limit and no seizure of first, second residence and land. Solidarity, with the right to fight small and medium-sized farming, so as not to pass its unraveling and repression!

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. A state of emergency has been declared in the centre of Szeklerland, Romania, in Târgu Mureş. Hungarian students and teachers object to the fact that, after the former Hungarian Medical University was sedented into a large Romanian university, the chauvinistic Romanian university management continued to restrict their rights to learn in the mother tongue step by step. The European Parliament has rightly condemned the deplorable state of the rule of law in Romania. We rightly expect the President-in-Office of the Union, Romania, to put an end to his anti-Hungarian policies and to ensure the fundamental human and community rights of Hungarians in Transylvania. As part of this, we demand hungarian autonomy of education, the restoration of the Medical and Pharmaceutical University of Târgu Mureş in its original form. Don't let the EU set double standards. While you are unjustly siding with Soros's CEU, do not leave the Hungarian University in Romania to its fate.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am deeply concerned by the harrowing threats faced by LGBT people around the world.  Last week Jean Wyllys, a gay congressmen in Brazil, announced he was leaving the country due to death threats. Still in Brazil, the sickening murder of Marielle Franco, an LGB activist, shocked the international community, shining a light on the acts of violence against those who dare speak out against the Bolsonaro fascist government. In Chechnya, the LGBT community is persecuted and tortured in complete violation of human rights conventions, and with the silence of the Russian Government. These cases reveal that homophobia is seeping into public space and some people in power are actively enabling it. In front of blatant human rights violations, the EU cannot merely wag a finger at the perpetrators. We must condemn homophobic governments and provide a platform for victims to raise their voices.  However, the protection of members of the LGBTI community must start here. As a British MEP, I want to voice my concerns for the members of the LGBTI community post-Brexit as it’s apparent that the standards of the Charter of Fundamental Rights will be abandoned. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, as today, twenty-three years ago, Turkish military force landed on the Greek rocky island of Little Imia, bringing the two countries to the brink of war, while a Greek helicopter crashed in the area resulting in the death of the three soldiers on board. This sad anniversary underlines the fact that, as then and now, the European Union lacks an adequate common guarantee of borders and a corresponding common defence infrastructure. This huge shortage undermines the prospect of European integration. It is an oxymoron to talk about the Union and at the same time to leave its Member States alone and unprotected in the face of external threats. The Greek-Turkish border in the Aegean and Evros is at the same time a Euro-Turkish border and the halt to Turkish aggression must become a common affair of all Member States within the framework of European integration.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. On several occasions, the European institutions have been informed of the unprecedented situation that, in Romania, one of the higher education institutions called multicultural, the Medical and Pharmaceutical University of Târgu Mureş, has simply not complyed with the current education law since 2011, citing university autonomy. According to the law, they were supposed to create a special faculty in Hungarian, but this is constantly rejected by the Romanian-majority Senate of the university. A few weeks ago, an English-language faculty was established. However, the same decision is no longer considered acceptable in relation to the Hungarian-speaking faculty. This is serious discrimination and a disregard for the principle of rule of law. The situation has gotten much worse in the last few days, because just before the exam period, the exam conditions were changed at the expense of Hungarian students, not caring about the opposition of hungarian teachers. This decision shows the direct consequences of ignoring the law and the worth of legislation that is not put into practice. In Romania, there are many such paper-only minority-friendly provisions, while the country claims to be at the forefront of the fight to combat minorities.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, colleagues, Romania's takeover of the Presidency of the Council of the European Union is one of the most important moments of the present. As you saw last week in committees, in dialogues with the ministers of the Romanian Government, the Bucharest executive treats this task with seriousness and professionalism, which we are prepared to successfully carry out. Through the ambitious agenda that the Romanian Government has set for this mandate, but also through the important files it will have to mediate, we will demonstrate that Romania is one of the most important members of the Union, unequivocally employed in European construction. Twelve years after accession, Romania will write a beautiful history tab in the process of political unification of the old continent.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the antics in the British ‘House of Chaos’ prove that their commitments to protect the Good Friday Agreement and the peace process are written in sand. Theresa May’s objective was to unite the Tory Party and shift the blame for a no—deal Brexit mess to the EU. Only 57 days to go, and they’re shredding the Good Friday Agreement line by line. Once again, they’re threatening and trying to intimidate the Irish people, but we will not be bullied by the British establishment. This Parliament has supported the Good Friday Agreement in all of its parts, and that means all the provisions, including the provision for a unity referendum. The people of Ireland have a right to self—determination, and we make no apologies – no apologies to anyone – for working to end the partition of Ireland. When Article 50 was triggered, I stated in this Parliament that Britannia was waiving the rules and Britain was ignoring the democratic deficit in the north of Ireland – indeed, creating a democratic deficit by ignoring the democratic wishes of the people of the north of Ireland to remain within the EU. A solution to the Brexit negotiation mess is the reunification of Ireland.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: Mr President, the Social Democrats, Greens and GUE/NGL have nominated Tsipras and Zaef for the shameful Prespa Agreement. It's a challenge! They describe as a historic achievement an Agreement imposed by NATO with "plass" SYRIZA, the Euro-NATO so-called Left, which strengthens NATO in the bloody and broken by the interventions of the Balkans, cultivates altruisms and nationalisms and "divides and reigns" puts people at risk. It makes NATO a guarantor of peace and security. People remember NATO only for wars, interventions, bombings and border changes. Those who set up stolen progressive fronts against the right and the far right get congratulations from Trump, Merkel, NATO, Erdoğan, the Austrian far-right Kurz, the reactionary Macron. They wash away, literally, imperialism! The "patriarch" of Italian capitalism, fiat owner Gianni Agnelli, is vindicated for saying: "The Left sometimes does the job better than the Right. With such a Left what to do with the Right!".

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: – Mr President, the news flew around the world yesterday that the Pakistani Supreme Court had upheld the acquittal of Mrs Asie Bibi. I consider it my duty, at least symbolically from this place, to thank President Tajani, all my colleagues who supported the resolutions on this matter, the European Union Special Envoy Figeľ and also the hundreds of thousands of Union citizens who supported the petition for the liberation of Asia Bibi. It has been confirmed that the European Parliament, even with its politically diverse composition, can contribute to the defence of religious freedom in the world. If we were to devote at least as much time and energy to the fight to save the millions of women and mothers persecuted for their faith as the fight for quotas for women on the supervisory and management boards of the big companies, which Parliament will debate again tomorrow, the world would become better, freer and fairer.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Dear President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. Commissioner Jourová, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Jourová, for her excellent work. Colleagues! I want to talk about the fact that a new government was approved in Latvia a week ago. It is currently led by Arturs Krišjānis Kariņš, our colleague from the EPP faction. But how often do we, those sitting here, in the plenary committees and everywhere we talk about third-country nationals being involved in elections, fit into our processes in Europe, something putin, the Kremlin is trying to do. But Krišjānis Kariņš is a U.S. citizen! Imagine this situation, colleagues. A US citizen is currently leading the government of a Member State of the European Union! And it's all right! I think we need to develop criteria that third-country nationals are outside. We only have to rely on European citizens.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: By the way, I would like to congratulate Mr Krišjānis Kariņš, with whom I have worked very well.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome the Commission's initiative precisely in the fight against the spread of dangerous terrorist content on the Internet. I really welcome this initiative, I think that the Commission can also act much more effectively and effectively, and it has my full support on such a serious subject. However, I wonder how the legislation responds to what precedes this spread of terrorist content, that is to say, to hateful ideologies, to dangerous manifestations that reflect or originate in religion, in political ideologies. In the Czech Republic, we have a specific case of a previously wrongfully convicted pensioner who felled trees on railway lines and claimed these acts of terrorism as the actions of Muslims. I think this is precisely the example of radicalisation, which is dangerous and had its origins, a reflection in its favor with the extremist parliamentary faction in the Czech Republic.  I think that we need not only to focus on the dissemination of terrorist content on the Internet, but also on the causes, on the undershooer. I would very much like us to focus on these very topics as well.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, today we celebrated International Holocaust Remembrance Day. Allow me to give this speech in memory of my grandparents, who survived the concentration camp in Terezin. It is an important time to recognise the still-present issue of anti-Semitism in Europe. On 30 January – this day – in 1933, Adolph Hitler took power in Germany, in silence and without protests from democratic forces. Nobody could imagine where his populism would eventually lead. Anti-Semitism was deeply rooted in Europe at that time and it has not disappeared yet. Since 2013, almost 90% of the Jewish communities in Europe say that anti-Semitism has increased. Almost 40% of them state that they have considered emigrating. Therefore, hatred against Jews and racist prejudice belong not just to the past: Jewish people, like other minorities, face them every day in various, and sometimes hidden, forms. Honourable Members, the European Union’s key values are humanity, dignity and respect for everyone. The European Union is a true home for the Jewish people.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate on this point on the agenda.
